That alone has meant that older Australians have had a $13.60 increase that they would never have got if the Australian Labor Party were sitting on this side of the House. And God help them if they do!

The argument now is that we did not tell them. The interesting thing is that on 10 July 2000 Nora McGuire from the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation—and they do a great job representing their members—even stated on the ABC's 7.30 report:

quote.para: The four per cent that pensions are being increased is actually a 2 per cent real increase and 2 per cent advance for the March CPI.

speech.para: We stated that. We were very clear about that. We put it in a number of publications. Simon Crean, the member for Hotham, got it right, but the member for Lilley could not get it right. The member for Hotham put out a statement in his electorate explaining that the four per cent increase was made up of two components. This is a good government because we gave them that component nine months in advance—which they would never have received under the Labor Party, leaning back on their indexation points.
There was an interesting talkback today on Greg Evans's radio show and I would like to share it with the House. Greg Evans was the presenter and a chap rings in called Barry:

quote.para: Evans: What can we do for you, Barry? What are your thoughts on all of this?

speech.para: This is regarding the clawback beat-up. The discussion continues:

quote.para: Barry: Well, I'm afraid I have to—unless I missed something—I have to really defend the government on this.
Evans: Yeah.
Barry: I'm an aged pension as my wife is ...
Evans: Mmm hmm.

Barry: ... and Centrelink, who pays the pension, puts out a very good quarterly publication called Aged Pension News. And as far back as April last year it was made perfectly clear in that publication that the increase in March this year would be affected due to the four per cent pay they'd made in July last year.
Evans: Well, that's what the Prime Minister is saying of course and he's saying that because we warned you of that there is no clawback.
Barry: Well, that's absolutely right ...
Evans: Mm.
Barry: ... and I must say that if pensioners read what's given to them instead of complaining all the time ...
Evans: No, it's not the pensioners that are complaining here, it's the Opposition understandably, you know.
Barry: Yeah, but the pensioners are being sucked into it, Greg.
Evans: Mm.
Barry: You know, I think it's a political beat up, quite frankly.

speech.para: A political beat-up. This is talkback. The discussion continues:

quote.para: Evans: Okay.
Barry: And the other point I'd just quickly like to make is that if you look at the twelve months from March 2000 to March 2001, assuming that the two per cent increase is going to be paid ...
Evans: Mm.
Barry: ... the percentage increase in pensions according to my mathematics is ...
Evans: Will be six ...
Barry: ... seven-point-eight.
Evans: Yeah.
Barry: Which is well ahead of inflation. So, I really think it's just a beat up and I just wish the government ...

speech.para: Of course, the lesson for us is that we should obviously get out and market our products more by telling pensioners that this is a total beat-up by the Australian Labor Party. The talkback caller went on:

quote.para: Barry: Well, to clear it up because I think the anti ... ah ... well, the pensioner groups are being sucked in on it. People are ... pensioners who just don't understand the mathematics of it are being suck [sic] in by it.

speech.para: Of course, they are being sucked into it by the Australian Labor Party. I think it was opportunistic of them to take advantage of it. Again, I suppose, the criticism of us could be that we should be getting out there and telling people that these are fraudulent lies that the Australian Labor Party are saying. The interview went on, and is just one example of a talkback caller from Melbourne yesterday.

You have to ask yourself what the member for Lilley is talking about when he says that we are allowing members to have trusts and we are doing nothing. It is this government, my friend, that is introducing legislation—we have actually done it; it is coming into force in 2001. We are saying to people, particularly those who own trusts or private companies, that we do not believe that they should be entitled to social security payments. It is this government that is putting propriety back into the system to ensure that people who may be using those vehicles are not paid social security, which the Labor Party never did anything about. They never did anything because their masters are not only the elite of the trade union movement but, indeed, some among the elite of the business sector. This government has not only been pursuing welfare reform but is making a fairer system, particularly for people who are claiming social security payments and particularly for pensioners.

The member for Lilley also claims that those people have gone backwards. But it was this government that, when it came to private health insurance, introduced the 30 per cent rebate, which is fundamentally important for older Australians because they cannot get into the public hospital system. The money that we give to the states, particularly Labor states, does not go back into those public hospital services. It is this government that gave that rebate to all Australians, and it is particularly older Australians who have been direct recipients of that.

Talking about other issues where the Labor Party claim to have looked after people, not only pensioners: what happened to the tax cuts? Do you remember those? Do you remember the tax cuts that were promised that would have benefited all Australians? As soon as Labor got back in in 1993, they were abolished. Now that definitely was a clawback; that was a clawback that was never delivered. You talked about other increases, particularly in Medicare. Carmen Lawrence denied news reports that the Medicare levy was to go up. There was no proposal to increase the levy, but they jacked it up straightaway. Or do you remember the Commonwealth Bank? Talk about a breach of trust. A letter from the Treasurer back then, in the Commonwealth bank prospectus, said that the government had no intention whatsoever of further reducing its shareholding. This was an ironclad agreement. But of course what did they do? Within months they sold off the rest of the bank and the proceeds just went into recurrent expenditure. The record of the Australian Labor Party, what they say and what they do, in regard to older Australians—and all Australians—is absolutely abominable.

When we talk about older Australians, what we have donewhich has been very beneficialis to reduce the withdrawal rate. If older Australians choose to work and earn, say, more than $102 a fortnight, we have said to them that instead of losing 50 cents in the dollar they lose only 40 cents. That was a positive move to encourage older Australians if they wanted to take part-time work. We have made changes to capital gains tax, which of course the Australian Labor Party introduced. We have introduced franking credits, which is particularly important. And, most importantly, we have introduced the savings bonus. The savings bonus has gone to over 1.7 million Australians. On average, over 74 per cent have received in excess of $500. What compensation was there when Labor were in power when they—as I mentioned before—increased, without any consultation, the wholesale sales tax regime, which had a dramatic effect on older Australians? And they never had pensions tied to 25 per cent of male total weekly earnings. They actually had only two adjustments separately, and they were, just coincidentally, prior to an election.

We have been very up front with pensioners and particularly with older Australians with regard to GST compensation. There was a four per cent increase in July, which was made up of a two per cent real increase above the rate of inflation and a two per cent advance. They had an increase again in September of last year and they will get another increase on 20 March this year. Again, we have guaranteed that people on pensions will be two per cent ahead of the rate of inflation. This graph demonstrates the shallowness of the debating point by the member for Lilley. It states that older Australians and those on pensions are receiving $30 more today than they received in June last year. They would have received significantly less, of course, if the Australian Labor Party had been in power.

We have also changed the means test, which is very important for pensioners. We have increased the thresholds by 2.5 per cent, both on income and assets. We have also increased the income cut-off levels for part-time pensions. So we believe that, if you are on a pension or on a part-time pension and you want to find some extra work to have some more earnings, then we will recognise that and integrate your payment back into the social security system, which the Australian Labor Party never did. It is interesting when you look at the actual amount since 1996: pensions have gone up $58 since then. We recognise that this reflects the rate of inflation, and let us remember that it was this government which reduced inflation substantially from the double-digit figures of the halcyon days of the Keating-Hawke stewardship—

talk.start.para: —The hell days.

—Yes, the hell days, as the Chief Government Whip says. Or, to put it another way, that is $1,500 a year that they are receiving today that they would not have received, and that is entirely appropriate for older Australians, to ensure that they are compensated. The Labor Party are just using older Australians as a political football to make points, which is scaremongering. But also the Labor Party knew only too well about the compensation that we put into place last July. The member for Hotham even wrote to all his constituents explaining it. But no, of course, little tricky dicky over here continues to masquerade in the sense that—
(Mr Nehl)—The minister will refer to the member for Lilley by his correct title.

—I get overly enthusiastic, Mr Deputy Speaker. The issue that is continuing to be portrayed here is that we did not inform people. We did, through numerous publications. We have been a good government in the sense of the compensation measures that we have put in place, and particularly the last two indexation increases. The indexation of rent assistance was actually introduced by the Labor Party in 1993. The Labor Party know full well how the indexation arrangements work. We have ensured that for those who are paying at the maximum rate in particular it has been increased further, from seven per cent to 10 per cent. That will benefit over 550,000 people right across this country. In between those minimum thresholds and maximum thresholds we are paying 75c in every dollar.

speech.para: Certainly, in some areas, because of the adjustment process and the picture in time, there may be some adjustments. However, the important point is that, because of the overall compensation that we are paying, those on pensions or other social security payments in particular will be significantly better off. Of course they are going to be significantly better off with a government which has been far more responsible, particularly with policies for older Australians, than the Labor Party will ever be. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Community Services, in his response to the shadow minister, said, `You are just making points and using pensioners.' Of course we are. We are pointing out to the pensioners of Australia and to the government where the government is clawing back some of their fixed income. The minister said that we did not compensate for wholesale sales tax increases. The wholesale sales tax had a different base. It certainly was not a tax on the essentials, like the GST is. That argument is totally false. The minister mentioned the 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance. I would point out that there is $3 billion that is not in public hospitals in this country. In my electorate I do not think there is one doctor that is now bulk-billing. Medicare rebates to doctors have stagnated and this is having a big effect on pensioners.

speech.para: These are the pensioners that were born in the 1920s or before. These are the pensioners that went through the Depression. These are the people that went to war and defended this country. Then, in the 1950s and 1960s, they helped build our great nation. The people in my electorate who are in this age group—the people that have gone on to reach this time of their life—have been through many governments in their lifetime. There have been many dangers, many fears for their country, many difficulties and many uncertainties. They have raised families. And then they end up with the Howard-Anderson government. They end up with a government that wants to claw back some of the lousy cost of living increase that will help them continue to be able to purchase and to have the quality of life that they enjoy. This government, in all its meanness, is probably the worst government that any pensioner has had to deal with. The Howard-Anderson government is a very bad, mean government. I do not believe this measure is going to work—this government knows that it is not going to work—and we are going to see another backdown. There will be another backdown like the one on petrol. This minister will have to do a backflip. The government should be up-front and apologise for this effort to claw back the compensation from the pensioners.

The government has decided that it needs compensation because of the impact that the GST has had on the price of just about everything. The next thing we know it is trying to get the compensation back. After it had paid it, it is now trying to get it back with clawback. The increases are real. The increases to pensioners are real. Pensioners know that their costs have gone up. They know now that the GST is starting to bite into their quality of life. It is starting to bite into their incomes. The other day a pensioner from Strahan in my electorate rang me and said that the GST compensation of $4 in his normal age pension had made his rent allowance decrease by $8. He was $4 worse off last December. The CPI will increase on 20 March when a supposed increase in the pension should occur. He should get his four per cent, but he will not. His pension will go up by half the CPI increase, so he will now be $10 worse off than he was before any of the increases. When you apply this to the other costs that a person on a fixed income has to put up with, you see that pensioners have had it hard. Under this government, it is getting harder.

We also know from the latest announcement that there are 170,000 low income families and youth allowance recipients who will have an outright cut in their benefits, since the rent assistance cuts will not be offset by the two per cent in their primary benefit. We had the minister, just at the end of his speech—I thought the light had come on; I thought he would not get there—admitting that there would be some adjustments and that some people would miss out. I would like to see the Prime Minister try to live on a real pension—the one that has no superannuation payments attached; I would like to see how he would feel about the cost of petrol, the price of his electricity bill—that is going up now for pensioners as the GST starts to come on—and the cost of going to a doctor and the lack of bulk-billing. Most pensioners pay up front and then wait two or three weeks to get back their rebate. All of these increased costs are impacts, imposts, from the GST. We should ask the other minister, the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, the guy who is getting a bit of a take out of the 70 poker machines, how he would go on a pension. I wonder if he would feel the effect of the GST on his pocket. Another core promise broken is that pensioners would be on 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and nothing would affect that. Well, it has been affected and, of course, the relative cost of living has gone up.

The point that I am sure will not be lost is that this government is penalising pensioners and unemployment recipients—all people who are poor. I think that last year this government breached—gave the cane to—200,000 unemployed people for not attending interviews at Centrelink offices. This government targets people who are on low incomes, people who are at the bottom end of our economic system. While we are looking at what the government is actually doing here and now by clawing back two per cent of four per cent from pensioners, let's look at its overall policies: for education—increasing the education dollar to private schools; and its attitude to family trusts, which means more money for people at the higher end of the system in which we live. So we see that richer people are doing better under this government than pensioners who will have half of that four per cent increase for the cost of living clawed back. They lose two per cent of that increase. Private schools gain and of course family trusts gain. People who can afford to pay more tax, pay less tax. This is a very mean government that we have here.

I am told by some pensioners that every time the postman comes, they worry about the bills: energy bills are starting to come in, and the GST is on them; the rates, the phone, and their health needs—the cost of all these activities is starting to go up. Your quality of life depends on your recreational needs. If you cannot afford to play bowls any more or you cannot afford to go down the road with your friends, that impinges on your quality of life. That is because the GST is ripping a bit out of your fixed income. We always said that it was going to affect people's quality of life, and of course we see that it is. Telephone bills, in particular, differ for pensioners because of the hidden costs in special deals offered by some providers. Non-Telstra carries are apparently applying the GST without stipulating that on the bills. I have been told by one pensioner that the telephone allowance has gone up only 40c, yet the telephone line rental has increased by $5.85. This government really is tough and strong on the poor. They are a bad government, a mean government. I believe they have lost and will continue to lose the support of the Australian people with this clawback of two per cent. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is a government which cares about all Australians, particularly the elderly and pensioners amongst our ranks. It is in fact contrary to what the member for Lilley and the member for Franklin, in their expansive rhetoric, would have us believe this afternoon. Contrary to that rhetoric, it is actually a mark of this government's care for pensioners that this measure was introduced. It reverses the unfair system where pensioners, under the Labor government, were always having to play catch-up with inflation, so far as their pension increases were concerned. Anybody who wishes to understand this debate ought first to understand historically the situation so far as the impact of inflation, or CPI as it is referred to, had on pensions.

speech.para: Historically under the Labor government, when inflation went up, as it did, pensions were always catching up with that increase in inflation six months after it occurred. So if inflation went up by four per cent or five per cent and there was a six-monthly adjustment in the pensions, that adjustment was to take account of the increase in inflation over the previous six months. So pensioners were only ever getting back to an even-keel position after every six months in which the pension was adjusted. That was the system, which persisted under the Labor Party when they occupied the government benches in this parliament. As I said, it is a mark of our care for pensioners and older Australians that we have abolished that system and put in place a system where there is an adjustment made six-monthly in advance to take account of inflation. What compounded the system under the Labor government was that we had a period when the Labor Party was in government when inflation in this country was running at exorbitant levels—far higher than they are today. Not only were pensioners playing catch-up in terms of the CPI and their pensions; they were playing catch-up when the rate of inflation was almost vertical under the Labor Party in government.

What have we done in relation to this? First of all, we are not clawing back any of the CPI adjustment; we are simply reflecting the new system which was put in place—and I will explain that—when the new tax system came into operation. If we had done what the Labor Party seems to be suggesting today, then on 1 July last year, when the new tax system came into operation, we would have increased pensions by two per cent. And then, if your system had operated, we simply would have waited until the next period of adjustment came around, to March of this year, and increased it again. We did not do that. We said to pensioners of Australia—and I will go to where we set this out in the documentation—`We know there is a CPI effect from these changes. Instead of just increasing it by two per cent to take account of that change on 1 July, we will increase it now by four per cent so you are not out of pocket and then we will make the adjustment in March of this year so that it reflects putting it up the full two per cent.' If you go to the tax fact sheet for aged and other pensioners, which was available and which I distributed hundreds, if not thousands, of in my electorate, we said this:

quote.para: The Government will increase the maximum rates of all social security and service pensions by 4 per cent from 1 July 2000.

speech.para: We went on to explain:

quote.para: The 4 per cent increase will consist of an upfront advance of 2 per cent and a real increase of 2 per cent. This will ensure that pensioners will be ahead at least 2 per cent, regardless of the actual `price effect' of the goods and services tax (GST)—that is, how the GST will affect the Consumer Price Index ....

speech.para: What we were saying was that we were not going to simply put this up by two per cent and take a chance that you might be adversely affected by the GST coming into operation. We said we were going to double that and make sure it was up four per cent at the outset so that when the CPI impact had its bearing over the period from 1 July, over the last nine months, those pensioners would not be adversely affected. That is what we did. That was quite clear at the time. Let me refer to the Age Pension News of March-April 2000. This was before this measure came into operation. Page 9 of the Age Pension News of March-April 2000 said:

quote.para: The four per cent increase to your pension or allowance is made up from two amounts:
· a two per cent real increase above the Consumer Price Index (CPI). This part of the increase is above and beyond any other increase that would have been payable to you; and

· a two per cent advance increase in rates to offset the anticipated first-year effect of the GST on the CPI. This advance ensures pensioners and allowees will benefit from the very start of The New Tax System.

The two per cent real increase will be paid on top of the normal indexation arrangements for movements in prices and wages. This means that all pensioners and allowees will always be two per cent better off, regardless of the effect of the GST on prices.
The September 2000 increase to your pension will occur as usual. This compensates for the January to June 2000 price movements.
The March 2001 increase will be adjusted to take into account the 2 per cent advance already provided in July 2000.

speech.para: I repeat that sentence:

quote.para: The March 2001 increase will be adjusted to take account of the 2 per cent advance already provided in July 2000.

speech.para: This is what the Labor Party, the member for Lilley and the member for Franklin are complaining about. If there were any validity in this attack that has been mounted by the Labor Party today, we would have heard in March, April, May and June of last year when there was discussion about the new tax system coming into operation. We would have heard from these members opposite that this was not an appropriate way to deal with this particular measure and that in fact we should just have been increasing the amount by two per cent. But nary a word did we hear then from those opposite. Indeed, as has been pointed out by others in this debate, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the member for Hotham, Mr Crean, put out an information kit, as many of us did, in his electorate in which he said:

quote.para: The real increase in the pension will therefore be two per cent.

speech.para: This man who sits on the benches opposite says to the Australian nation, `I will make a better Treasurer for the Australian nation than the current Treasurer.' This man holds himself up in this place and elsewhere as the person who has the economic, financial and similar credentials to be in charge of the purse strings of this country. Mr Crean, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, said in his information kit, which he put out to his electorate:

quote.para: The real increase in the pension will therefore be two per cent.

speech.para: That statement in itself gives the lie to the proposition being advanced by the Labor Party here this week. The word `opportunism' has been bandied around in relation to what is being proposed by the Labor Party. There is probably no more appropriate word than that in this regard. The increase last year in fact involved two amounts that were paid—in effect $7.45, a real increase, and an advance of $7.45. And the adjustment, as we said, is taking place now.

I said at the outset that this is a government which cares about all Australians—about all people, and particularly about those who are the least fortunate economically and otherwise within our society. It is the very meeting of that objective by this government, the very concern for those people, which led to this mechanism being put in place by the government so that they would not be in any way worse off as a result of these changes. In fact, by indexing pensions to the male total average weekly earnings and providing the compensation to pensioners, we can see that pensions have now risen to $402. If it had been under the Labor system, pensions would have been only $379.39 a fortnight. Quite clearly, in terms of the quantum, the total amount that is being provided to pensioners, there has been a real increase of around $30 since July last year over what would have been provided by the Labor government.

As I said, this is a government which cares about all people—about all Australians, and particularly about pensioners. This is an opportunistic attack by a Labor Party whose only contribution to public policy in Australia at the present time is to find the latest thing to nitpick about, to scare particularly elderly people and pensioners. They ought to be ashamed of this attack. They know it has no substance. If it had substance, they would have said something about it last year. If it had substance, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would be up here saying something different from what he said in his own information kit. This is nothing but an opportunistic attack from a lazy party that has no policies, no program and no proposals of any real value for the people of Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The discussion has concluded.
