talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the first and second reports for 2001 of the committee relating to: Remediation of Defence land at Neutral Bay, Sydney; and Defence Housing Authority responses to recommendations in the 10th report of 2000, development of 90 apartments in Darwin.

speech.para: Ordered that the reports be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—The first report that I have tabled concerns the proposed remediation of Defence land at Neutral Bay, Sydney, New South Wales. The remediation of the Defence land—the site of the former HMAS Platypus—is intended to do two things: first, it will mitigate Commonwealth liability for the contamination of the site; and, secondly, it maximises the revenue to the Commonwealth from the sale of the site. Once remediated, the site is intended for use as a residential development. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $16.5 million. This includes design; site establishment and environmental controls; demolition and excavation; the treatment and removal of contaminated materials; the backfilling and compaction of clean fill; seawall protection works; and management of contaminated groundwater. The estimated cost includes a construction contingency and a price indexation adjustment over the proposed remediation period. The committee has recommended that the proposed remediation proceed.

speech.para: The conclusions of the committee were, first, that the contamination on the site is causing ongoing pollution to the Neutral Bay area and the surrounding environment; secondly, that remediation of the site may mitigate the Commonwealth's liability for the contamination of the site; and, thirdly, that the proposed work represents value for money and has potential to maximise the revenue return to the Commonwealth from the future sale.

The committee acknowledges that nearby residents have concerns about the remediation. However, it believes two factors will minimise the impact of the proposed remediation on the amenity of the local area. They are: conditions imposed by the Land and Environment Court of New South Wales; and actions proposed to be taken by the contractor over the time required to remediate the site.

The issue of most concern to all stakeholders is that of ground contamination. This is the legacy of the gasworks constructed in the late 1800s. The committee found that the site is subject to contamination flowing from the ground beneath an adjacent residential property and that, under the remediation proposal, the Commonwealth would meet the cost of a contamination management system. In the committee's opinion, responsibility for drainage from the adjacent site is the responsibility of the New South Wales government, both now and in the future. The committee is firmly of the view that the Commonwealth should be exempted from any future legal liability of the site, over which it does not have ownership but which in fact may continue to affect the Commonwealth site.

Accordingly, the committee has made two recommendations. First, it recommends that the Minister for Defence write to the New South Wales Environment Protection Authority requesting that the authority consider issuing an investigation under part 3 of the New South Wales Contaminated Land Management Act 1997 in respect of the adjacent land; and, secondly, it recommends that the Department of Defence investigate the possibility of being compensated for (1) any damage caused by the mitigation onto the former HMAS Platypus site by off-site contaminants and (2) costs associated with remediation and installation of a management system for such contaminants.

In all its inquiries, the committee gives specific attention to heritage and environmental issues. They must have priority in any proposed work submitted for consideration. They can never be just an afterthought. The committee believes that, where practicable, features of cultural and historical significance attached to public works should be preserved and bequeathed to future generations. From time to time, the committee has faced challenges in determining how others assess some features to be significant—either culturally or historically. In the case of the remediation at Neutral Bay, the committee had to assess how some of the community had come to see retaining walls, remnant pipes, traces of tar and other chemicals and a cliff profile as being in need of preservation. The committee expects that Defence will photograph and carefully document features of heritage and historical value that have been identified. This should be done in consultation with the Australian Heritage Commission and the Australian National Archives. With respect to the heritage value of the cliff at the rear of the site, the committee is of the opinion that a satisfactory solution would be to re-create a straight vertical face at the back of the site when excavations are completed. Then the cliff will continue to appear as it currently does—that is, a single excavation along the waterfront.

In conclusion, I thank the Department of Defence and, in particular, Mr Bernard Blackley and Mr Matthew Beggs for their assistance during the inquiry. The information provided to the committee by the department included an independent audit of the works costs and an independent legal opinion as to the Commonwealth's future liability with respect to the site. This information greatly assisted the committee and it set a benchmark which other agencies would do well to follow.

Before commenting on the second report that I have tabled, I would like to briefly pay tribute to the work of Ian Ireland in the Parliamentary Library. Ian was seconded to the committee's secretariat last year, and since then he has demonstrated an impressive affinity with the role and work of the committee. We will miss his attention to detail and his good nature on the committee. In large measure, the final responsibility to draft the report that I have just tabled rested with Ian, and I commend the report to the House.

The second report that I have tabled is a sequel to the committee's 10th report of 2000. It is unusual for the committee to report in such a fashion, and so I will provide some brief background information. The committee's 10th report of 2000 was tabled on 11 October. It presented findings and recommendations in relation to a proposal to develop three residential apartment towers in Darwin. The proposal was presented by the Defence Housing Authority, or DHA as it is more commonly known. Under the heading of `General comments', the committee concluded its 10th report by stating:

quote.para: After months of investigation the Committee still has serious concerns about aspects of the proposal ... The Committee believes DHA must do more work before the Parliament can endorse the proposal.
The Committee concludes that the development of apartment towers in Carey Street, Darwin by the Defence Housing Authority should not proceed until all the Committee's recommendations have been met.
The Committee recommends that the Defence Housing Authority report to the Committee when it has complied with all the recommendations contained in this report.

speech.para: In accordance with the last recommendation, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence wrote to the committee on 8 November 2000 providing the committee with the response to its recommendation. The committee considered the response, advising the minister that it had: agreed to DHA proceeding with the issue and the evaluation of tenders and obtaining an updated market appraisal; accepted a response to recommendation 6 concerning a cost-benefit analysis of the Defence rental assistance program; and resolved that the construction of the proposed work not proceed until the committee's recommendations, with the exception of recommendation 6, had been met. The committee also advised DHA that it required a more detailed response than that initially provided.

The report I have tabled today presents the committee's findings and conclusions in relation to material provided after the tabling of the 10th report of 2000 and, in particular, a detailed response and accompanying reports provided by DHA on 1 February 2001. The committee has found DHA willing to comply with all of its recommendations. Its willingness to comply with the committee's recommendations has been evident in the provision of the detailed response and the commissioning of various technical reports. This willingness was also evident in a recent meeting between all members of the DHA board of directors, led by the chairman of the board, Mr Peter Jollie, and members of the committee.

The committee recognises that there are challenges for a Commonwealth agency, such as DHA, which is charged with operating in a commercial environment while remaining accountable to the parliament. The committee is firmly of the view that, while at times it may be difficult to achieve a balance between commercial imperatives and accountability to the parliament, it is not impossible to do so and that the processes must be adhered to.

Since tabling its 10th report of 2000, the committee has reviewed DHA's proposal for apartment towers at Carey Street in Darwin. At this time the committee has some reluctance in approving the proposed work. This reluctance is linked to the need for the work and the operation of the rental assistance program.

The committee states in its report that, following approval by the committee, the DHA board of directors will proceed to consider whether the work will go ahead. Because of the way DHA is established, the board of directors will accept responsibility for the success or otherwise of the work. The committee concludes that the parliament should not delay the board from its final consideration of the proposal. I commend the report to the House.

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Mr Reith:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr Bevis moved by way of amendment:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for:
(1) increased job security for all Australian workers;
(2) protection for workers from harsh, unfair or unreasonable dismissal, regardless of the size of the business;
(3) ready access for all workers to an affordable and fair industrial umpire to deal with unfair, unreasonable or harsh dismissal; and

(4) repeal of paragraph 170CC(1)(a) of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to give workers engaged under a contract of employment for a specified period of time or a specified task protection from unfair, unreasonable or harsh dismissal”.

talk.start.para: —The debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Unfair Dismissals) Bill 1998 [No. 2] was interrupted last night, and I want to briefly recap my argument. I took a considerable interest in this bill because, when I was shadow minister for small business, we made this issue one of the central planks of our small business platform in the lead-up to the 1996 election. In fact, I mentioned in the House last night that I debated the issue of unfair dismissal in the Newcastle markets from the back of a truck with the then Labor government minister Senator Schacht. That led to considerable public debate on the issue and considerable media coverage, to the point where the then Labor Prime Minister promised to review the unfair dismissal provision because it was evident that it was causing great difficulties within the small business community.

speech.para: As I said last night—and I will repeat it—I think all of us in this House believe in a fair system, one that treats workers fairly and treats employers fairly. If employers cannot go about the business that they are engaged in and if they are caught up in long legal battles about unfair dismissal because of the way the provision currently works, despite our attempts to amend it, then their opportunity to grow their businesses and to employ more people is impeded. I went through a number of reports last night that contained ample evidence that this particular measure—introduced by Labor originally—is still causing enormous difficulties within the small business community.

This bill essentially proposes amendments to the current bill, and the amendments generally exempt small businesses with 15 or fewer employees from federal unfair dismissal laws and provide that only employees other than apprentices and designated trainees who have been continuously engaged by the same employer for at least six months may access federal unfair dismissal remedies.

This bill does not affect the scope of state unfair dismissal laws or the federal laws dealing with unlawful dismissal. There are plenty of provisions in place to ensure that workers are protected in the workplace. On eight occasions this bill has been voted down by Labor in one form or another. On five occasions it has been voted down by the Australian Democrats in the Senate. I suggest that this action will continue to impede the growth, development and health of our small businesses. There are protections in place to look after the interests of employees, but if small business people—and I am talking about the small family businesses of Australia which form the backbone of our business community—continue to be impeded in the operation of their businesses in the way they are by these measures, it would certainly put a dampener on our economic growth and employment opportunities. No-one is served by not having the dignity of work and being disadvantaged because they do not take home a regular pay packet. I suggest it is very important that we give consideration to these amendments and that we get them passed in the interests of small business and in the interests of future employment in Australia.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in this debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Unfair Dismissals) Bill 1998 [No. 2].I would like to start by analysing the rhetoric that this government spouts in relation to industrial relations as compared with the reality and to make some comments about the clear divergence between the two. I would then like to come to the details of this bill. First of all, let us have a look at the government's rhetoric. As we all know, day after day the current Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and his predecessor spend question time railing against unionism. I notice that the minister is joining us for this debate; he is very welcome. The minister is often ably assisted in these endeavours by the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, who seems unable to answer a question without railing against teacher unions. If we want any proof of that proposition, we just have to cast our minds back to question time today where the minister again railed against a teacher union, on this occasion the Queensland Teachers Union.

speech.para: Anti-union rhetoric is the cornerstone of the government's industrial relations policy. Its justification for industrial relations changes is often predicated on the need to control what it sees as big and powerful unions. The imagery that this government constantly seeks to draw to justify its industrial relations stance is of big unions holding employers and the country to ransom. That is the rhetoric, that is the fairytale, that is the imagery that this government tries to draw, but behind that picture there is a more disturbing reality which is that, properly viewed, this government's industrial relations reform is not about containing the industrially strong; it is about laying open to further exploitation the industrially weak. This government came to office with a vision for industrial relations, a vision of ensuring that the law only protected a minimum number of allowable matters, a minimum number of issues for workers, and beyond that workers would have to bargain. The vision then ran on to the creation of an industrial relations system where the industrially weak workers, the price takers in the system, would be in a position of having to sign up to Australian workplace agreements which, of course, were designed by their employer and met their employer's needs.

Lest there be any doubt about this, let us recall that the greatest uptake rate of Australian workplace agreements was in the Victorian public sector under the Kennett government. Everybody knows that those agreements were in absolutely standard form, designed by the Kennett government as the employer. The only thing that varied from agreement to agreement was in the name slot: one would say `Julia Gillard' and another one would say `Tony Abbott'. In those circumstances, we know crystal clear that this was never about workers bargaining with some sort of market power for individually determined outcomes for things that might have suited their own employment position. This was about an employer saying, `Here, take this.' That was the vision that this government had for industrial relations—industrially weak workers being put in a position where the employer said, `Here's your agreement: take it and sign it.' This is a vision of an atomised industrial relations system where every worker is doing the best they can for themselves but they really are not able to do very much, unless of course they happen to be in a premium market position because of a skills shortage or the like.

To concrete this vision of individualised industrial relations into place, the government had to design a system which would fracture unionism in those sections of the work force which were unionised. So the government designed a collective bargaining system which, subject to certain procedural requirements being met, makes it lawful for unions to take industrial action and lawful for employers to use sanctions such as lockouts against workers. The government had in mind two outcomes when it designed this system. First, it hoped that hardline employers would use tactics like lockouts to break workers and their unions, and to some extent that has occurred but I suspect nowhere near as widely as the government would have liked. Secondly, the government was hoping that workers would move away from traditional union structures and engage in non-union bargaining or bargaining through newly created enterprise based employee associations. Indeed, much of the Workplace Relations Act is given over to creating these new bargaining entities in this non-union bargaining stream. That was the government's expectation—that workers would be weakened in their capacity to industrially organise because they would move into such structures.

We would have to say that that part of the vision—the creation of weakened enterprise unions, moving away from traditional union structures to some sort of weakened form or organisation—has been a spectacular failure. So the government now presides over a two-track industrial relations system: one in which workers outside the unionised sector of the work force who attempt to bargain without market power are basically left to the mercy of their employer, unprotected, and of course the other track where unionised workers who are collectively bargaining, in some circumstances, manage to strike very good bargains indeed and their industrial tactics are made lawful by the government's own legislation.

We all know the fact that some unions have managed to collectively bargain effectively under this industrial relations system has been seen by the government as a complete affront and the government have responded by coming into this House with pieces of legislation like the pattern bargaining bill in an endeavour to force these unions to bargain with one hand tied behind their backs. Fortunately, commonsense prevailed and this parliament has not sanctioned these new attacks. Let us have a look once again at the rhetoric versus the reality. The rhetoric of this government was, `We're tough and we're going to bring unions under control,' whereas the reality is that they have just assaulted the weakest. In characterising the government's position in this way, I am not saying that the government have not engaged in actions which are fundamentally anti-union. We know that they have, with the waterfront dispute being perhaps the most spectacular single example. But I am also trying to point to the dishonesty which is at the centre of the government's industrial relations approach. They did not go out at the last election and say, `We will do all we can to hurt the industrially weak,' but that is what they have done.

I note that when they get a message back from the industrially weak that they are not happy with current work force conditions—and one of those messages was delivered through the ACTU survey which gained some media coverage today and was dealt with by the minister during question time—rather than listen to the message they attack the messenger. We should note that there is considerable pain out there in the community, and we need really do no more than go to the ABS figures that are being used in the living wage case which deal with the 800,000 lowest paid working households. The figures show a startlingly bad picture, and I would have thought that the minister would be exhibiting some concern about statistics like this: 30,000 of those households went without meals, 30,000 could not afford heating, 41,000 sold or pawned things, 284,800 had no holiday, 115,000 had second-hand clothes and 22,000 had sought help from welfare or community groups. When you are presiding over an industrial relations system which gives you outcomes like that, I do not think you can really deny that the effect of the system has been to jeopardise the working conditions of the industrially weak.

I now turn to the details of this bill. When you analyse this bill properly, it is a further assault on the working conditions of the industrially weak. This bill would prevent employees who work in a business that employs no more than 15 persons from having access to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act. There is no provision in this bill preventing employers incorporating companies and transferring the employment of employees to those companies in order to keep the number employed by any one company at 15 or less. Lest it be viewed as fanciful that anyone would go to the trouble of doing that, I point out that, in a former occupation—two occupations ago now—as a partner of a law firm that regularly worked on behalf of workers in the clothing trades industry, I had workers come to me who had been employed in the same factory at the same machine for more than 15 years and when you looked through their group certificates there was a different company listed as the employer in every group certificate. That had been deliberately done to try to avoid obligations like long service leave. When people will go to that kind of trouble to avoid the potential of having a long service leave claim, one wonders what kind of trouble they will go to to try to bring their numbers to 15 or less and make sure they are not caught by the unfair dismissal provisions. Anybody who is getting quality industrial relations advice would have had that risk raised with them, and the least they could have done was to try to deal with it in this bill. But that has not been done.

This bill also introduces a requirement that an employee cannot access the unfair dismissal provisions of the legislation unless they have been engaged by their employer for a period of at least six months. Let us have a look at this bill. Who is it going to affect? Predominantly, people who work in small businesses are the non-unionised sector of the work force. Predominantly, people who work in small businesses are the industrially weak. They are the price takers, and they are the people who are going to be left without a remedy. However the government wants to dress this bill up, the reality is that this bill will enable small businesses to dismiss employees unfairly and allow employers to be able to dismiss new employees unfairly. This bill is about taking fairness out of the equation and giving small business employers in particular more power. I think this was revealingly put by the member for Curtin in her contribution to this debate when she said in relation to this bill:

quote.para: It is a reaction to the cold, hard fact that the cost of labour is an integral factor in the demand for labour, which is hardly, I would have thought, a disputable proposition. Things fall down, not up. The sun rises in the east and sets in the west—

speech.para: She might well have added that the sun rises on a Court government and sets on a Geoff Gallop one.

talk.start.para: —The other way round.
—I thank the minister for the clarification, because the sun has well and truly set on the Court government and on the member for Curtin's aspirations to be Premier. She goes on:

quote.para: ... and price is a factor in determining demand. The price of labour is not merely the level of wages or other remuneration; the cost of labour to employers is the aggregation of all relevant costs—wages, remuneration, taxation, regulation and risk as well as the initial set-up costs associated with employment. By inflating the cost of labour, unfair dismissal laws drive down demand for employment among small businesses. The obvious consequence is unemployment.

speech.para: There we have it: the coalition philosophy of industrial relations laid bare. In breach of the historic tradition of fairness that has characterised the Australian industrial relations system, where the price of labour to an employer is also recognised as the wage of a worker used to support the worker and his or her family, we have the coalition philosophy of industrial relations where wages and on-costs are no more than a cost to business and workers can be left without protection to enable that cost of business to fall until hopefully the market for labour clears. With that kind of philosophy, there is no floor below which you will not go, and this bill is an example of that kind of philosophy in action.

Let us deal with some of the spurious claims that have been made in the government's attempt to defend this bill in this debate. One of those spurious claims has been that this bill does not matter because employees have legal rights in relation to unlawful, as opposed to unfair, dismissals. Now that is true, but we know that unlawful dismissal is confined to a number of very specific grounds, including if you are dismissed for discriminatory reasons such as sexual preference, age, union membership, family responsibilities or if you are dismissed because you are engaged in protected—that is, lawful—industrial action. But outside that very limited class this bill sanctions unfair dismissals by small business or unfair dismissal of newly engaged employees.

I will raise with you a real-life example I came across when I worked at Slater and Gordon, and I will be very interested in the minister's response to this when he rises in relation to this bill. I acted, when I was at Slater and Gordon, for a man who worked in a bus depot. It was a small bus depot and I have no doubt the employer would have employed fewer than 15 people. The employer had a large and, as it turned out, vicious dog that roamed around the bus depot—if the minister is doubting the veracity of this, I can have produced to him out of archives the file with the relevant identifying features deleted—and bit the worker. The worker went to the employer and complained about being bitten by the dog and asked if the employer would restrain the dog. The employer's response was to dismiss the worker rather than restrain the dog.

That might sound humorous but there we have a worker with no job, a bleeding wound and, under this government's legislation—this very bill—no remedy. That worker was not dismissed for sexual preference or because he was engaged in lawful industrial action or any of those things. He was dismissed because he complained about being bitten by a dog. I do not know what the minister is going to tell us should be done in those circumstances; but, if the minister thinks this bill is fair legislation, he has to be arguing it would be a fair outcome for that worker to be left without a remedy. I would find it very interesting indeed to see if the minister is capable of making out that argument, media training and question time training included!

Can we look at the horizontal inequity here. If the worker bitten by the dog worked down the road at a bigger bus depot where there were 20 employees, he would have a remedy. How can that be right? If the employer had marched out and said to him, `I think you are a homosexual; you're dismissed,' he would have had a remedy. But, bitten by a dog, he does not have a remedy. Let us have a look at the horizontal fairness. How can we say, looking at those circumstances, that all of them—the bitten worker in the bigger business, the person dismissed for sexual preference and this worker—should not have remedies? Of course, all of them should have remedies, yet this government, picking and choosing in a completely ridiculous way, is leaving a bundle of workers—what is likely to be the most industrially weak section of the work force—without a remedy.

The second spurious claim that has been used to justify this bill is that it will create 50,000 more jobs in the small business sector. It is one of those things that, if you say it often enough—if the former minister for industrial relations says it, and then the Prime Minister says it, and then the former minister for industrial relations says it again, and then the new minister says it—you will somehow convince each other it is true. But you have to go back and say, `Where does this figure come from?' It might have been exchanged around the Liberal Party room so many times that they all believe it to be true. But where does it actually come from? It comes from an assertion made by the Small Business Council, and no evidence was ever produced to ground that assertion.

When you look at the evidence that exists on this issue—and of course the best evidence, we think, comes from the Australian Workplace Industrial Relations Survey 1995—there is no way in which a claim of 50,000 new jobs can be sustained. In fact, when you analyse that survey, as our Labor senators in another place remarked when they issued their minority report dealing with this bill, you find that only 0.9 per cent of respondents nominated that they had not recruited employees due to unfair dismissal legislation. So there is spurious claim No. 2 absolutely gone.

Spurious claim No. 3 is that you need a period of time to assess whether a new employee is going to fit into a job and that consequently you need this legislation. That is undoubtedly right: you do need a period of time to assess a new employee; but provision is currently made for that by the proper use of probation periods. That is the way that it has always been done on hiring. There is nothing wrong with that mechanism. Any employer with a sensible industrial relations strategy or human resources strategy does that—they review, counsel and look at new people as they are bedding into a job—and really no argument has been advanced to suggest that the bill is justified in that sense. Once again, this claim is without foundation.

If it is going to create the kind of unfairness we know it is going to create; if it is going to impose that unfairness on the industrially weak, by and large; if there is no foundation for the job claims that are made in relation to this bill and no foundation for the claims made that it is necessary to deal with new employees, what are we all doing here? I think we know what we are all doing here: we are continuing down a relatively mindless and repetitious industrial relations agenda that was set by the former minister. The new minister has an opportunity—perhaps a historic opportunity—to break with that agenda. I think if he looks at this legislation—I will be very interested in his response on the worker and the dog—on its merits, as opposed to what they have all convinced themselves about while sitting around the Liberal Party party room, he will see this bill is absolutely unjustified and should be rejected again.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr ABBOTT
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —This Workplace Relations Amendment (Unfair Dismissals) Bill 1998 [No. 2] is the first bill that I have had the chance to deal with in the House in my current capacity. Let me take this opportunity to say that I am determined to be a minister for employees and not just employers. I am proud of the fact that under this government the wages of ordinary workers have significantly increased. In fact, basic award earnings under this government have gone up by nine per cent in real terms. Under the former government they actually fell by five per cent. I am not against unions, but I am against union privilege. I spent enough time as a student and as a younger man amongst the disciples of the late, great B. A. Santamaria to have a proper appreciation of the historical role that unions have played in civilising capitalism and in trying to establish the dignity of work. Unfortunately, under the system as it has developed in this country, unions are given a position of legal privilege which is not justified by any of the real evils that they might possibly counteract.

speech.para: The fundamental approach that I bring, and that the government brings, to this whole question of workplace relations is that the players in this drama are essentially decent people who can be trusted most of the time to do the right thing. We do not believe that the average Australian worker and the average Australian manager these days are people who need their hands constantly held by unions, commissions, employer organisations or courts. We believe that they are capable of managing their affairs by themselves in their workplace.

Much of the debate over this legislation has been very general. From members opposite we have had a lot of general attacks on the government. Let me focus for a moment on the bill. This bill essentially does two things: first of all, it exempts new employees of small businesses from the unfair dismissal laws and, secondly, it provides for all new employees of any business to have a six-month probationary period during which the unfair dismissal laws do not operate. As members opposite have pointed out, this is by no means the first time this bill has come before the parliament. Bills of this type came before the last parliament twice. This bill has come before the parliament once before. This is the second time that the bill has been debated in this House in this term of parliament. The government's determination, again and again, to see this bill come in is a sign of its seriousness about trying to protect small business and business generally. The opposition's determination to reject it is a sign of its concern to protect rights as it sees them, no matter how much damage those rights might do.

It seems to me that small business, in particular, is nothing like the ideological battleground that so many members opposite seem to think it is. Small business is much more like a family than an ideological battleground. It is not appropriate to inject into small business situations the kind of legalism which may be appropriate under some circumstances in different contexts. As a result of the operation of the unfair dismissal laws introduced by the former government and modified in part by this government, an employer who wants to dismiss an employee generally has to provide two warning letters. There has been a bureaucratisation, if you like, a legalisation of this process in ways which are not appropriate for small business in particular—sending warning letters to the staff of small businesses is a little like sending a lawyer's letter to your spouse. It certainly signals a very serious downturn in any relationship—the sort of downturn from which it is very difficult to recover. Unfortunately, under the unfair dismissal laws as they have developed in this country, small businesses are now accustomed to have to pay what they crudely describe as `piss off money' if they want to dismiss people. They are accustomed to pay not only this money but also large legal fees to get rid of people. It has become a large and significant impost on small business, and it is an impost that the government does not believe they should face.

The member for Lalor raised an example from her own previous life. I take her example seriously. Obviously, I think it is most unfortunate that a worker in the situation she described should have been dismissed. I do not say that all employers are perfect, just as I am sure that she would not say that all employees are perfect. I do not say that doing what this government would like done is going to produce a perfect world. I do not suggest that, if this bill were passed, there would never be any injustice or wrong in the world. I do not suggest that for a second. What I do say, though, is that the unfair dismissal laws as they stand are worse than the problem they have been designed to fix. I believe that the unfair dismissal legislation is a cure that is worse than the disease. The truth is that, if small business cannot fire people, it feels that it cannot hire people, and it is the government's position that, if we freed small business from the restrictions of the law as it currently stands, the extra employment that this would generate would far outweigh any occasional instances where employees feel they have been hard done by.

It has been said by members opposite that the government should not single out small business for particular exemption from these laws. I should point out to the House that, in Germany, unfair dismissal laws do not apply to firms employing fewer than five employees. In Italy, more informal unfair dismissal provisions apply in the case of companies employing fewer than 15 staff. There are other legislative precedents for treating small business differently. In 1982, for instance, the New South Wales Labor government introduced an employment protection act which had an exclusion for employers with fewer than 15 employees. In 1986 the former Hawke Labor government introduced an affirmative action bill which excluded from its operation employers with fewer than 100 employees. In his second reading speech, the then Prime Minister acknowledged that small business did not have the capacity to undertake the sort of legalistic processes that large businesses manage all the time.

It has been said by members opposite that in fact it is not a big issue, that small business is not really concerned about the unfair dismissal laws as they stand. The Morgan and Banks 1996 survey indicated that 16 per cent of small businesses have been adversely affected in their hiring intentions by federal unfair dismissal laws.

talk.start.para: —What did they have to say about the GST? What did they have to say about that?

—We will come to that. In April 1997 there was a Recruitment Solutions survey which indicated that 32 per cent of businesses in metropolitan Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane had been the subject of some sort of unfair dismissal claim in the 12 months covered by that survey. In May 1997 there was a New South Wales Chamber of Commerce survey which reported that 56 per cent of businesses said the prospect of unfair dismissal claims had discouraged them from recruiting staff. A report by the National Institute of Labour Studies in May 1997 found that unfair dismissal laws strongly influenced hiring decisions. The Yellow Pages small business survey in 1997, covering 1,200 randomly selected proprietors of small businesses, showed that 79 per cent of those proprietors thought small business would be better off if exempted from these laws. Thirty-three per cent of those same small business proprietors reported that they would have been more likely to recruit new employees if exempted from the unfair dismissal laws. In March 1998 the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce revealed that 85 per cent of small businesses nominated unfair dismissals as a key issue for businesses with 15 or fewer employees. In July 1998 the South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry revealed that 52 per cent of respondents who had been subject to unfair dismissal claims had not hired replacement employees. Seventy-seven per cent of respondents with fewer than 15 employees indicated that they would hire more if exempted from unfair dismissal laws.

speech.para: The member for Brisbane asked about GST. It is interesting that the same small business survey which has been recently used by the Victorian government to attack the federal government over GST and other issues—the Sweeney survey—said that 39 per cent of small businesses say that unfair dismissal laws affect their business.

talk.start.para: How many in the same survey say it was the GST? It was the last in 11 options.
—We are debating unfair dismissal at the moment. You cannot be selective about these things.
—You can't, so tell me.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Brisbane should not get too excited.

—Let me say that 39 per cent of small businesses, even on the Victorian Labor government's own survey, said that unfair dismissal laws affect their businesses. Of course, we have solved that problem with the changes to the business activity statement. Even Bob Carr, in 1996, said publicly that the unfair dismissal laws were damaging employment and causing small business not to employ as many people as it otherwise would. I will move briefly to the second element of this bill; that is, the six-month probationary period for all new employees.

speech.para: There is nothing unusual, nothing draconian, nothing out of the ordinary, about what is proposed. In the UK, for instance, one year's continuous service is normally required before you can make an unfair dismissal claim. In Canada, employees in the federal jurisdiction must have been continuously employed for at least one year before accessing an unjust dismissal remedy. In Germany, an employee must have been employed for at least six months before they can gain access to an unfair dismissal remedy. So what we are proposing is in fact less rigorous than the situation which obtains in Blair's Labour Britain, so there is nothing harsh, nothing draconian, nothing out of the ordinary, in this particular bill.

We have had members opposite, in various debates over the last few weeks, constantly talking about the need to create better conditions for small business. We have had members opposite crying crocodile tears over high petrol prices and the paperwork involved in the business activity statement. If members opposite were serious about helping small business, they would talk to the government about this issue. They would be prepared to sit down and talk to us about the kind of protection that small business needs from frivolous and vexatious unfair dismissal claims. They would be prepared to talk to us about establishing a more reasonable probationary period for new employees. They are not. Unfortunately, all that members opposite have done, at least in the course of this debate, has been to make general attacks on government policy, to attack this government as being somehow against workers. We are not. We are determined to do the right thing by workers, because workers in Australia are our constituents as well as the constituents of members opposite. We want to do the right thing by them, and we believe that we have given the workers of this country a good deal.
Question put:

motion.para: That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Bevis's amendment) stand part of the question.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Abbott) read a third time.

debateinfo.title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (NEW ZEALAND CITIZENS) BILL 2001

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 28 February, on motion by Mr Anthony:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (New Zealand Citizens) Bill 2001 before us today follows on from discussions of late between the Australian and New Zealand governments focusing on reciprocal social security arrangements between our two countries. This has been an issue that has been subject to ongoing discussions for many years under governments past and present. The broad agreement that has been struck reorientates the onus for providing social security entitlements to New Zealand citizens in Australia. At first glance the proposal seems fair and achieves the stated aims of both countries. In particular, the opposition wishes to acknowledge the efforts of the New Zealand Labor Prime Minister, Helen Clark, who has on the face of it made the greatest compromise in relation to the new agreement. It is a compromise that the former conservative government in New Zealand was unable to make. The opposition commends the tough stand taken by the New Zealand Prime Minister. It was Helen Clark's determination to stop the population drain that more than anything has meant there is finally a resolution to this matter.

speech.para: Before getting into the detail of this legislation, I believe it is appropriate to acknowledge the contribution made by migrants from New Zealand to the fabric of Australian communities over the years. Despite our great sporting rivalries and good-natured digs at each other on occasion, Australia and New Zealand share a great deal in common not just because of our proximity to each other but also because of the partnerships we have had during adversity, most notably doing the two world wars. It is because of this that the opposition believes that we have to be careful to ensure that the management of this new agreement is handled with sensitivity so as not to create any ill feeling with our neighbours. The opposition also believes that it is appropriate to monitor the new agreement to ensure people are treated fairly.

Moving on to the specifics of the bill, it changes the definition of `Australian resident' for the purposes of social security law, so that access to social security payments for New Zealand citizens taking up residence in Australia is restricted unless they either meet normal migration selection criteria or are covered by a social security international agreement. The new agreement that is coming into force expands upon the two-year waiting period that was introduced last year. There will now be a requirement that all new New Zealanders arriving in Australia will have to successfully apply for residency before the two-year waiting period will take effect and social security payments can then eventually be paid. This brings New Zealand migrants into line with migrants from other countries.

However, the bill makes sure that the changes will not operate to restrict access to child related payments under the social security or family assistance laws—for example, family tax benefits or concession cards and related concessional pharmaceutical benefits. Also, New Zealanders who are already in Australia accessing social security benefits will not be affected. Specifically, the changes made by the bill will not apply to New Zealand citizens who are in Australia on 26 February 2001 or New Zealand citizens who have been in Australia for a period, or periods, of 12 months in the previous two years immediately before 26 February 2001. Added to this there is a general three-month period of grace from the announcement of the changes on 26 February 2001; a six-month period of grace will apply to those New Zealand citizens resident in Australia but temporarily absent who are in receipt of a portable social security payment—for example, the age pension; and a longer 12-month period of grace will apply to those New Zealand citizens resident in Australia but temporarily absent who are unable to return to Australia in the three-month period.

While the opposition has not had a great deal of time to scrutinise every element of this new agreement, we are at this stage satisfied the new agreement will operate fairly and in accordance with community expectations. Although, I must say, given the way that this was put into the House only last Thursday and it is now being debated today, I do not think that that is an entirely satisfactory way to consult the opposition to ensure agreement. The opposition notes that there has been some speculation of significant savings being generated from the new agreement resulting from longer waiting periods and, presumably, fewer New Zealanders making the decision to come to Australia. Figures that have been mentioned are in the vicinity of $100 million per year. Ordinarily these savings would be channelled into consolidated revenue. On this occasion the opposition believes that these savings could well be earmarked for assisting unemployed Australians back into work—to build and to invest in some of those capacity building programs that the McClure report talked about. So we call on the government to seriously consider this, particularly given what we heard in question time yesterday when the Treasurer, Mr Costello, walked away from Minister Newman's very public assurances that the Howard government would restore up to $1 billion of the $5 billion that the Howard government has taken out of welfare since coming to office. When questioned about the government's commitment to welfare reform, Mr Costello warned:

quote.para: Both the Prime Minister and I have made the point that having cut taxes means that, coming into this budget round, the government will have to take a tight rein on expenditure and will have to target measures accordingly ... As I recall, the government has never put a sum, any sum at all, on the amount of the reforms in relation to welfare.

speech.para: I think this contrasts starkly with Senator Newman's promise of 14 December last year that welfare reform would be the highest priority in this year's federal budget, and unambiguous leaks since before December last year—

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order. I hesitate to interrupt my colleague, Mr Deputy Speaker, but this bill is a narrowly cast bill. It is a family and community service legislation amendment bill relating to New Zealand citizens, and that is the extent of it. It relates to New Zealand citizens living in Australia and Australian citizens living in New Zealand. It has nothing to do with Mr Costello, Jocelyn Newman or anybody else.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—I uphold the point of order. It is a very narrowly cast bill. The member for Lilley should stick strictly to the terms of the bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, this bill forecasts savings to the Family and Community Services budget. We are currently having a discussion nationally about the need to invest in welfare reform. What I have just said is that the government should seriously consider the very considerable projected savings flowing from this bill, which the government itself has talked about and which the Prime Minister, when he was in New Zealand, talked about. The government should consider reinvesting these savings in capacity building programs that come within the ambit of the Department of Family and Community Services. This is not a bill which is being put forward by the minister for immigration. It is being put forward by the Minister for Family and Community Services. It is integral to the expenditure of that department. With due respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not think that I am moving outside the confines of this bill, when the government has publicly talked about savings. I am simply asking: how much are they; where are they going; have they been put into the forward estimates; is the government going to put them back into consolidated revenue; what is happening to them?

speech.para: I think it is entirely legitimate to raise these savings in the context of the McClure report and in the context of the answer given in this House yesterday by the Treasurer when he was asked by the Leader of the Opposition whether welfare reform was still the highest priority of the government, whether it still intended to invest these savings. The Sydney Morning Herald reported last year that the cabinet submission estimated the cost at about $800 million net over several years and $1 billion gross. The Minister for Family and Community Services at the time was running around the country beating her drum prior to her resignation from the ministry saying that she had it on the highest authority, from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, that welfare reform was going to be the top priority in this year's budget. Here we have a bill in which the government says there are considerable savings and I am drawing the linkage within the context of the budget of that department, in the context of this bill, to the government's stated agenda and so-called commitment to welfare reform as embodied in the McClure report. Indeed, I think the Prime Minister has drawn that linkage himself. On the 7.30 Report on 14 December last year he said:

quote.para: We will be making additional money available in next year's Budget. We're not going to cherry-pick.

speech.para: I am asking what is happening to the additional moneys that are coming from this bill within the Department of Family and Community Services, which has a $50 billion budget a year. The government has been claiming that welfare reform is its top priority and that it is going to invest up to $1 billion in that reform because it recognised some validity in the approach that was outlined in the McClure report. The McClure report is integral to all of the operations of the Department of Family and Community Services. It is a statement that Labor has also largely endorsed because it points in the direction to which, we believe, welfare reform must always point—that is, helping people to move from welfare to work. It goes to the very heart of this bill. This bill is at the very heart of that whole debate.

The government has said that it will make an investment. It has finally acknowledged that its short-sighted cuts, and indeed cuts which have cost us a lot more in the long-term, were wrong. It has talked about the need for an injection of funds and about some of the measures in the McClure report as being positive. The McClure report has pointed to many of the things that we have suggested which are positive, such as recognition of tax credits, work bonuses, participation supplements and better case management. These are all ideas that can make a difference, that can help people move from welfare to work. The ideas in the McClure report are good but they require cash. They require money, they require government support, they require backup.

What disturbed me was the answer by the Treasurer in this House yesterday. It seemed to me that he was torpedoing the commitment that the former Minister for Family and Community Services thought she had from both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. The McClure report will be absolutely meaningless unless the Department of Family and Community Services backs its recommendations with some substantial investments in the future. My concern with that report also was its loose use of the expression `mutual obligation', which left the door wide open for the government to target some of our community's most vulnerable. We all know that the government has been determined to force changes on single parents and disability support pensioners. Given that we expect the government to breach up to one and two job seekers over the coming year, and we have had the Minister for Community Services talking about that today, no-one can expect that it will implement the report with the good heart that is needed to make it genuinely work.

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order and it goes to drawing the member back to the bill. I have been patient, Mr Deputy Speaker. The member has talked about savings, but he is now talking about nothing else but the McClure report. If he wants to deal with the McClure report he ought to move an amendment that takes account of the McClure report and its relationship to this bill. This bill stands as it is. There is no mention of the McClure report in the explanatory memorandum or anything else connected with the bill.
—I uphold the point of order. There is nothing in the bill that talks about the McClure report. The member for Lilley has to stick strictly to the bill before the House.
—Yes, but this bill is an essential part of the government's—
—There will be no debate. The member should know the standing orders.

—I was not disagreeing with you. This bill is an integral part of the whole approach the government is taking to social policy. We hear the government use the term `social coalition' so frequently. This bill is obviously part of the centrepiece—probably the centrepiece—of the government's social coalition. As the centrepiece of cost cutting, I am raising the relationship of this bill to the rest of the government's program. Last year Senator Newman, prior to her resignation from the ministry, said she was unable to guarantee that there would be no loss of benefits to anyone affected by the proposed changes to welfare reform of which this bill is an integral part.

speech.para: In recent months, this government have had no problem putting out money for roads and Defence. I want to know whether they are going to take the savings from this bill and actually invest them in the capacity building programs that the former Minister for Family and Community Services talked about. It is unknown to me whether her agenda has become the agenda of the new Minister for Family and Community Services. It is almost impossible to tell in this House whether the Minister for Community Services has an agenda at all. But I would hope that there is some commitment to a positive agenda of reform on the part of the new minister, Senator Vanstone, and that she will take the opportunity to live up to the commitments made by the former minister that there was going to be an absolutely essential investment of significant money in capacity building programs and in changes to reward work over welfare. That is why we, as an opposition, are supporting this bill. We have a positive agenda for reform. We recognise that it must be funded. We doubt that this government is genuine in its previous public commitments to funding that agenda. But we believe that, when we come to government, that will be an agenda that we will take on wholeheartedly because we are prepared to invest in capacity building programs, and we are prepared to reward work over welfare.

talk.start.para: —The Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (New Zealand Citizens) Bill 2001 has come to the House, to my knowledge, after 20 years or more of discussion between the Australian and New Zealand governments about the relationship between the citizens of each country; for instance, what are the rights of Australians in New Zealand and what recognition should New Zealanders be given in Australia? There is a closeness in our history: the fact that, even when we were separate colonies of the British Empire, there was a close relationship, stretching right back to 1828 until 1840, during which time New Zealand was under the jurisdiction of the Governor of New South Wales; and, of course, New Zealand is mentioned in the Australian Constitution.

speech.para: It is not surprising that we have such a close link and that there has been such a ready and easy movement of people between the two countries. However, in the latter years there has been not strain so much but differences as the Australian economy has expanded and our population has blossomed and increased. There is new life and variety in Australian life and, of course, that is reflected in both the lifestyle and wellbeing of Australians compared with New Zealanders. The variety of opportunities in Australia has expanded, and that has tended to attract Kiwis from across the Tasman to want to live in Australia and to become permanent residents of our nation.

It is very interesting to look at the composition of the New Zealand community living in Australia. The most recent figures that I am aware of are the 1996 census figures which record almost 300,000 New Zealand born persons in Australia. It appears that the increase is roughly 1½ per cent per annum. The distribution of those people by state and territory shows that Queensland has the largest number of New Zealanders, followed by New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia. The average age of New Zealand born people in Australia in 1996 was 35 years compared with 44 years for all overseas born people. Something that every Australian has observed is that New Zealanders coming to Australia tend to be young, active and looking for opportunity. The age distribution of New Zealanders in the census showed that 10.3 per cent were nought to 14 years of age and 46 per cent were 25 to 44 years of age.

Another interesting feature was the qualifications of New Zealanders. Despite the fact that they were younger than the average migrant coming to Australia, they were very similar in skill level to people living in Australia: 42.4 per cent held some form of educational-occupational qualification compared with 42.3 per cent of Australians. Among the New Zealand born, 16 per cent had higher level qualifications and 16.1 per cent had skilled vocational training. Of those with no qualifications, 11 per cent were still attending educational institutions. This is very interesting because there appears to be, in those people who have come to Australia from New Zealand, quite a spread of skills and disciplines. The figures on earning capacity show that at the top end of the skills and qualifications range, there is a significant number of New Zealanders earning well above the average income of native born Australians. At the other end, however, there is a significant number of New Zealanders who have struggled on arriving in Australia and who have found it necessary to go on welfare.

It has been said by some that the welfare benefits in Australia are more attractive than in New Zealand and that that is a good reason for New Zealanders to move to Australia. Whether there is truth in that, I am not aware, but that has been said and it appears that there are among those New Zealand citizens living in Australia a significant number with low skill levels. In this day and age, as Australia has changed and moved into a more technologically astute and technologically dependent economy, people who lack skills have great difficulty in finding employment. What the government has been able to do is successfully negotiate with the New Zealand government on the way in which our relationship, the movement of people and their access to benefits should be dealt with.

The new social security arrangements between Australia and New Zealand were announced by the Prime Minister. That was after a very successful visit by John Howard to New Zealand on 26 February 2001. Those negotiations, to my knowledge, had been going on for 20 years. The situation had been remarked upon for over 20 years as a matter of some concern between the two governments. Helen Clark and John Howard were the ones that brought together a suitable arrangement.

The agreement will be similar in character to the reciprocal agreements that we have with other countries in similar circumstances—with Italy and the UK, and we are trying to develop one with Greece. Countries from which many people have come to Australia are usually covered by some form of reciprocal agreement which covers things such as the age pension, assistance to people who are severely disabled and carers. Under this arrangement, each country will contribute the cost of payments according to the period of working life spent in the country. That is similar to all the other reciprocal agreements. The payments do not start until a period, as I remember it, of 10 years spent in work in Australia.

From 26 February this year, New Zealanders moving to Australia to live will need to meet normal migration selection—that is something we have not applied before—before they can access certain social security benefits and obtain Australian citizenship. The freedoms which Australians and New Zealanders enjoy under the trans-Tasman travel arrangement to work in each other's country remain unchanged and unaffected by the process, and New Zealanders will still be able to travel to Australia without a visa. New Zealanders can live, study or work here indefinitely.

The really substantial change reflected in the bill before the House today is to the definition of `Australian resident'. Under the social security law, the definition of `Australian resident'—this is not a change to the immigration law; it is a change to the social security law—will restrict access to the full range of social security payments to New Zealand citizens unless they are holders of permanent visas. That is the change. They will not be able to access welfare unless they are the holders of permanent visas. Those who come here in the future will not be able to obtain a permanent visa. If they are not able to obtain a permanent visa, they will not have access to Newstart and similar payments. They will continue to access family payments and some of the concession cards. They will also continue to be able to access Medicare, emergency housing, higher education and some employment services. Those who are currently living in Australia or who are in the process of moving to Australia permanently will not be affected by the changes that were negotiated by the two prime ministers. New Zealanders who do not obtain a permanent visa but who have been living and working in Australia for at least 10 years will be given short-term income support for up to six months if they run into difficulties. That also reflects reciprocal agreements between Australia and other nations.

The current agreement will remain in place until 30 June 2002, when the new agreement takes effect. I trust that the Minister for Community Services and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will be very vigilant to make sure that there is not a great inward rush of New Zealanders as they come here to take advantage of this window of opportunity.

I do not wish to delay the House. I think this is an enlightened approach. It has been needed for about 10 years. It has been impossible to sensibly manage the relationship between Australia and New Zealand with the access to welfare. That has been a magnet for New Zealanders wanting to come to Australia. It has not been used correctly in some instances. This approach is very fair both for Australians living in New Zealand and for New Zealanders coming to Australia. New Zealanders will be able to come, they will be able to work, they will be able to holiday, but they will not be able to access Newstart unless they hold a permanent residency visa. That definition is taken care of by the Social Security Act and these changes before the House rather than through the Immigration Act, which would be the natural way to consider it. This is a much more successful way of dealing with it. I want to compliment the two prime ministers and the governments of both countries for being able to forge such a change without damaging the relationship between the two nations.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank members on both sides of the House for their contributions to the debate on the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (New Zealand Citizens) Bill 2001. In particular, I would like to thank the member for Mitchell for his contribution, which was very lucid. It is pleasing to see that both sides of this place agree on this very important issue. It is, of course, unfortunate that the member for Lilley found it necessary to stray from the bill, making it necessary for the deputy speaker to make sure that he stuck to the bill.

speech.para: It is overwhelmingly obvious that most Australians recognise the very special and close links that Australia has had with New Zealand. We share a common history, typified through our great Anzac tradition dating back to the landing at Gallipoli and going right up to recent times, when we had the joint participation of forces deployed to East Timor. It is fair to say that we have more in common with New Zealanders than with any other nation in the world, particularly on the sporting field. The relationship that we have built over years has been based on common needs, common values and common interests. It is clear that Australia and New Zealand have both benefited greatly over the years from the free flow of people across the Tasman to live, to work and to travel. I must emphasise that this will not change with the passage of this bill. This bill gives effect to the changes announced by the Prime Minister of Australia, the Hon. John Howard MP, and the Prime Minister of New Zealand, the Rt. Hon. Helen Clark MP, on 26 February 2001. The new arrangements mark the successful conclusion of the social security negotiations between Australia and New Zealand that date back to 1999.

The new arrangements will be similar to our arrangements with other countries. It will cover unemployment assistance, age pensions, assistance to people who are severely disabled and carers. Under the agreement, each country will contribute to the costs of the payments according to the period of working life spent in each country. These arrangements represent a substantial step forward in our social security relations with New Zealand. They are mutually beneficial and affordable. They also provide a fair approach to the cost of supporting people in need while preserving the common labour market and free movement of people currently available through the trans-Tasman travel arrangement. It will place citizens taking up residence in Australia on the same basis as other migrants by restricting access to social security payments unless the person meets normal migration selection criteria or the payment is covered by a social security international agreement.

The bill achieves this by amending the definition of the Australian resident for the purpose of the social security law. The amendment will restrict New Zealand citizens' access to the full range of social security payments unless they are holders of a permanent visa. The changes will not apply to New Zealand citizens who were resident in Australia on 26 February 2001, or who are temporarily absent from Australia and who have been in Australia for a period—or periods—of 12 months in the previous two years immediately before 26 February 2001. For those New Zealand citizens who are intending to reside in Australia, a three-month period of grace will apply from 26 February 2001. A six-month period of grace will apply to those New Zealand citizens temporarily absent from Australia on 26 February 2001 and who are in receipt of a social security payment under the portability arrangements that apply under the social security law. A longer 12-month period of grace will apply to those New Zealand citizens, resident in Australia but temporarily absent, who are unable to return to Australia in the three-month period and are not in receipt of social security payments.

This bill will introduce amendments to the definition of the Australian resident so that only a holder of a special category visa—a protected SCV holder—will be considered an Australian resident for the purpose of the social security law. Amendments will also allow payment of Newstart allowance, youth allowance and sickness allowance for a one-off period of up to six months to New Zealand citizens who are not protected SCV holders but who reside in Australia for a continuous period of at least 10 years from February 2001. The proposed amendments will achieve the required restriction to access to social security payments for New Zealand citizens who reside in Australia but who do not become permanent residents or Australian citizens. The amendments also ensure that changes do not apply to child related social security payments and access to concession cards for all suitably qualified New Zealand citizens.

I note that New Zealanders will still be able to travel to Australia without a visa—they can live, study or work here indefinitely. The most substantial change reflected in this bill is to the definition of an Australian resident in the social security law to restrict access to the full range of social security payments to New Zealand citizens unless they are holders of a permanent visa. New Zealand citizens who come here in the future and do not obtain a permanent visa will not have access to Newstart allowance and similar payments. They will continue to have access to family payments and some concession cards. Also, they will continue to be able to access Medicare, emergency housing, higher education and some employment services.

New Zealanders who currently live in Australia or who are in the process of moving to Australia permanently will not be affected by these changes. These people will automatically retain current rights and privileges as if they are permanent residents of Australia. We recognise that these people have already made Australia their home and we want to ensure that they are not unfairly disadvantaged by the new arrangements. I know the member for Mitchell is very keen on that. In addition, New Zealanders who do not obtain a permanent visa but who have been living and working in Australia for at least 10 years will be given a short-term income support of up to six months if they run into difficulties.

The current arrangements will remain in place until 30 June 2002 when the new agreement takes effect. These arrangements represent a substantial step forward in our social security relations with New Zealand. It goes without saying that the new social security arrangements between Australia and New Zealand will provide a more stable, durable and affordable underpinning for the free trans-Tasman flow of people. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I move as an amendment to the motion for the second reading:

speech.para: This is a bill which proposes to retrospectively correct a very serious administrative omission which has rendered the aircraft noise levy inoperative from 1 July 1996 to 21 February 2001. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —During question time, the Leader of the Opposition asked me a question about the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation. I took it on notice, and I undertook to get back to the House as soon as I could. I have investigated the matter and can inform the House as follows. There were allegations of a conflict between the minister's portfolio responsibilities in relation to interactive gambling and his private interests in relation to poker machines. I think that the following points are relevantly made in refuting the claims of a conflict of interest. The minister declared to me and to the parliament that he was a beneficiary of a family trust with interests in hotel-motel operations. There was no specific mention of poker machines, but one could not reasonably expect that the operations of the hotels would be provided in fine detail. There was no reference to linen or china either. The minister's portfolio responsibilities have not encompassed interactive gambling issues. Senator Alston's response to his charter letter in November 1998 detailed Mr McGauran's responsibilities. Those responsibilities did not touch upon any online matters.

speech.para: The minister was, however, Acting Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts from 7 December to 17 December—a period encompassing debate and passage of the bill, but of course the debate and passage of the bill reflected previously determined government policy. The minister—and this is very relevant to the allegations made—was not present at cabinet on the three occasions that interactive gambling was discussed—namely, 3 April, 8 May and 26 June.

As is well known, the minister represents Senator Alston in the House of Representatives, and in that capacity he carried the Interactive Gambling (Moratorium) Bill 2000 in the chamber. On 7 December, there were three divisions during consideration of the bill. He voted in each of those divisions. House of Representatives standing order 196 states:

quote.para: No member shall be entitled to vote in any division upon a question (not being a matter of public policy) in which he or she has a direct pecuniary interest not held in common with the rest of the subjects of the Crown.

speech.para: The practice, however, defines public policy as government policy, not identifying any particular person individually and immediately. It could not reasonably be taken, therefore, to have been relevant to the minister's situation.

Mention was also made in the parliament today of the minister's interest in the National Australia Bank. It was declared to me and the House that a company in which he held an interest had purchased shares in the NAB. The secretary of the department asked that Mr McGauran ensure that there was no direct influence on these shares. His portfolio responsibilities do not create a conflict with the NAB holding.

I have obtained a letter from the Clerk of the House detailing the compliance with the requirements of the declaration of interests by members. The Clerk confirms that the requirements of the House are summarised in the guidelines authorised by the Committee of Members' Interests:

quote.para: ... require under category 2 the declaration in respect of family and business trusts to nominee companies of the names of trusts, the nature of their operations and their beneficial interests or beneficiaries. The requirement for the declaration of the nature of operations has not been interpreted as requiring the declaration of the details of activities undertaken by the particular business.

speech.para: That means that the minister has complied in full with the requirements of the declaration of a pecuniary interest. I might also add that the Clerk's letter confirms that between 1984 and 1988 the House required members to declare interests orally before speaking in debates and before voting in a division. These requirements were abolished following a report from the Committee of Members' Interests which expressed doubt that the requirement served any useful purpose. I understand that a similar action was not taken in another place.

It seems, therefore, on the examination that I have made and on the advice that I have received, that there is no breach of the obligations by the minister at all.
