The minister declared his interests, the minister has been forthright and the minister did not participate in the cabinet discussion. In piloting the legislation through the House, the minister was merely publicly advocating government policy which, as a member of the government, he was bound to do. I absolutely reject any suggestion that he has behaved improperly. I table a letter from the Clerk addressed to me, dated 6 March. I also table advice that I have received from Barbara Belcher, First Assistant Secretary, Government Division, Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

talk.start.para: —I wonder if I could have your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker.
(Mr Hollis)—Yes.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for your indulgence on this matter—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I simply ask for your guidance as to the basis on which—
—You don't mind me asking, do you? I am simply asking the Deputy Speaker a question.
—My advice is that the honourable member for Brand, the Leader of the Opposition, asked for indulgence, and I have granted indulgence.

—Thank you very much for that, Mr Deputy Speaker. Of course, the Prime Minister's answer on this ought not to complete, for any body like ours, a full accounting on the question of the potential of a conflict of interest. That potential is substantial. The point about conflict of interest is not whether or not you own a particular company and then have to give a description of whether it has linen or cutlery or whatever; it is whether the operations of the companies put you in a situation where you may, as a minister, find yourself in a conflict of interest. If you are handling a gambling interest and you happen to own poker machines, you have the potential for a conflict of interest. So that particular sleight of hand—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: indulgence is poorly used in this place. If the Leader of the Opposition wishes to move a substantive motion, that is fine, but to use indulgence to—
—So you're going to tell the Speaker what to do now, are you?
—So the acting minister for gambling—
—Order! The Prime Minister has the call.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, it is my understanding of the granting of indulgence in this place that it is not normally done to allow contentious debate but rather used for matters of courtesy and matters where there are no substantive differences of opinion. The opposition leader is perfectly entitled to speak at whatever time he chooses, but I think it is not appropriate that the indulgence device be used.

—As the Prime Minister would appreciate, what I thought would happen is that the Prime Minister would explain and then the Leader of the Opposition would ask for indulgence. After that, I thought we could conclude the discussion. I hope that the Leader of the Opposition will soon conclude.

—I will be as brief as I possibly can, Mr Deputy Speaker, bearing in mind the concerns you have expressed. The question of a potential conflict of interest arising from the operations of a company does not go just to whether or not cabinet has considered it. Did the Prime Minister cover whether or not any submissions had been made to the minister in the period when he was the acting minister associated with those concerns? Did he cover any submissions made or any arguments put to him by those who had concerns one way or another with the decision? Has he been approached in any way, shape or form in his private capacity on these matters? Has he seen any documentation arising out of the department? Was he dropped a copy of the cabinet submission or any other materials associated with it? These are all relevant questions which go to the matter of whether or not a conflict of interest has occurred.

speech.para: The Prime Minister seems at least alive to the possibility that a conflict of interest could arise, given the character of the honourable gentleman and the minister's interests in this matter—those poker machines. It seems to me that the Prime Minister has inspected the detail of that activity. The mystification on his face as I started to ask a few of these basic questions is a pretty fair indication that the Prime Minister has done a pretty paltry job of coming to a conclusion as to whether or not his ministerial code of conduct has been breached. Given the Prime Minister's record on the administration of his code of conduct, I guess we ought not be surprised. There will be further opportunities to pursue this.

debateinfo.title: AIRCRAFT NOISE LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 2001

talk.start.para: —The aircraft noise levy collects revenue to fund a significant home and public building insulation program around airports with noise above a prescribed level. As at 31 January 2001, the levy has collected $197 million against the $347 million expended on insulating 3,300 homes and 80 public buildings. It has been estimated that the levy will need to continue for another five years to fully finance the insulation program. The Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001 proposes to deem that the appropriate ministerial declaration was made for the period from 1 July 1996 until 21 February 2001. From that date, a new prospective declaration was gazetted by the Assistant Treasurer. The reason for retrospectivity going back the best part of five years is that there has been massive incompetence on the part of this government. It is blaming the bureaucracy for this error. Notwithstanding the fact that the bill is retrospective, Labor need to support this bill because it confirms what we believed to be properly collected revenue. If this measure were not passed, that would necessitate the return of the levy to the airlines which collect it, despite the fact that the real economic incidence of the levy was on passengers. That would result in an undue and inappropriate windfall gain for the airlines, as well as a significant cost to the Commonwealth and taxpayers generally.

speech.para: In that regard, it is a legitimate retrospective piece of legislation but one which has been imposed on this House and is necessary because the government failed to do the administratively appropriate thing, and that is make a ministerial declaration from 1 July 1996 when the aircraft noise levy was originally supposed to begin. Regrettably, this government has been—and I have made this point a number of times—so focused on the goods and services tax over the past few years that they have let a whole raft of important taxation issues—just as with this one—slip away. Their administration of the taxation arrangements in general has been far from satisfactory. I have spoken previously in this parliament about the government's failure to properly police fuel substitution and their failure to protect taxpayers and, indeed, motorists against the resultant excise evasion scams. I have talked about the Taxation Office's inadequate pursuit of the missing superannuation entitlements of many workers. I have talked about centralisation of the Taxation Office staff in the ACT to the exclusion of people in areas like Western Australia. I have talked about the issuing of multiple Australian business numbers to businesses who only ever wanted one number and, indeed, on occasions issuing wrong Australian business numbers and having to tell businesses, `No, that's not your proper ABN, you've got to use this one,' after they had printed off stationery and incurred various business costs, having relied on the initial advice. I have also talked about the private binding ruling saga where hundreds of millions of dollars, and perhaps even billions of dollars, have been lost in tax revenue where the Taxation Office should have been chasing up dodgy offshore employee benefit superannuation and employer superannuation schemes.

Since the parliament has been informed on a number of occasions about the failings of the Taxation Office and this government concerning those questions, I think there are other issues that need to be raised in this House as well. Indeed, government members could do with some reminding about the slipshod manner in which this government has handled tax administration issues. It would seem that the government is starting to drown under the weight of these administrative failures. One of the most conspicuous failures of this government in relation to tax administration and excise administration is that of petrol. It showed in the Treasurer's face over the last few days in question time and in the parliament generally as he struggled to get his head around the Prime Minister's populist trashing of what remained of the surplus to make up for his own inadequacies. The government might not have been brought to the situation of making this backdown on petrol indexation as it has done if it had been prepared in the first place to keep its promise that the GST would not increase the level of petrol taxation and therefore should not lead to any petrol price increases. We saw that in the first instance the government claimed that GST would not lead to an increase in petrol taxes, but in fact what we had was a reduction—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The bill that is before the House is the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001. The member for Wills is moving well outside the confines of the bill, and I ask you to direct him to return to the provisions that are contained in this bill.

(Mr Hollis)—I heard the member for Wills at the beginning clearly outline his amendment, and I thought he was sticking to the detail. But I will listen and, if the member for Wills was ranging widely, I am sure he will bring his comments back to dealing with the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I point out to the member for Cook, who may not have been present when I moved my original amendment, that the third part of my amendment to the motion for the second reading condemns the government for giving priority to the GST at the expense of other important taxation matters. I am expressly speaking to that part of my amendment, and I intend to continue doing so.

speech.para: We had a situation where the government said that the GST was not going to increase the level of petrol taxes. What happened was that it dropped the excise by some 6.7c a litre, but then we found GST adding on 8.2c a litre—an immediate windfall gain to the government of the order of 1.5c a litre. That gain increased in the course of the year 2000 as international circumstances led to petrol prices increasing generally. We saw the GST adding on its own increase, because it is a retail tax, and leading to higher petrol taxes and higher petrol prices. Then we saw the February excise indexation where the GST effect on the CPI generally was passed through. So we saw the petrol excise and the GST tax upon a tax each feeding off the other in a vicious inflationary spiral, and there was an awful lot in the way of extra petrol taxes being paid as a result of the GST. Unfortunately, the government has refused to clarify the extent of the windfall. I think many Australians were disappointed about the broken petrol tax promise, the refusal of the government to admit that it had broken its promise and its refusal to quantify what the impact of that was and what the windfall gain to the government was. We got condescending lectures from the Treasurer and the Prime Minister concerning those matters, which served only to further anger taxpayers and no doubt played their part in the election results in Western Australia and Queensland. We were told over and over again by the government that it could not give the excise back because that would see the budget surplus disappear. That was a bit rich. All we wanted back was the windfall gain which had accrued to the government as a result of its breaching its petrol tax promises in the first place.

To add to this, we witnessed a major blunder on the part of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, entirely relevant to this issue of the competence of the government's administration. He was forced to reveal, just prior to the Western Australian state election, that a whopping $2.9 billion had not been used for road funding as it should have been. We had what was a damning report from the Australian National Audit Office on the management of our national highways, a report which raised very serious questions on the administration of road funding within the Department of Transport and Regional Services and, indeed, raised questions about the confidence of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services to handle this most important policy area. That was a report which directly criticised the Minister for Transport and Regional Services for failing to report to the parliament important financial details about road funding. The Minister for Transport and Regional Services had to admit that he had failed to fulfil his requirements under the Australian Land Transport Development Act. He said, `Technically, like previous ministers, it would appear that I am in breach.' My colleague the shadow minister, the member for Batman, will talk about the situation in relation to previous ministers, but this was in fact the second time that the National Audit Office had criticised the minister for failing to comply with his own legislation.

At the end of 1999 the Australian National Audit Office slammed the transport minister for breaching aviation legislation when he failed to supply corporate plans for two years. It is simply not good enough to have the minister saying, `I didn't know about the requirements of the legislation.' He is the minister. He is someone who has been feeling the pressure on petrol and road funding. He put out a misguided and desperate attempt to gag his MPs from talking when the Audit Office report was released. Australian motorists know only too well that they have been short-changed by the Howard government in relation to petrol prices and road funding. Enormous moral and political pressure has been put on the government by the opposition, motoring organisations and a range of community groups to stick to its promises concerning GST on petrol and remove the spike and hand it back to motorists.

The administrative neglect and sloppiness underlying the need for this piece of legislation is apparently not attributable to the current minister for transport—although it is not very far from his door! The bill before the House is necessary because the Howard government has failed since 1996 to declare Kingsford Smith airport a leviable airport. This declaration allows the collection of a levy on jet aircraft to cover the cost of the impact of their noise on the community. That enables us to put in place noise amelioration programs such as the insulation of houses and public buildings. The last time Kingsford Smith airport was declared a leviable airport, as was intended under the legislation, was by the then Minister for Transport, the Hon. Laurie Brereton, on 18 September 1995. For continuity of the program, the next declaration was due before 1 July 1996. As we have now become aware, this did not occur and, as a direct consequence of that oversight, error or incompetence, the collection of the levy since then has been illegal.

At some point in the history of this legislation, the responsibility for making declarations under the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act 1995 has shifted from the minister for transport to the Treasurer. The timing and reasons for the shift in ministerial responsibility are not covered in the explanatory memorandum. But what is clear is that the last time this part of the legislation was adhered to was under the former Minister for Transport, Laurie Brereton, the member for Kingsford-Smith. Now we have the Assistant Treasurer taking the rap. It is a bit unclear, and no-one in government—Treasurer, Assistant Treasurer, Minister for Transport and Regional Services—is stepping forward to take responsibility for this and say, `It was my fault, I should have done it.' Clearly, this is a failure on the part of this government, a government which has been very remiss in relation to administrative matters, when what it needed to do, rather than be focused on the GST to the exclusion of all else, was to make sure that important administrative issues in relation to taxation were dealt with properly.

I have talked about the failure of the transport minister to pay sufficient attention to the administration of his portfolio—in fact, his record is one of not taking responsibility for the consequences of his poor administration—and we have the recent exposure of the maladministration of the Australian Land Transport Development Act, to which I have referred, as a pretty good example to highlight his buck-passing. The first and obvious casualties were his two advisers. While, on the one hand, he took the defensive stance that he had operated the legislation in the same way as Labor had, claiming that more than the default 4.95c per litre had been spent on roads—making those defences to protect his own hide—on the other hand, he lashed out and sacked two key advisers. Mr Anderson claimed that those staff had failed, that they had not kept him informed, and he complained that he was not made aware of the issues in the Audit Office report until it was tabled and was therefore unable to prepare a response. In falling on his sword, Mr Oxley said:

quote.para: Mr Anderson only became aware of the tabling in parliament of the ANAO report, and the issues raised in it, after the event on Thursday, 8 February 2001.

speech.para: This is totally contrary to the minister's press release on 9 February, the day after, when he conceded that he was aware of the suggestion of a substantial surplus in the Australian land transport development special account last November. Frankly, this is a minister who has hidden behind a `nice guy' image for far too long—his actions on that day expose his desperation and his failure to accept proper accountability and responsibility for his errors.

I now return to my amendment, which condemns the government for, amongst other things, giving priority to the GST at the expense of other important taxation matters. One of the things that has caused small business a great deal of needless grief, particularly during the summer holiday period, has been the obligation to fill out the second business activity statement. The government is now claiming that it has heard from small business, that it has listened to small business and that as a result small business will be given the option of annual reporting of their business activity statement obligations rather than being required to report on a quarterly basis. We have to take this announcement with a certain amount of salt because, when the government originally announced the business activity statement, it said that it had introduced the form after consultation with small business and after consultation with accounting bodies. The tax office claimed there had been widespread consultation and that this was the form that small business wanted and this was a form that was going to simplify the taxation system.

Indeed, the Treasurer used to boast that his new tax system amounted to a simplification of the tax system. He went on record on a number of occasions, in this House and elsewhere, talking about simplification of the tax system. Mysteriously, after about 1 July last year when the GST came in, he stopped talking about this idea of simplifying the tax act. Increasingly, small business came to realise the full horror of the red tape obligations which had been placed on them and just how far from the truth the government's boast that it would cut small business red tape by 50 per cent had been. In fact, there have been surveys suggesting that, far from being cut by half, their red tape has doubled, in particular as a result of the GST and the business activity statement.

The opposition has established an inquiry into the business activity statement which I have the honour of chairing. That inquiry will be looking not simply at business activity statement issues, although they are important. Of course, the option of annual reporting is a worthwhile option and one which we pressed on the government. The government has referred to us as being policy lazy. The truth is that, in recent times, we have not been able to produce policy fast enough for them to pick it up. After we pressed on them the option of annual reporting, they have agreed to put this forward as an option. But small businesses are saying, as well, `We still have to collect all this data on a daily and weekly basis, so to report it on an annual basis may not relieve our GST obligations a great deal.' We certainly heard that at the business activity statement inquiry when we had our first hearing in Melbourne on Friday. We went to the electorate of Melbourne Ports and we also heard from small businesses in the electorates of Chisholm and Deakin about issues affecting them, and they were concerned about the total GST based workload. It is an important task of this inquiry to hear from small businesses about not only business activity statements but also other aspects of the GST workload and how they might be improved.

It is Labor's intention to seek the support of small businesses. This is a government which has talked the talk of small business but which has invariably failed to look after small business—whether it be issues of market power or retail concentration or any of those sorts of issues, it is always looking after big business. This is a tax system which was essentially designed by big business and the tax office, with precious little genuine input from small business. We are intending to change that. We are intending to come up with recommendations, through the business activity statement inquiry, designed to genuinely reduce the red tape burden for small business and make their GST compliance obligations simpler.

In conclusion, this is a piece of legislation which we will support, but we note that it comes from a government which has been incompetent in dealing with the basic requirements of administration and which has been collecting the aircraft noise levy for nearly five years without any proper legislative authority. That is regrettably the kind of bungle which is all too typical of this government, which does not have its eye on the ball of day-to-day administration. It is regrettable that the parliament has been put in this situation but, nevertheless, it is clear that this legislation needs to be passed so that the levy can be collected on a legal basis and the important work of protecting residents who live around airports can continue.

I represent an electorate which includes the Essendon Airport, and I know from residents who live around the airport that issues of airport noise are at times very important to them. One of the problems we have at Essendon Airport is that, although there is a curfew of sorts in operation between 11 p.m. and 7 a.m., in fact, there are all too many aircraft which use the airport at night and disturb the sleep of local residents. Essendon Airport is located particularly close to local residential housing, which is a matter of metres away from several of the runways. Residents are concerned that the curfew is a Clayton's curfew, and noise from the airport does disrupt their sleeping patterns. They are also concerned that the government, in proposing, as it has proposed once before, the sale of Essendon Airport to private operators, may put residents in a situation where resident protections are diminished and existing regulations weakened or that, in any event, private sector operators will be anxious to maximise profit from that airport if it does turn out to be sold off and that residential amenity will suffer as a result. I know from my own experience that issues of aircraft noise are important to local residents and it is, on that basis, important that the levy is collected and that the work protecting residents via insulation is proceeded with.

talk.start.para: (Mr Hollis)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.28 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure to rise tonight to support the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001. I also note the comments that were made by the member for Wills opposite when speaking on this bill. He spoke most of the time on matters totally unrelated to the bill that was before the House during a generally wide excursion into perceived government failings. It was interesting to hear him speak at length on petrol pricing and on the failings of the government. Because the article written by Alan Ramsey on the weekend about petrol pricing was mentioned by the member for Wills, I thought it would be interesting to look at it. Alan Ramsey, who is a fairly independently minded individual, went through the actual statistical price increases that happened under various governments. What is particularly interesting is the level of hypocrisy that we see on the other side of the House, because Alan Ramsey actually pointed out that petrol excise went from 6.15c a litre when Labor came into office in March 1983 to 34.1c a litre by the time it lost office. So it was an incredible change in that they are talking about the 1½c increase that occurred at the time the GST was introduced—and that, the indexation, has been taken off by this government—but if we look at what happened under their government there was a rise from 6.15c a litre to 34.1c a litre in excise, which was not a bad effort.

speech.para: The member for Wills attempted to say, `We actually saw what was happening with BAS.' It was particularly interesting that he said, `We actually put forward that it should be done annually and when we did this the government embraced it.' Actually that indicated how far out of touch the opposition is because we never heard anything about BAS until it was raised in the coalition party room. When it was raised there and recommendations were put forward about having the BAS for companies with a turnover of less than a million dollars annually, suddenly the next day it became Labor Party policy. So I think the member for Wills needs to get his facts right over the actual chronological order in that the recommendations about what should happen came out of the party room. They did not come from the lazy policy concerns of the Labor Party but, rather, from the coalition parties.

The other thing that he mentioned in his general comments as he ranged across the various issues of the bill was that his party was actually terribly concerned for small business and it was very concerned about issues concerning small business and retail concentration. We had an inquiry, a joint standing committee, into retail pricing and the retail sector and the recommendations that came from this particular inquiry were unanimous, supported equally by the Labor Party and the coalition. So I am not quite sure where this myth came forward that you were the party that was very much concerned about concentration of the retail sector. The unions, who of course relate to the larger companies operating in the retail sector, were very concerned about the outcome of the inquiry, so let us get real about where the Labor Party stands on these key issues that are brought up by the member for Wills as showing its great concern for small business, the retail sector and BAS. They have no credibility in any of them. As for fuel tax, Alan Ramsey put paid to that by just showing the huge level of increase in petrol taxes under Labor when they were in power. Secondly, there was no interest in the BAS until it was raised in the coalition party room. Finally, in terms of retail concentration, I would suggest that he look at the bipartisan recommendations that came down from the committee.

Now I will refer to the bill, and I would hope to spend the rest of my time on the bill, as opposed to the shadow minister who ranged over everything else but the bill. He made the failures of administration a big issue. In fact, not one cent has been lost as a result of that. This is simply a mechanical bill where the collection that took place in the period from 30 June 1996 to now is simply deemed as part of the period. The money has been spent. The Secretary to the Treasury has admitted the failure of his department to correct this; it was not on the part of the department of transport. It is a mechanical failure. Nothing was lost in terms of collection and nothing was lost in terms of noise insulation, so all of this false bravado about the failures was not borne out in reality. The legislation amends the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act 1995 and the Aircraft Noise Levy Act 1995. The levy was to be collected until 30 June 1996 and, because of a technical oversight, it was not recognised that this was not moving forward. That was discovered later, and it was reaffirmed as part of the need to bring in new legislation. It was noticed at first when they were looking at doing a similar levy at Adelaide airport. It should be stressed that this levy has been collected continuously since 30 June 1996, so there is no shortfall in the revenue arising from the oversight and, as I mentioned, this is done by way of deeming.

Representing an electorate that receives almost 55 per cent of the total take-offs and landings in Sydney, I am very conscious of the impact of aircraft noise in Sydney. As somebody who lives on Cronulla Beach, which has aircraft going by each day, I can attest to the intrusion of this on everybody in their everyday life. However, my electorate falls just outside the ANEF guidelines determining where compensation is required. You need to be 30 ANEF levels or above in the decibel range and Kurnell is at about the 25 ANEF level. This means that public buildings, including the church and the school, are eligible for insulation, but no other buildings. This is very unfortunate, because it was twice recommended at the meetings of SACF—Sydney Airport Community Forum—that Kurnell be recognised as a special case and that, because of the extent of the flights that go over it, it should receive this insulation. Apart from the church and the school, no insulation has gone into the area and that is unfortunate. I have made representations to the minister, and I understand the problems that exist for him, as his own department is coping with the insulation levels of those who fall within the appropriate guidelines. We all have sympathy for those people who live in areas such as Sydenham, Marrickville and Petersham and who fall within those noise guidelines. But I make a special plea that the people of Kurnell need to be recognised. When the noise sharing program was in operation—and I believe that that worked reasonably well overall—the noise levels did increase over Kurnell if only because of the sheer volume of take-offs and landings. So I do believe that the people of Kurnell, who have often been put on with suggestions of the construction of an airport, should be recognised.

This is a contentious issue. Of all international visitors to Australia, 68 per cent come by way of Kingsford Smith airport. The number of international visitors to Australia continues to increase. In 1975 there were 500,000 international visitors to Australia, last year there were 4.8 million international visitors and this year there are expected to be 5.2 million international visitors. With the projection that by somewhere around 2005 we will reach eight million international visitors, you know that this situation is not going to go away. The high aircraft noise levels across Sydney will continue, so this is an important piece of legislation recognising the disadvantage for those who live under the flight paths, particularly those who come in the orbit of the 30-plus ANEF levels.

The levy applies to a number of airports around Sydney and Australia. The levy makes an important contribution towards funding the costs of properly insulating homes. It provides for double-glazing, the installation of soundproof batts in the ceiling, airconditioning, the replacement of a normal front door with a more solid, soundproof door, and the installation of a damper into a fireplace to prevent noise coming down the chimney. The estimate of these improvements is about $50,000 per house and the Department of Transport's cost ceiling for providing this insulation is $55,500 per dwelling.

I will refer again to the problem of Kurnell in my electorate. While Kurnell falls just outside the guidelines, the Sutherland Shire Council says that any additions or alterations to buildings or any new construction must meet insulation guidelines. So there has to be double-glazing and various soundproofing measures for any building and yet there is no assistance from the federal government. People are being caught both ways and it would be nice either to see the council relax its requirements or to see some assistance for Kurnell.

The levy raises about $40 million overall each year and by the end of January this year it had raised just under the substantial figure of $200 million. This is out of the total outlay by the government of nearly $350 million in insulating 3,300 homes and 80 public buildings around Kingsford Smith airport.

In a survey we carried out in my electorate, we found a number of interesting things. Firstly, we discovered that the average period of residency in Kurnell, a village of 2,500 people, is 16 years. This is significant because you quite commonly hear people say, `These people don't deserve any particular recognition. They knew what they were doing when they bought into that area.' However, if the average length of time that people have been in that area is 16 years, it means that they were there well before the third runway was constructed. It is the third runway, of course, which has impacted very considerably on the quality of life of the people in Kurnell. There are 2,500 people who live in Kurnell. It is not just a small community of a few people; it is a real community. Secondly, 60.5 per cent of respondents to my survey indicated that their standard of living had been affected dramatically by aircraft noise. In addition, the very high figure of 90 per cent said they found aircraft noise to be `annoying' to `extremely annoying' in their day-to-day activities. Clearly it is a serious issue for the residents of this area.

There was a particularly pleasing result for the Sutherland shire over a year ago when our region's representative on the Sydney Airport Community Forum, Mr Kevin Hill, was able to gain approval from CASA for the departure now known as `Deena Two Syd'. The `Deena Two Syd' departure relates to aircraft taking off from runway 16R and going over what is called `the dunes', that is, above the uninhabited Kurnell sand dunes area. This particular provision means that, after going over the dunes, they make a left-hand turn which takes them out further from the residential areas of North Cronulla and Cronulla and also Kurnell. It was quite successful and there was a noticeable, if not big, reduction in the level of noise in the general region.

However, in recent weeks we have had complaints from the people of Bundeena that there has been no change in terms of `Deena Two Syd'. They would find sometimes in adverse weather that the aircraft would go overhead, and we understand that, but the calls indicated that the original flight path was being adhered to. Because of that, we made some inquiries from Airservices Australia. It appears that the reason for the change was that a recent software package omitted to include the manoeuvre, which meant that it could not be uploaded to the navigation systems of departing aircraft and they were therefore unable to perform it. It is a little unfortunate that this occurred. It would have been appropriate if this had been expedited because it was a change that was welcomed by the residents of the area. After pursuing this issue, it became apparent that that was the case. It is important that we protect the rights of the people who live in the area in terms of the noise levels and their quality of life.

It is also important to recognise that Kurnell has a special and unique place in the history of Australia. It is the birthplace of modern Australia because it is the point at which we had European civilisation arriving in Australia. When we have the celebrations of the landing of Captain Cook, they also these days appropriately recognise indigenous culture within the area and the blending of the two communities. We have an official welcome from the Dharawal people, which is appropriate and the way it should be.

Nevertheless, in recognising the very significant role that the Dharawal people have in the area, we also need to celebrate our heritage, and I think the Dharawal people would also understand that. The area is a site of considerable natural beauty and environmental significance. It is dominated by the 280 hectares of the Towra Point Nature Reserve, which is a Ramsar site that has migratory birds from both Siberia and Japan. It is surrounded by Botany Bay National Park and the Royal National Park, and it is all within a stone's throw from the centre of the city.

The site could become a major focus for international visitors as well as domestic visitors. This is why it is important, in terms of noise insulation and a recognition of the unique role of Kurnell that we see the impact on a community—which not only has 2,500 people living there but is also caught by local government regulations, being just outside the requirements for noise insulation under the current requirements of 30 ANEF—as well as acknowledge its unique role in being the birthplace of modern Australia. If this site were in any other country, I think there would be much more celebration of the origins of that country. Here there is one lone obelisk that celebrates the arrival of Captain Cook but not too much else. It is time that we recognised the great significance of Kurnell in our community at several levels. This is paramount in terms of the noise problem that exists there.

I believe the original formulation of this legislation is entirely appropriate. It was introduced by the previous government, and I commend them for it. It was a recognition that noise has a very deleterious effect on those on whom it impacts. Of course, if you are part of the tourism industry, which I was in my time between state and federal politics, it is fine for everyone to get the benefit of having an airport close to the city but there are those who are significantly disadvantaged. In saying that, we appreciate having the airport in such a great location, but it is also appropriate that we compensate those who feel the impact on a daily—often minute-by-minute—basis of the noise of the jet engines going overhead. So this legislation was appropriately crafted and put forward, and we now have legislation to ensure that it will continue. I for one think it is appropriate that we have it brought into this house so that this legislation continues.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the second reading amendment in relation to the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001. In so doing, I would like to draw particular attention to the ministerial incompetence of the Howard government in the transport portfolio and in particular the current Minister for Transport and Regional Services, John Anderson. The administrative neglect and sloppiness underlying the need for this bill is not attributable to the current minister for transport, but it is also fair to say that it is not far from his door.

speech.para: The bill before the House is necessary because the Howard government has failed since 1996 to declare Kingsford Smith airport a leviable airport. As has been explained by other speakers today, this declaration allows the collection of a levy on jet aircraft to cover the cost of the impact of their noise on the community. That is, to put in place noise amelioration programs such as the insulation of houses and public buildings.

For the record, the last time Kingsford Smith airport was declared a leviable airport, as was intended under this legislation, was when the then minister for transport, the Hon. Laurie Brereton, made that declaration on 18 September 1995. For continuity of the program, the next declaration was due before 1 July 1996. As we all know, this did not occur and the collection of the levy since then has been illegal as a consequence of that oversight, error or incompetence. On 11 March 1996, the responsibility for making declarations under the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act 1995 shifted from the Minister for Transport to the Treasurer. From this bill before us, it seems that someone forgot to tell Treasury of this responsibility.

The reason for that shift in ministerial responsibility is not covered in the explanatory memorandum. What is clear, however, is that the last time this part of the legislation was adhered to it was under the then Minister for Transport, the Hon. Laurie Brereton. Now, the rap is being taken by the Treasurer and the Assistant Treasurer. When the details of this bill and the error it was correcting were advised publicly, my immediate thought was, in light of recent events—to put it rather plainly—`Here is another stuff up by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, John Anderson.' Given the history of this legislation, the closeness of this issue to the transport portfolio and the fact that the last declaration was by the last minister for transport—and nothing since—anyone would be forgiven for thinking that this was another mess by the Deputy Prime Minister and member for Gwydir, Mr Anderson.

The error, I suggest to the House, has a very John Anderson ring about it. The transport minister has been plagued by maladministration in his portfolio. Not only does the minister have a record of paying insufficient attention to the administration of his portfolio; he also has a great record of not taking full responsibility for the consequences. The recent exposure of his maladministration of the Australian Land Transport Development Act is a good case to highlight his buck-passing. The first and obvious casualties were his two advisers. While on the one hand taking the defensive stance that he operated the legislation the same way that Labor had, a point I will return to, and professing that more than the default 4.95c per litre had been spent on roads—while making those defences to protect his own hide—he lashed out and sacked his two key advisers. The minister claimed then that the staff did not keep him informed. He complained that he was not made aware of the issues in the Australian National Audit Office report until it was tabled and he was, therefore, unable to prepare a response. In falling on his sword, Mr Oxley said:

quote.para: Mr Anderson only became aware of the tabling in parliament of the ANAO report, and the issues raised in it, after the event on Thursday 8th February 2001.

speech.para: This is totally contrary to the minister's press release on 9 February 2001 when he conceded that he was aware of the suggestion of a substantial surplus in the Australian Land Transport Development Special Account last November. The minister has hidden behind his Mr Nice Guy image for far too long. His actions on that day expose his desperation and his failure to employ proper accountability and take responsibility for his incompetence. When you take a close look at the facts—and I deal specifically with Labor's record on the administration of the Australian Land Transport Development Act—you also see that quite often the minister has been out of order with his statements on that front as well. In his media statement in February, the minister tried to blur the significance of his maladministration by saying:

quote.para: The making of a determination is optional. Former Labor Ministers administered the Act in exactly the same way.

speech.para: Minister, you are wrong. The truth is that, when we go back and look at the facts, we see that the last road user charge determination was for the year 1993-94. As these charges were determined retrospectively, we find that it was actually gazetted by the then transport minister, the Hon. Laurie Brereton, on 18 January 1995. So, by simple and fair assessment, it is clear that the next time a road user charge was due to be gazetted was early 1996. We all know that in early 1996 we were in an election and that the next scheduled charge was to have been determined by the transport minister in 1996. Plainly, that was not Laurie Brereton. The last federal Labor transport minister was in charge and competent with the administration of his portfolio, unlike successive Howard government transport ministers. Our Labor transport ministers did not administer the act in the same way as the current minister, John Anderson, and it is an insult for him to suggest they did.

While we are on the subject of contrasting the respective competence of Labor and the coalition on the administration of the Land Transport Development Act, I will now turn to the issue of tabling reports. This was another prime example of the failing of this transport minister as identified by the Australian National Audit Office this year. What was revealed was that the minister had not tabled annual reports in accordance with the requirements of the same act. I therefore requested a list of all the reports tabled under section 21 of that act and found some interesting and telling facts—if anything, telling gaps. On 20 May 1993, the review of operations, volume 1, covering 1989-91 was tabled; on 14 December 1993, the review of operations, volume 2, covering 1991-92 was tabled; on 28 June 1994, the review of operations, volume 3, covering 1992-93 was tabled; on 28 March 1995, the progress report for 1993-94 was tabled; and, on 21 August 1996, the progress report for 1994-95 was tabled.

It then seems that the Howard government transport ministers took their eye off the ball. It seems that, after the August 1996 report was tabled—presumably, the preparation of that report was well under way under outgoing Minister Brereton—no other reports were tabled until 1999. The requirement under the act was ignored until 8 December 1999 when the current minister tabled three outstanding reports on the same day. Those reports covered the years 1995-96, 1996-97 and 1997-98. On that date in December 1999, the minister slipped in a catch-up tabling of three years worth of annual reports. I submit to the House that this is no way to run an Australian Land Transport Development Fund. Contrary to the impression that the minister, John Anderson, has tried to peddle all around the media, it is not how Labor administered this important legislation. Today, as we speak, the transport minister has still not complied with the act. The reports covering 1998-99 and 1999-2000 have still not been tabled in the House.

When the issue of the failure of the minister for transport to notify a road user charge arose—that is, when the audit office exposed the administrative failing that led to a nominal surplus in the land transport development account—this minister tried to say that that was the same as when Labor administered the fund, and he scapegoated his staff. This is blatantly wrong. It is now obvious that the problems with administering the act arose when the Howard government came into office. It was also the case with the administration of the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act that all was fine until the incompetence of the Howard government intervened. Obviously, the machinery of government is held in contempt by the Howard government. Since the incompetence of the Howard government caused all this anger and angst and fuelled the general mistrust already existing in the community, the minister has been doing his best to show up some sort of division within the Labor Party on this issue. Not one quote has been produced that gives any truth to the rhetoric. We have taken an honest, open position on this matter. We have nothing to hide, as we administered this act in accordance with the requirements of the parliament. By contrast, the Howard government's stream of incompetent transport ministers has mucked up the administration of the Land Transport Development Act, and it was appropriate that the Audit Office exposed the consequences as it did. This is not the first time the Audit Office has exposed the poor administration of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr Anderson.

The 1999 Audit Office report into aviation safety compliance found that the Civil Aviation Act was not being complied with. Again, it was an issue of the minister not tabling reports in parliament—namely, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority Corporate Plans. That Audit Office report found:

quote.para: The finalisation of only two corporate plans in four years since it was established represents a clear breach of the legislation.

speech.para: As an aside, that was the same Audit Office report that revealed that CASA inspectors were spending only 15 per cent to 17 per cent of their time on surveillance tasks.

Again, the federal transport minister, Mr Anderson—your close friend, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley—was exposed for not meeting his legislative responsibilities, let alone his ethical reporting requirements to this parliament. This is the same minister that sat on the government response to key road and rail reports for years, for instance, the Planning not patching report, tabled in 1997, and the first of three key rail reports tabled in August 1998. The industry had to wait until mid-2000 for a response on any of those reports. Then it was a response so vague and brief that it did not give credit to the effort that went into those reports. I draw to the attention of the House that there are other reports outstanding on the minister's desk. In December 1998, the minister commissioned a high-level industry-government task force to provide him with options to increase the international competitiveness of Australian shipping. While the Australian shipping industry is left to wither on the vine, the report on how competitiveness can be increased is gathering dust on his desk.

The transport minister last week admitted another major failing in his portfolio area. It has been revealed that the minister broke his promise on the collection of avgas and avtur levies. This is a matter I spoke at length on in the adjournment debate last Thursday evening. In the May 1999 budget, the House will recall, the minister imposed a levy of 0.51c per litre on aviation fuel to keep down the cost of regional and general aviation towers. It should be pointed out that the cost of these towers became unaffordable because of the location specific pricing policy of the Howard government. Under that policy, charges were reduced at the major airports but increased significantly at regional airports; for instance, in Northern New South Wales close to the Deputy Speaker's electorate. What became obvious last week, conceded by the minister, was that all the revenue from that duty had not been used for the purpose promised to the Australian electorate. In fact, it is now clear that millions of dollars have been inappropriately collected from the aviation industry and have disappeared into consolidated revenue. In conceding this broken promise, what does the transport minister propose to do? Does he undertake to give the money back? No. He sits on the extra money and only commits to resolving the issue during the budget process. In the House the minister said:

quote.para: The government will be considering the fuel duty rate and the control tower subsidy as part of the budget process in the normal way this year.

speech.para: Do not hold your breath if you are in the industry and expect any payback—clawback is the order of the day under the Howard government, be it with respect to pensioners or people doing it tough in the aviation industry. It is therefore time that the House realised that breaking promises is not normal behaviour, even though the transport minister may think that promise-breaking is an acceptable tool of public administration. The Liberal Party and coalition government leader, John Howard, sets a fine example in that vein.

Promises to the aviation industry and to the Australian community were broken. I simply suggest to the House that, if you take something under false pretences, you should hand it back. So when we heard that the collection of the levy from airlines for noise amelioration programs had been botched, it is no wonder we could detect the minister's hand in that incompetence as usual. The Audit Office did not detect the problem to be remedied by this bill when they did their audit of the government's management of non-primary levies last year. That report examined the administration of a number of government levies, including the aircraft noise levy. The oversight is a concern to those who rely on the independence, resources and rigour of the Audit Office to put the microscope on government administration. I note in the second reading speech that the minister attributes the failure to declare Sydney airport a leviable airport as an `administrative oversight'. This is reminiscent of the transport minister sacking two staff to cover his own failings.

In conclusion, I suggest that it is time that Howard government ministers took appropriate responsibility for their actions. It is time that the Howard government ministers got their houses in order and attended to the business and machinery of government. After all, that is what they are paid for, that is what the taxpayers of this country expect of government ministers, and that is why they are resourced to give their attention to such activities.

On that note, I speak in support of the second reading amendment moved by the member for Wills. I believe that, on the basis of the material that I have outlined to the House today, that second reading amendment ought to be supported by both sides of the House. I say that because it was the Prime Minister who said, on his election in 1996, that he was for improved standards on accountability and ministerial competence. The record I have outlined to the House this evening clearly proves that successive Howard government transport ministers since 1996 have failed the standards set by the Prime Minister on being sworn into office in mid-1996. Those standards went to attending to the day-to-day requirements of the operation of parliament and ministerial portfolios, and also to public accountability, integrity and honesty in government. It is for that very reason that the Labor opposition has moved a second reading amendment that:

quote.para: ... condemns the Government for its incompetent administration of the aircraft noise levy, in failing to declare Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport a `leviable' airport for the period from 1 July 1996 to 21 February 2001 ...

speech.para: The second reading amendment also:

quote.para: ... condemns the Government for collecting in excess of $150m—

speech.para: not a small amount—

quote.para: from aircraft operators without due legal authority as a result ...

speech.para: Thirdly, the second reading amendment:

quote.para: ... condemns the Government for giving priority to the GST at the expense of other important taxation matters.

speech.para: When someone accepts the responsibility of being a government minister, Australian taxpayers expect accountability and attention to detail with respect to their performance. The Howard government stands condemned this evening for not meeting that test. Even more importantly, the range of examples detailed to the House this evening clearly suggest that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services is an abject failure when it comes to the administration of his transport portfolio—a very important portfolio. I believe that he should come into the House and give a full and proper explanation with respect to all the issues I have raised in the debate this evening. I say that because the issues I have raised go to competence of government, and the Australian taxpayer expects better. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act 1995 established a regime for the imposition and collection of an aircraft noise levy at certain airports. The funds are used to recover the cost of noise amelioration programs funded by the federal government. It is the case, as the member for Batman has indicated, that there was an administrative oversight within Treasury and that there was no subsequent declaration until 21 February 2001, after the initial period ran out on 30 June 1996. The Treasury discovered the oversight in January in the course of preparing a declaration to make Adelaide airport leviable. The Treasurer and Assistant Treasurer were informed on 9 February after Treasury had sought legal advice on the matter. The Secretary to the Treasury accepts full responsibility. It is worth noting that the amount of levy paid before each landing of a jet aircraft is based on the noise characteristics of each particular aircraft. For example, under the methodology for calculation of the levy, aircraft such as a B747 pay some three to four times as much as a quieter aircraft—for example, a B737.

speech.para: I want to address some of the issues raised by the member for Batman in this debate on the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001. It is, under our system of adversarial parliamentary debate, the role of the opposition to flush out and to expose the government for its weaknesses. That is an acceptable practice within our system. It is also, on our side of the House, quite acceptable to remind the House that Minister Anderson, the member for Batman's opposite number, was not the responsible minister when this event actually occurred—that is, at the end of June 1996. There is much discussion about the ANAO report, and I for one would be wondering why it took so long for the internal workings of government to bring this to the fore. I am not aware that the ANAO has specifically written to the minister to advise him—or to the Secretary to the Treasury. That certainly is not apparent to me. Perhaps there is a responsibility on all sections of government when these oversights occur to bring them to the attention of a number of people who are the relevant authorities.

There has been some discussion about expenditure exceeding collection. In the case of the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act, let me be quite specific. The Sydney airport noise amelioration program to 31 January 2001 has seen the expenditure of $347 million and the collection of something like $197 million. So let us be quite clear that there has been much more money expended on things like insulation in 3,349 homes and 83 public buildings. Some 146 residences have been voluntarily acquired; up to 1,000 residences remain to be insulated if the owners choose to take up that offer. It is worth noting that Adelaide airport, as announced in the 2000-01 budget, will also have the benefit of this levy which will come into effect from 1 May 2001. It is estimated that the levy in Adelaide will raise about $6 million and should apply for around 10 years.

I should also point out that when the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act was introduced into the parliament in 1995 it was made quite clear that the levy would apply at Sydney airport over a period of up to 10 years. There was never any doubt about the intention. Indeed, we might ask why it was only included in the legislation for that nine months. Nevertheless, Treasury discovered it, took legal advice and acted. The minister—who of course was not the responsible minister at the time—has brought this to the attention of the House through the good offices of the Assistant Treasurer.

A few other points are worth making. There is some discussion in the amendment about the collection of $150 million from aircraft operators without due legal authority—and I think I have covered that. As far as condemning the government for giving priority to the GST at the expense of other important taxation matters is concerned, that is normal opposition adversarial discrediting the government style of politics—that is, after all, the role of opposition. If we examine the Labor Party in government for a moment, I can remember a few outstanding examples. I seem to remember a Prime Minister that forgot to put in his tax return for a while. I seem to remember that there was a certain Leader of the Opposition claiming that there was $700 million in the bank when the new government came to office but we found that it was about $10 billion short. So these things work both ways. I will not say much about the l-a-w tax cuts or the excise or the increase in the sales tax. As far as the standards of the government are concerned, it is, in the words of the member for Batman, perhaps easy to accept promise breakers—that is, of course, denied on this side of the House, as he would expect—but this was a simple oversight which the Secretary to the Treasury has accepted full responsibility for. The minister of the day had no connection whatsoever with it and the Assistant Treasurer has acted appropriately.

As far as the general issues around an airport like Sydney are concerned—being South Australian, I guess it is a little dangerous for me to venture in and discuss that issue—there can be little doubt that the politics of the Sydney airport have been with us for at least two decades to my memory, and probably well before that. I seem to remember ministers of the Labor Party resigning. There is the well-known Bennelong funnel and there are all sorts of action groups. Then, in this recent period—with the Olympic Games and that remarkable effort of moving so many people in those wonderful few weeks of athletics and all sorts of sporting activities—we saw Sydney airport do a remarkable job for that city and for this country. But the politics remain and this is another small component of that, I guess, as far as the history books will judge. Having flown into Sydney many times now and understanding a little more about the reality of it, there is no doubt in my mind that it serves that city and the state of New South Wales particularly, as well as the nation, in an exceptionally effective manner.

The most important part about this bill, of course, is that the levy collection does offset the inconvenience that those citizens have endured over the recent years particularly. It is to be hoped that in the future that people in the thousand homes that remain to be offered to have their insulation put in will see the benefit of this levy—after all, that is the main purpose of it—and that the whole issue of administration will pass into the ether. I am sure it will. This has just been an oversight; the process went on. As I said, the Secretary to the Treasury noted it when they were looking at the Adelaide airport and the whole matter has been resolved.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I rise to support this bill and to particularly support the amendment moved by the member for Wills, Mr K.J. Thomson. I also support the sentiments echoed by the member for Batman and shadow transport minister, Martin Ferguson, who would make a much better minister than Minister Anderson and Minister Fahey presently in respect of the issues I am going to raise on this bill.

speech.para: The explanatory memorandum by the Treasurer before the House notes that the purpose of the bill is to deem Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport—SKSA—to be declared a leviable airport for the purposes of the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act 1995 from 1 July 1996 to 21 February 2001. The second reading speech of the Hon. Mr Joe Hockey, member for North Sydney and Minister for Financial Services and Regulations, on this bill was made in this House on 1 March 2001. The minister noted that:

quote.para: The funds that are raised through the levy are used to recover the costs incurred in providing an airport noise amelioration program.

speech.para: As such, the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001 is both necessary and, quite frankly, long overdue in rectifying this technical error in the original legislation. However, the question of who benefits from the noise amelioration program is an ongoing saga of drawing aircraft noise lines in the sand. Obviously, residential areas affected by aircraft noise differ widely depending on changes in aircraft movements. In the case of Sydney airport, the government have made a host of announcements which have thrown noise affected residential and other areas into complete turmoil. Far from the brave promises that were made prior to the 1996 election by the then opposition—now the government—the action they have taken has been precisely the opposite of what they have said. It is therefore timely to remind this House of what the government committed themselves to in terms of aircraft noise. On 8 February 2001 in this chamber, I cited the then Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon. John Sharp, who said in his second reading speech on the Airports Bill 1996 on 29 May 1996:

quote.para: I will refer particularly to the first item in the amendment, which reads:
No sales should occur until all Environmental Impact Statement processes are completed and the future of Sydney West Airport is resolved;

We are determined not to sell Sydney Mascot airport and Sydney West airport until such time as we have satisfactorily completed the environmental impact studies and decisions are made in relation to that. We will not be putting on the market Sydney Mascot and Sydney West airports until such time as we fulfil our election commitment, made by the former shadow minister for aviation, Senator Parer—and indeed reiterated by the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard), then opposition leader—that we will not do so ...

... put them on the market and you will achieve the highest possible value for those airports when you put them up for sale. So we believe that that is the appropriate approach to achieve the goal of obtaining the highest value for Sydney's airports.

speech.para: I further note the second reading speech of the Hon. John Fahey, the Minister for Finance and Administration, on the Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 on 1 October 1997. On page 8958 of the House Hansard, he says:

quote.para: The sale of the Sydney basin airports, which are Kingsford Smith, Hoxton Park, Bankstown, and Camden airports, will take place only after completion of an environmental assessment of options for the site for the second Sydney airport and when the government has effectively addressed noise issues relating to Sydney airport.

speech.para: I next turn to the insightful comments of the then Minister for Transport and Regional Development and member for Lyne, the Hon. Mark Vaile, in his second reading speech on the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997, delivered on 1 October 1997 and found at page 8861 of Hansard.He said:

quote.para: We went through that rigorous EIS process with Holsworthy to make sure that ... the decision on Sydney's second airport was justified on solid grounds. We can move forward now to the completion of that process with Badgerys Creek.

speech.para: But wait, there is more. The member for Lyne made these bold assertions about aircraft noise from Sydney airport. He said:

quote.para: The government promised a more equitable distribution of the aircraft noise problem. We have done that. The government promised a review of the flight paths for Mascot airport, and we have done that.

speech.para: Mr Vaile went on to heap laudatory praise on the long-term operating plan for Sydney airport. He said:

quote.para: Under the coalition, 17 per cent of aircraft movements will be to the north, 15 per cent to the west, 13 per cent to the east and 55 per cent will be to the south.

speech.para: Since the introduction of the long-term operating plan for Sydney airport, the facts have consistently contradicted these forecasts. The most recent statistics from Airservices Australia's Sydney Air Traffic Services—the Sydney airport operational statistics for December 2000, which were received in my office on 26 February 2001—indicate, on page 12 of the report, that aircraft movements to the north of Sydney airport were 27.4 per cent of total movements while aircraft movements to the west were 8.5 per cent. But wait, there is even more.

talk.start.para: —More!
—You are right, Member for Melbourne Ports. Mr Vaile went on to say:

quote.para: What is being done here is exactly what we set out to do—that is, to create a more equitable situation not only for the movement of aircraft in and out of KSA but also for the distribution of noise. We are a government that has inherited a problem that we are dealing with ... There has been positive action to deal with the surrounding suburbs around KSA in an equitable way. We have put those measures in place.

speech.para: The people of Sydney were given promise after promise by the Howard government. Again I cite Mr Vaile from his second reading speech on the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997:

quote.para: But you can rest assured that this government will deliver on alleviating the problems as far as the second airport in the Sydney basin is concerned. We will not be vacillating on this the way the Labor Party has done.

We will not muck about and wait for 13 years to pander to different interests in some of our electorates, as we have seen happen around KSA. We will get on with the job so there is certainty in what is going to happen in aviation in Australia.

speech.para: The government has blood on its hands in this matter tonight. The sheer hypocrisy of these words ring clear in demonstrating the difference between the actual measures and the promises and vain rhetoric that are in these speeches. And what are those measures? The actual measures that this government has implemented are: (1) the proposed sale of Sydney airport without an airport at Badgerys Creek—not only not commenced after five years of office but now being effectively abandoned altogether; (2) the proposed sale of Sydney airport in contradiction of the provisions of the Airports Act 1996, in particular section 18, which requires the lessee of Sydney and Sydney West airports to be the same person or a subsidiary thereof; (3) the abandonment of Badgerys Creek after the EIS process had eliminated Holsworthy as an airport site; (4) the relocation of regional aircraft from Sydney to Bankstown airport; (5) the announcement made on 13 December 2000 that Bankstown airport is to be an overflow airport for Sydney airport; and (6) the introduction of the precision runway monitor system without any prior consultation with the Sydney Airport Community Forum or other community representatives, effectively meaning the restoration of parallel runway operations at Sydney airport and thus undermining the implementation of the long-term operating plan. When we read these speeches together, we get a disjointed series of comments by various coalition members.

I turn to section 18 of the Airports Act, for this section is highly significant in light of this bill's operative parts. The explanatory memorandum to the Airports Bill 1996, tabled by the then Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the Hon. John Sharp, states at page 8:

quote.para: This clause ensures that the airport-lessee companies for Sydney Airport and Sydney West Airport have a common holding company. The requirement for common ownership of the two airport-lessee companies is necessary for the implementation of the Government's development objectives for Sydney West Airport and the complementarity of the two airport operations in Sydney.

speech.para: And what are the `government's development objectives for Sydney West airport' to which the minister refers? To answer this question, one must turn to the coalition's stated aviation policy Soaring into Tomorrow, dated 13 February 1996. I welcome the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, the member for North Sydney and former chairman of the Sydney Airport Community Forum, who is coming into the chamber to listen to what I am saying.

talk.start.para: —What do you know about aircraft noise?

—I know a lot about it, like you. This is the problem we have now and you should be doing something to make sure that you do not flog the airport off without committing yourselves to building a second airport contemporaneously with the sale of—
—Bring back Paul Zammit!
—Don't worry about Mr Zammit. His preferences were warmly received on election night. Page 14 of the coalition's aviation policy states:

quote.para: The coalition will lease the 22 Federal Airports Corporation airports, but, at the same time, introduce a regulatory framework to protect the interests of current and future airport users and local communities ... We have announced that we will not lease Sydney Airport and Sydney West Airport until there is a satisfactory solution to the current aircraft noise problem in Sydney. The leasing process will be deferred until two conditions are met:
• the east west runway is reopened; and
• a genuine environmental impact statement on Sydney West Airport is completed.

speech.para: There is an interesting anecdote in the coalition's policy:

quote.para: The Coalition will set the X values in the CPI-X system for Sydney Airport and Sydney West Airport so that the charges at Sydney West are lower than the ones at Sydney, to give airlines an incentive to use the new airport.

speech.para: This tells me that, in light of the actual announcements by this government on 13 December 2000, the government has deliberately abandoned Badgerys Creek so that it can maximise charges under the CPI-X system, thus maximising profits for that airport. Again, the government has abandoned its own policy in favour of sheer greed and the lust for money. In turn, the government is sacrificing safety and has abandoned its policies relating to the management of Sydney airport and aircraft noise. I put to this government that, over the last five years, it has participated in a systematic campaign of deception of the Australian people, by selling its various parcels of legislation in the hope of aircraft noise sharing amelioration. However, all the while, this government has systematically sought agenda other than the publicly declared intention of the various bills and legislation it has enacted through sheer force of numbers.

I put it to the House that the real agenda is to sell all four Sydney Basin airports at the highest price possible, by maximising their utility in the hands of the new privatised owners. Hence my question on notice No. 2426 on the Notice Paper today. I hope the minister has a look at it. The government has betrayed the public through a systematic campaign of deception, as demonstrated by its repeated conduct in this House in the various speeches made by not one but several frontbenchers and backbenchers of this government with respect to aircraft noise. What is the deception to which I refer? I put this question to the House: how can the government's development objectives as referred to in the explanatory memorandum to the Airports Bill 1996 be fulfilled without the existence of or even intention to construct a second Sydney airport at a known location? As I said earlier, the provisions of section 18 of the act clearly contemplate the existence of Sydney West airport before Sydney airport is leased. The exact parameters of Sydney West airport must be known before Sydney airport can be leased. These parameters are critically important if the government's development objectives are to be realised. The reason for this is simple. By analogy, you cannot learn how to box with only one arm; you must train with both arms.

This government's two-airport strategy for the Sydney Basin is obviously predicated on the known parameters of Sydney West airport. You simply cannot devise a two-airport development strategy without knowing the operational parameters of the second airport. This government has decided to sell a 50-year lease for Sydney airport whilst abandoning Sydney West airport. The Howard government has thus exhibited that very `pandering' to `different interests' to which Mr Vaile referred against the Labor Party when we were in power. I repeat what I said last week in this House when I was speaking on the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2000. There is no EIS on the impact of Bankstown Airport as an overflow airport pursuant to the provisions of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. There is no EIS on the impact of Bankstown Airport in its newfound role, including, for that matter, the interaction between Bankstown, Sydney, Camden and Hoxton Park airports, including aircraft safety impacts. Let us be clear. Bankstown Airport is not Sydney West airport. `Sydney West airport' means, for the purposes of the Sydney West airport EIS of 1996, Badgerys Creek. I repeat: Badgerys Creek. As Badgerys Creek has been shelved, that means there is no Sydney West airport. That is a bloody disgrace. No mere announcement can substitute Sydney West airport for Bankstown Airport.

The member for Watson understands quite clearly what I am saying here tonight. I am pleased he is here in the chamber, because he has an interest in this. He has been in this place a lot longer than I have. The substantial technical analysis in the Sydney West proposal, which includes both the 1996 EIS and the 1997 supplementary EIS, contains comprehensive analysis on the impacts of that airport proposal. No similar documentation exists for the interaction between Bankstown Airport as an overflow airport and Sydney airport, thus making a mockery of this government's development objectives for aircraft management.

The member for Lyne said he represents `regional Australia'. The shifting of regional aircraft movements to Bankstown in order to allocate the most lucrative slots to jet-only aircraft demonstrates the government's commitment to regional Australia. Ha, ha! The betrayal is absolute. It is little wonder the National Party is decaying and its supporters are turning to Country Labor to look after their interests. Today's National Party does not represent the interests of country people. Today's National Party is a servile agent of the Liberals. I am sure that the people where I was born and bred, in Dunedoo, New South Wales, would agree that the National Party is not representing their interests. Just have a look at Labor's vote for Country Labor in the next federal election. You will get a shock, and so will the National Party—and so will the Liberal Party.

This bill is designed to validate moneys being received from the noise levy on users of Sydney airport. For the reasons I have mentioned, the benefits of this noise levy are only as effective as the areas of Sydney that are subject to its benefits. The decisions of this government and the actions they have taken demonstrate the worst scenario of aircraft noise in the Sydney Basin. I will not stand a bar of it, and I will be in here every day and night when this parliament is sitting talking about this issue and putting questions on the notice paper.
