The decisions of the government and the actions they have taken demonstrate absolutely that they have got no interest in looking after the people of Sydney on this issue. The government's own words condemn them. The more I dig into the government's decision on this issue, the more complete the betrayal becomes. We owe the people of Sydney a solution to aircraft noise that is fair and equitable. We owe that to the people of Lowe, the electorate I represent. What the Howard government are doing is criminal. The government must not be allowed to sell the lease of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport without the buyer being required to build Sydney West airport. That is what the government promised.

Finally, this bill, like so many other bills from this government relating to aircraft noise, says one thing but the conduct of this government shows another thing. I urge the people of Australia to make their vote count in the year 2001, this year of a federal election, and show the government that it has not profited by pandering to those interests that would seek to maximise profit at whatever cost. On this issue, the government stands condemned. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have been here for some years, as you have, Mr Deputy Speaker Hollis. I think it is about 15 or 18 years on your part and 20-odd years on mine. It is not often that you find no government member willing to support a bill put forward in this House by the government, in this case the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001. But tonight I am speaking after my friend and colleague the member for Lowe. When the member for Lowe sat down, the minister at the table, who represents one of the North Shore seats in Sydney, looked around to see who was behind her on the government benches to stand up and support the government's smelly dead cat sitting on the table in the House of Representatives tonight. The truth of it is that no-one is. There have been two government speakers on this bill. The member for Cook made a very good argument about what he has done to do the best for his constituents on aircraft noise. The member for Grey in South Australia had something to say as well. There are six other speakers on this bill, which makes eight opposition speakers and two government speakers. No-one from the government is willing to come in here tonight and defend the government's activities on airports in Australia.

speech.para: They are certainly not willing to come in tonight to try and fix up the mess that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services has got the government into on this issue. For years and years—indeed, all the time of his tenure as a minister—he has allowed the revenue to dribble out. He has allowed his department to illegally collect money from people who fly out of Sydney airport, because he was too stupid, too lacking in understanding, too lazy or too something to get the point that they actually had legislation that they had to regenerate. For this minister, that is an ongoing problem. We saw recently that the Auditor-General criticised him for a billion dollar screw-up on road funding. This is a minister that the government ought to take out and shoot before the exchequer is empty.

talk.start.para: —The electorate will soon.

—The electorate will soon, as my dear friend from Melbourne Ports says, because the Minister for Transport and Regional Services—and he is not quite sure what he has to do with the regions—is a menace. He is a menace to people from the country and he is a menace to people from the city. On this bill, once again, he has shown that not only is he a menace but he is incompetent. In politics, if you are clever enough you can get away with being a menace. You and I have managed that from time to time, Mr Deputy Speaker. But, if you are an embarrassment, you go. The trouble is that Minister Anderson has become an embarrassment. He is not just a menace; he is a godforsaken horrible embarrassment.

speech.para: As my dear friend the member for Lowe said, `What we are talking about here tonight is a bloody disgrace'—that is what he said, and it is true. This minister cannot keep his eye on the ball about anything. Of course, he says it is all the fault of the department—probably the reason we are dealing with this Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001, which they could not keep alive, is someone else's fault. It is always someone else's fault. The poor devils who worked in his office got the sack for the roads screw-up—who knows who is going to get the sack for this. It is for sure that someone will. But Minister Anderson, like the good old Kings boy he is, will slip-slide through—he is one of the born to rule people, one of those Liberals in gumboots. He is here representing what? He is here representing his own self-interest; that is precisely what he is representing. What Minister Anderson represents is a ministerial salary and a ministerial car and a minister who sacks staff. My friend the member for Barton is to speak in this debate after me but there are no government members here to defend the government; none of them are here. The minister at the table will not be defending the government—

talk.start.para: —Of course I will be defending the government!
—The government are not sure whether they are defending you either, but no-one is here to defend the government tonight.
—No-one I know got paid $60,000 for riding a bike, of taxpayers' money

—She is all kerosene and no care; that's her! Her trouble is that she is a sell-out, just like Minister Anderson is. The member for Lowe and I are here to talk about our constituents. The poor old constituents of the minister at the table also have a problem with aircraft noise but she keeps telling them, `Don't worry about the long-term operating plan. Don't worry about the precision management plan. Don't worry about the plan that brings all of these planes down over the North Shore.' Your property values are probably dead, and that is probably good socialism, from my point of view. The problem the government has is that this bill is a massive screw-up. If you believe what the minister's colleagues in the National Party think and what his friends in the Northern Territory think—you know, three strikes and you are out, or you are in—he has two on the board. There is the billion dollar screw-up on the road program that the Auditor-General picked him up on, and this one. This is the Deputy Prime Minister of our country and he cannot even get the accounts right.

speech.para: The member for Lowe, the member for Barton and I want to talk about the problems that this government has visited upon the people of Sydney, and the people of south-west Sydney in particular. As the member for Lowe said, `It is a bloody disgrace!' What we have seen with this government is one of the worst three-card tricks—or two-card trick, sharp card trick, spivvy trick—of all time, that is, their new plan for Sydney airport. Here is a bit of parliamentary and political history. I got elected to Marrickville council in 1971—that is longer ago than I like to remember, actually—and at that time the big interest in the east ward of Marrickville council was aircraft noise. It was Malcolm Fraser who had a plan for the major airport needs of Sydney—they do not like to remember Malcolm Fraser on that side of the House, because he was one of those cryptosocialists who got into their party and whom they have now driven out. There were studies, and there was this, that and everything else. It went on for years and years and years and the government finally decided Sydney needed another airport. You did not have to be Einstein or a brain surgeon to work that out! Sydney is an international city and most other international cities have a couple of airports—a big international operator out on the city rim, and a smaller, older, 1930s airport close in. Look at Sydney; maybe it is an international city—the Olympic Games sure showed that it was.

Even Malcolm Fraser worked out that Sydney needed another airport. But, nearly 30 years later, where have these geniuses here worked out that the new airport ought to be? Bankstown. The overflow airport for Sydney airport, in the eyes of the geniuses from the government, is to be Bankstown. For people listening to the radio tonight—and maybe some of them live in Sydney so they will know—Bankstown is about 20 minutes from the centre of the city. Where is Kingsford Smith? It is about 10 minutes from the centre of the city. You would think, if you needed a new airport, that maybe you should not put it in the middle of where about one million people live—but these geniuses think you should! The member for Barton and I know where Bankstown is—it is surrounded by houses. There are houses everywhere out there. The former Prime Minister represented the area and he said that it would be over his dead body that anyone would put an airport at Bankstown and, to his great credit, he ensured they did not. But this government says the solution to aircraft noise and the use of aircraft in Sydney, the biggest international gateway in Australia, is to put a bigger airport at Bankstown.

Even Malcolm Fraser in his wildest dreams would not have thought anyone would be stupid enough to come up with that—but this government have. They think it is a terrific idea. They are telling the people from northern New South Wales and the regional commuters, `Look, don't think you are going to go to Sydney airport; we will send you to Bankstown.' They are telling the people of Bankstown, `We're going to put another airport in your backyard.' The people are saying, `Hang on, listen, we have lived here all our lives, for 20, 30, 40, 50 years.' Bankstown was developed and expanded just after the war, so they have been living there fairly peacefully, and now these geniuses are going to drop an international airport there. They say it is only a commuter airport now but that, when Sydney airport grows and gets bigger, there is only one overflow airport and that is Bankstown. What are they putting in tomorrow? Bigger jets? Of course. It is crazy; it is absolutely crazy. It is like all the things that this government are doing at present. They are a government out of control.

We have a Prime Minister who used to believe in decent fiscal arrangements. We have a Deputy Prime Minister who is mad—he does not know what fiscal arrangements mean and he lets them all lapse. The Auditor-General says that he has screwed up a $1 billion road program and this bill is because he forgot to put the levy back on. For a couple of days they started out by trying to blame us. They said that maybe something happened in 1996 and it never got renewed then. Then they had to go and look at the legislation and it said that after a particular time you had to renew it. Unfortunately for them, they had to renew it when they became government, but they never checked anything.

This legislation is about trying to provide some relief to those people who live under the flight path of Sydney airport. It is about trying to get some money out of people who use the airport to provide some relief to those who live under the flight path, to put some insulation into houses, to do some things to make it livable—not pleasant, but livable. It is bad enough to live under the flight path of Sydney airport. I grew up in a house in Marrickville that was right under the flight path of the north-south runway of Sydney airport. As a child, I grew up seeing the television shake and the plates rattle when the planes flew overhead. I have spent a lot of my life in this parliament saying that we ought to do something about this problem. After all these years of debate about what you do about another airport for Sydney, we have an airport five miles away—Bankstown Airport. That is the new airport for Sydney. It is insane. It is like clearing Queens in New York and putting in a new airport there for La Guardia. It is like demolishing the inner suburbs of Rome and putting in a new airport there. It is like demolishing the Docklands in London and putting in a new airport for Heathrow. It is absolutely stark raving mad. But the government thinks that is the answer. The government thinks that the answer to the aircraft problem in Sydney is an airport at Bankstown. Tonight we are trying to fix up the mess made by the minister, who cares so little about the people who live in Sydney around the airport that he even forgot to continue the legislation that will pay for some of the soundproofing around the airport for people who live right under the flight path.

If you ever want a metaphor for a government that does not care, does not know and does not understand, this legislation is it. This is it. For a government that is out of touch, for a government that has lost the plot, Bankstown as the overflow for Sydney airport is madness—it is just absolute madness. Tonight we are dealing with legislation that tries to fix up some of the minister's problems.

I have been watching the policy stampede of the Prime Minister in the last few days, and I might share with the House a conversation I had with a journalist earlier tonight. He rang me up and asked me, `What are the procedures for the member for La Trobe's private member's bill about trying to make the states pay for the excise on petrol?' I said, `I'm not quite sure: what is your question?' He said, `Well, the government wants to bring this on.' You have to wonder. What we have now, and we saw it on the television earlier tonight, is the member for La Trobeand bless his heart, he is doing his best to become a minister, which is like getting on the Titanic, but that is his problembringing on a private member's bill which will be debated in this House on 2 April, the day after April Fools' Day, which is probably the appropriate day for it to come on. He is going to have us debate a private member's motion, which the government are going to support, which will destroy the intergovernmental agreement on the GST, the jewel in the crown for this government—the biggest and bestest thing they have ever done is foist the GST on us. In about four weeks time they are going to come in here like lemmings and vote to put a big hole in the federalism agreement—an agreement that the Prime Minister signed up to and told us was the best thing he had ever done. In four weeks time, `as sure as night follows day,' to quote one of his colleagues, the government will be in here voting for the private member's bill put forward by the member for La Trobe to do in one of the central points of the intergovernmental agreement.

This is a government out of control; this is a government that has lost the plot. This is a government that thinks that the smart political thing in Sydney is to turn Bankstown into an overflow airport. What is this all about? It is all about trying to save the poor old member for Lindsay. Nothing will save the member for Lindsay. I do not think her staff members will save her, but that is a matter for her and the police. With this Sydney airport stuff the government is trying to solve a problem for a minister whose staff are being investigated by the police. That is where we are. The people of inner and south-western Sydney are being put to the sword and they are having an international airport with no relief foisted upon them by a government that wants to save a minister who has a police inquiry going on into corrupt electoral tactics in a local government electorate where she was the campaign director. This is why it is about to rort the whole system of aircraft arrangements in Australia—to save the member for Lindsay. Nothing will save her. I do not know why the people of my electorate, the people of the good member for Lowe's electorate, the people of the good member for Barton's electorate and the people of the good member for Sydney's electorate should have to put up with this scandal and disgrace to save the member for Lindsay—the Prime Minister's pet—who is being investigated by the police. But it is going to do all that and those good people who live in inner western Sydney and inner south-western Sydney will suffer, and Bankstown is the answer. Only a government that is in policy turmoil and out of its mind—

talk.start.para: —In its death throes.

—Yes, only a government in its death throes would think that Bankstown is the answer. It is not, it never will be, and the minister who has brought this crummy piece of legislation in here tonight to try to fix up a whole lot of money that he has wasted will find that out when he loses his seat at the next election. This will be the first Deputy Prime Minister of this country who has lost his seat for being stupid—and that is his problem. (Time expired)

—As the previous speaker, my friend and colleague the member for Watson, indicated in supporting the amendment, the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001 indicates that the government are indeed in turmoil and that our role here as parliamentarians is to try to get this Minister for Transport and Regional Services out of the mess that he is in as effectively the government have been unlawfully taking money from air travellers under the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act. Why have they been unlawfully taking it? Because they have not bothered to certify, for the purposes of the act, that Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is a noise affected airport. As one who represents the electorate of Barton, which abuts the south-western perimeter of the airport, I can certainly tell you that Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is indeed a noise affected airport. Indeed residents living in the suburbs in my electorate, including Arncliffe, Rockdale, Banksia, Bexley and Carlton, extending into Kogarah and Hurstville, could all definitely confirm the chronic suffering of their families as a result of this government's policies on the operation of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

speech.para: The noise levy is necessary and the opposition will be supporting this legislation to fix up the government's errors because, under this government's policies, the levy is the only protection that some families in my electorate have. They are the families living virtually directly under the flight paths, a very short distance from the end of the east-west runway. Other areas, although they are certainly within the noise imprint given off by these planes, are missing out. There are all kinds of anomalies in this noise insulation program that I must put on the record. For instance, in my electorate there are areas where homes on one side of the street are insulated but those on the other side are not. In one area, Firmstone Gardens, which is literally a stone's throw away from the end of the east-west runway, residents are missing out on insulation because the area is not directly under where the planes are taking off. The ANEF measure, a noise forecasting measure used by this government, has just not taken into consideration the fact that the land that comes off the east-west runway in my electorate rises rapidly. Planes certainly rise after taking off from the airport, but so does the land, yet that is not taken into consideration in the calculation of the effect on those homes which are chronically affected by aircraft noise.

Why do I blame the Howard government for families in my electorate being affected by aircraft noise? It is simple: one of their first acts when they came to government in March 1996 was to reopen the east-west runway for the purpose of implementing what they called a policy of `noise sharing'. As for this policy of noise sharing, when I wrote to both the minister for transport at the time, John Sharp, and the minister for the environment seeking their formal reasons for reopening the east-west runway, I got a frank reply in the minister for transport's letter that the reopening of the runway was for reasons that were `essentially political in nature'. The reasons which were essentially political in nature were, to use the government spin, to implement noise sharing in and around the environs of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. But when you look at the facts—and we have now had five years of facts—you can see a different story.

This government has not got a lot to mark up as an achievement on its record—and certainly the GST is an achievement that the Australian people would rather not have—but it has created a geographical marvel. It has constructed a giant `mountain' that exists in the Prime Minister's electorate of Bennelong and that draws in quite a substantial part of the electorates of Bradfield and North Sydney. Planes cannot fly through this `mountain'. They are flying everywhere else in Sydney other than through `Mount Bennelong'. That is the protection that has been given to the Prime Minister's electorate. It is certainly not an exaggeration to say that that has been the effect of this government's policy, particularly during the most distressing times of the day when residents in my electorate are being affected. To explain just how that is occurring, it is necessary to explain for people who may not be familiar with Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport how the runway configuration operates. It has two major runways which are parallel, running north and south, and the runway which affects my electorate crosses those two runways; obviously, the east-west runway runs across those two runways.

So, just as having an intersection on a major highway causes hazards, a runway running across two major parallel runways must obviously present risks. When you have jumbo jets carrying about 162 tons of fuel for their longer flights—you cannot put up traffic lights; you certainly cannot put in a roundabout—if an error occurs at that intersection, if planes or, indeed, other vehicles intersect at that point, obviously you have a potential disaster on your hands. You cannot have the two major parallel runways—which obviously carry more aircraft than a single runway—in operation with a crossing runway during peak hours. This tends to occur, as you expect, when businesspeople are flying into Sydney for appointments, in the morning between about 7.30 and 9 o'clock and then again in the afternoon between about 4 o'clock and 7 o'clock when they are flying back out of Sydney airport. This means that the crossing runway mode of operation cannot be used during those busy times.

Why is that relevant to families living in my area? Because it has meant that the government, in its obsession to reach the target under the long-term operating plan—if you look at a map of the airport with the figures from the long-term operating plan, you can see that the government's target in my electorate is to have 15 per cent of all aircraft movements—has to fly planes over the homes of the families in my electorate at the less busy times. But those times tend to be the most distressing times for families: late at night between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock and first thing in the morning between 6 o'clock and 7 o'clock. It is at these times—and virtually all day at weekends—that families cop it in my electorate. They tend to be the less busy times. When there is an opportunity to fly a plane out over the homes in my electorate, the direction of this long-term operating plan is to do so. This is having a devastating effect on the quality of life of families in my electorate.

I might say for the record—and I wish that the bureaucrats in AirServices Australia would acknowledge this point—that what is happening is contrary to a motion I moved at the Sydney Airport Community Forum that, if one suburb suffers aircraft noise late at night, it should be relieved of that noise first thing the following morning. People who do not live in that area of Sydney will say that this is all a bit limited in its impact. It is not. As the father of four children, I know how hard it is to get children into bed of a night, let alone get them to sleep. If you are trying to get kids into bed at night, you cannot get them to sleep if planes are flying over until 11 p.m. And when I say `flying over', I have visited homes in and around the airport at that time and it is like standing on the edge of an aircraft carrier with planes flying out to battle. Trying to get kids into bed between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock at night is just an impossibility. You do not need an alarm at 6 o'clock the following morning because you will be woken by a jumbo over the top of you. That is chronically distressing. The number of complaints I have had from mothers saying that their children's school work is being affected is terribly distressing and upsetting, and I think that fair-minded Australians would be saying that that just should not go on.

I notice that today's Daily Telegraph and Sydney Morning Herald contained articles saying it has been demonstrated that sleep deprivation in children is manifesting itself in symptoms which are consistent with attention deficit disorder—an inability to concentrate and erratic moods. I would like a study to be done, quite frankly, on the children living in my area and the extent to which they are suffering from these traits because of the effect of aircraft noise. I am also receiving numerous reports of people suffering stress related illnesses—hypertension, heart complaints and, generally, anxiety and depression—because of this chronic sleep deprivation. It is really outrageous that it is being allowed to continue and that it is not being recognised by the bureaucrats.

I spoke earlier of the obsession of flying planes over homes rather than over the waters of Botany Bay. It is an obsession and there is no need for it. Even on quiet days, I will be out in the front yard and there will be virtually no wind and, although these planes could be flying out over the waters of Botany Bay, they are flying over our homes! Again, this is the period at the weekend when the airport is less busy and the east-west runway could be used. These are the sorts of times these planes are flying over homes when they could be flying out over the waters of Botany Bay.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I will give you some figures on that. In 1995 under the Labor government, only 29 per cent of aircraft movements were over residences in Sydney. Obviously, 71 per cent were over the waters of Botany Bay. That has now reversed. Now 53 per cent of aircraft movements from Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport are over homes and 47 per cent—less than half—are out over the waters of Botany Bay. That clearly could be turned around. Those figures could be dramatically increased. The number of overflights over water could be dramatically increased tomorrow, but the bureaucrats are saying, `If we do that, we are not going to be able to report to the government that we have achieved the targets of the long-term operating plan.' How stupid can you get? How lacking in commonsense can you get when planes carrying 162 tonnes of fuel are flying over homes instead of over the waters of Botany Bay? It is just completely ludicrous!

Why do I say that they are being obsessed? They are being obsessed to the point where they are taking risks. To fly planes off the east-west runway, they have been compromising the crosswind and downwind component. They increased that component to a 25-knot crosswind and a five-knot downwind, despite the fact that the international standard is a 15-knot crosswind. This raised all kinds of concerns and has been doing so for several years. Towards the middle of last year the media reported on these concerns, and I will read some of the quotes. The Sydney Morning Herald of 26 June 2000 reads:

quote.para: Sydney's aircraft noise-sharing plan is under threat of collapse in the wake of claims by international pilots that the use of the east-west runway should be curtailed because of potentially dangerous crosswinds.

speech.para: The Australian of 27 June reported:

quote.para: Qantas pilots accused aviation authorities yesterday of putting residents' concern about noise ahead of safety by forcing aircraft to use Sydney airport's east-west runway in potentially dangerous situations.

speech.para: We had, for instance, the Sydney Morning Herald quoting a David Lidbetter who expressed his concerns that the government would even listen to the pilots' safety concerns because he was worried about planes flying over his North Shore home. They are the people the government is listening to, not the pilots and certainly not the residents in my electorate who are having planes flying over their homes instead of Botany Bay. As the Australian and International Pilots Association said:

quote.para: ... safety must never become second to aircraft noise considerations. At present, noise considerations have taken over flight safety at Sydney airport.

speech.para: That is an objective, expert body entrusted with the responsibility of ensuring the safety of not only aircraft travellers but also the people on the ground. The government has been ignoring them literally until it hit the fan. The pilots concerns are justified.

If anyone is interested, in a reply to a question I asked on notice, Question No. 1743, the minister frankly gave incidents of aircraft accidents that had occurred around the world in crosswinds. These included one in Seoul, South Korea, when a Boeing 747 aircraft ran off a runway when landing at Seoul in crosswinds of 25 knots. There were incidents in Hong Kong and in Christchurch, and I recall the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation also reported an incident in Scandinavia. These concerns were not fabrications or pilots being too anxious; they were actual incidents that their colleagues had experienced and they were reporting to the government. They had been doing it for a number of years. Yet what was the government's response? On 15 August 2000—I commented a couple of weeks ago in another speech I made in the chamber that the government's answer to a question on notice demonstrates collusion between the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia—the minister replied that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, after reviewing a recommendation by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, `concluded that routinely operating runways with up to 25 knots of crosswind does not pose an unacceptable safety hazard'.

What did the pilots do? They marked Sydney airport with a spot designating to the international travelling public that it is an unsafe airport. The government eventually succumbed to that international recognition of the unsafeness of their long-term operating plan and reduced the crosswind component to 20 knots. But it is still five knots higher than the international standards. As someone who enjoys sailing on Botany Bay, I can tell you that, if you have a wind in Botany Bay of 20 knots, you have a very strong wind. To land planes carrying the travelling public at 20 knots of crosswind is still totally unacceptable but will continue because of this government's obsession with their long-term operating plan. The plan itself involving crossing runways has been the subject of criticism. The government use terms such as `complexity' in their spin, as is the case in the answer to question No. 1164 when I questioned about the use of mode 8, which is this particularly complex crossing runway mode of operation. The government said, `We have attempted to mitigate the identified complexities but use of these techniques is expected to result in a lower capacity for mode 8.' In other words, they are saying, `There are some problems here. We had better slow this down because of the complexities.' Those complexities are safety considerations.

Why is it a concern? Because most traffic aircraft accidents occur within eight kilometres of an airport. If they are flying out over the waters of Botany Bay with 162 tonnes of fuel on board—virtually a mini oil refinery—obviously there is going to be less loss of life. But the government is obsessed, as I have demonstrated with the figures earlier, with achieving these stupid, meaningless targets instead of flying planes over the waters of Botany Bay. There have been a number of incidents at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. Indeed, I have received a reply from the government to my questions on notice that there have been a number of accidents. Fortunately, the three major ones in the last 40 years have all crashed into Botany Bay but, if this long-term operating plan had been operating, they would have come down on homes. What I am putting to those representatives of the government, including Airservices Australia, is that if they continue with this reckless indifference of the safety of ordinary Australians, including those in my electorate, they are going to have to answer personally for a disaster. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to support the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001. Since being elected by the people of Swan, I have spent considerable time dealing with issues concerning the Perth Airport. Members might recall my statements in this House pertaining to the difficulties experienced by my constituents affected by aircraft noise and, more recently, the issue of staffing levels and relocation of services to Melbourne. This bill is aimed at retrospectively validating an aircraft levy worth around $175 million a year collected from jet aircraft operators at Sydney airport, in light of the discovery of a fundamental flaw in administration of the scheme since 1996.

speech.para: The principal legislation—the Aircraft Noise Levy Act 1995—empowers the minister to declare that a qualifying airport; that, is one where nearby buildings are forecast to suffer from noise that exceeds nominated levels and where the Commonwealth is funding a noise amelioration program, can be classified as a leviable airport. This would enable the Commonwealth to charge a levy that must be struck in a way to coincide with the amount expended on the noise amelioration program. This analysis would ensure that there is not an unfair burden placed on one leviable airport over another as outlined in the Bills Digest.

Presently this scheme only operates in Sydney, although invalidly, which is the reason for this amendment. In the May budget it was announced that the Commonwealth would fund a noise amelioration program for Adelaide for the purpose of funding the insulation of residences and public buildings in the areas of high aircraft noise surrounding Adelaide Airport. I strongly support the proposal for Adelaide and I will be seeking that Perth be considered as a further leviable airport. I intend to strongly lobby my party and the government to ensure that this occurs. Some members will be familiar with Perth Airport. It is, of course, the central hub of the aviation industry in Perth. It is located only 12 kilometres from the city centre. It is also a considerable component of the total landmass of the electorate of Swan, comprising a site of 2,105 hectares. The communities of South Guildford, Cannington, Queen's Park and Belmont have actively lobbied my office and their local government representatives with respect to the noise problem.

The aircraft noise levy, as it operates in Sydney, funds the airport noise amelioration program. According to the Assistant Treasurer, the levy had raised $197 million as of 31 January 2001 and program expenditure has reached $347 million. This has enabled over 3,300 homes and over 80 public buildings to be noise insulated, as outlined in the Digest. This would be of enormous benefit to the constituents of Swan and would assist them to minimise the health impacts of aircraft noise as identified by the House of Representatives select committee in September 1985—conditions such as sleep deprivation, cardiovascular disease and impairments to learning ability for children and adults.

There appear to be two requirements before an airport is considered to be appropriate for this legislation. First, it must be viewed as a `qualifying airport'. This involves meeting the technical requirements of the legislation. The second aspect seems to be a political one. It appears, from my observation of the legislation and the way it has been put into practice by the current minister, that the political concerns seem to far outweigh the technical requirements. In order to meet the technical requirements, the airport must be shown to have a significant number of public buildings and residences close to the airport that are directly affected by noise.

I believe that Perth meets these requirements as there are approximately 10,000 residents who live along these flight corridors, and a large number of adjoining suburbs such as Belmont that have busy business and commercial areas. Both aspects of the community have loudly expressed their dissatisfaction about the noise issue in general. There have also been a lot of comments about the way in which noise is measured. Currently there is the ANEF rating, which looks at people's perception of noise. It is calculated to an average, which sets certain limits. From discussing this way of calculating the problem and its impact on people in the community, what I have found is that it does not accurately measure its impact on surrounding residents. I take Belmont as an example.

There are suburbs in Belmont that are very close to one of the runways which is not used that often. In this area houses are located some 300 metres from the end of the runway. Whilst only two per cent of take-offs and landings occur in this direction, when that does occur the noise level for those people is horrific. Under the current ANEF levels, they are not eligible for any compensation, or even assessment, because it is calculated over a wide period. Therefore, they do not qualify. Certainly, if you are in these people's yards or even in their houses when a large aircraft is either landing or taking off in a strong easterly wind you know that the house shakes, the windows shake and they cannot hear themselves talk or think. The impact is very dramatic. I find it highly unfair that these people will not even be considered for any form of program because they do not qualify under the current arrangements.

Another recent example of aircraft noise affecting local residents in the electorate was most clearly demonstrated at the Queen's Park Primary School. Queen's Park would be eligible for consideration because it is at the end of the main runway in Perth. Recently I attended the school early in the morning to do some presentations for an assembly. The assembly was held outside. The young people were getting their awards and, every time an aircraft flew overhead, which was probably every two to three minutes, all activity at the school had to cease. The young people could not hear what was being said. They had no idea what I was saying, which was either a good or a bad thing, depending on which way you look at it. But I can imagine that had they been in their classroom and not at an outdoor assembly they would have had the same problem. The principal told me that this occurs on a regular basis, almost daily.

I believe this is totally unacceptable. If we have a mechanism where we can fund a program that provides insulation, double glazing and possibly airconditioning for those classrooms, surely these people deserve that consideration. I have also been approached about the possibility of a school being located close to Canberra Airport. We are very concerned that similar issues could affect these people. When you are dealing with children, obviously it is an extremely important issue and one that should not be ignored. We definitely need to have something that can address the issue. If a levy can provide insulation and other noise amelioration measures we certainly need to implement it.

The residents of Queen's Park and other areas have organised a number of events that I have attended. I have supplemented these meetings by continuing to lobby on their behalf, raising the issue in parliament and at a local level by assisting in the information flow, detailing possible action and developing responses. I can report to the House that at the numerous meetings in the community, in excess of 400 people came along to each separate meeting raising their concerns. Those of us that organise public meetings know that, if you are getting 400 people out at night to raise concerns about a particular issue, the issue really affects the wider community and is something that needs to be considered.

My office has also received over 13,000 signatures on petitions where people have been concerned about the issue of airport noise. We have also received hundreds of phone calls, faxes and visits by concerned residents. We also arranged a meeting with the minister and local government representatives to discuss the issue when the airport corporation was considering its master plan. The local representatives concerned came from the city of Canning and made a special flight to Canberra so that they could put their case to the government. At the meeting the mayor and the chief executive of the city said, `We really need to consider this whole issue of airport noise and what action will be taken to address this in the future.' They walked away from that meeting very disappointed. At the time they thought that their concerns were being heard and that the minister was going to act. Unfortunately, the minister did nothing and they were extremely disappointed. I can appreciate the frustration they walked away from this place with, given that no action was taken to address their concerns.

Another initiative that took place was the establishment of a noise committee at Perth airport as part of the overall program of the master plan. Unfortunately, that committee had no local representation. So, in order to make that happen, we lobbied the Westralia Airports Corporation—and they, not the minister, agreed that local representation should take place. In light of that response, I consider that Perth certainly meets the first aspect of the technical requirement in order to be considered as a qualifying airport for the aircraft noise levy collection. However, it is the second aspect of this technical requirement that my electorate of Swan fails to meet. To be selected by this government is a political decision which, it appears, will not be made for Perth.

Let us consider this fact: the Adelaide airport is located in the seat of Hindmarsh, which is held by the Hon. Christine Gallus. Hindmarsh is a marginal Liberal seat and, therefore, one that would lead the government to consider it worthy of classification as a qualifying airport. I find it rather interesting that Hindmarsh will be considered as a qualifying airport on some of the technical issues. Any of us who have flown into Adelaide know that that airport has problems. I am concerned that the selection of airports tends to be made as a political decision to sort out marginal Liberal seats. The electorate of Swan is not a marginal Liberal seat; it is a marginal Labor seat, and it is getting nothing. I believe that the basis of the government's selection needs to change. This is typical pork-barrelling by the government, and the electorate is waiting. The government have now introduced this legislation saying, `Let us deal with this; let us provide Hindmarsh with a few bucks to help sort out its aircraft noise problem.' Why? Because there is a threat that, in the coming election, they are going to lose. So the government says, `We had better throw a few bucks at Hindmarsh to help them out, but we will not worry about the poor people of Swan.' It reminds me a little of the Ryan by-election and the fuel issue where they thought, `Whoa! We have a problem here. We could lose Ryan. What are we going to do? Let us make sure that we provide the people with a 1½c a litre reduction in their excise to help pork-barrel them a bit to try to convince them that they should vote for us.' I believe that this sort of pork-barrelling is unacceptable. Where there is a problem, we need to address it. Certainly Perth has a problem, and we need to address it.

A further deterrent for the government will be the political pressure that will be applied by aircraft operators who will be forced to increase fees once they are obliged to pay the levy. The government needs to be strong and show its commitment to the people rather than its obsession with helping big business at the community's expense. The increase in populations around airports in Australia means that the government must take action and consider many airports as qualifying airports—and this should be regardless of the state's governing party or the political persuasion of the sitting member. Perth airport will continue to be a busy entrance to the nation. This can be seen in the latest data from Westralia Airports Corporation. Relevant documentation associated with the master plan in Perth states that, as flight frequency increases, approximately a further 10,000 local residents will be affected in the coming years. We have all read about the new super jumbos which are being considered for construction; in fact, I think Qantas has a number on order. These aircraft will revolutionise the way people are transported within Australia and the world community. One of the problems I have seen with these aircraft is that they need to have a hub from which they can operate. That hub in Australia may in fact become Perth, because from Perth they can fly non-stop direct to Europe and other areas.

talk.start.para: —That might be wishful thinking.

—The honourable member opposite suggests that it might be wishful thinking. I do not believe so. I think Perth is the central hub of the world. Certainly, anyone coming to Western Australia will not be disappointed. I will be looking forward to that occurring in the future. But if the airport is upgraded further and Perth does become a major hub for international travellers to and from Australia, as should be the case, then clearly we will have an ongoing problem, and the time to address that ongoing problem is now and not five or 10 years down the track when we start to have even bigger problems than the ones we have already got. The time to act is now. We need to plan for the protection, the prevention of discomfort and the good health of those residents located close to our airports, particularly Perth. We must ensure that local schools and child-care centres are not exposed to the ills that have been well documented to occur as a result of aircraft noise. We must be responsible and ensure that aircraft operators are also responsible for the effects that their industry imposes upon the communities in which they make their profits. Finally, I call on the minister for transport to look specifically at Perth and to take the appropriate action to commence its classification as a qualifying airport for the purposes of this legislation. This is a minister who is more concerned with keeping the mud off his gumboots than caring for ordinary Australians. It is time he started caring for the ordinary Perth folk who need his assistance. I commend the bill to the House and look forward to Perth being included in the program.

—I wish to speak in support of the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001. However, I express some astonishment that the bill is necessary. The bill, of course, is necessary because of the incompetence of the current Minister for Transport and Regional Services and his predecessors, who have failed to include Sydney airport in the leviable airport legislation since 30 June 1996. No wonder the government has absolutely no direction on Sydney airport policy when it cannot get simple administration right.

speech.para: For the people of Grayndler, the electorate that I am proud to represent, this is a mixed issue. On the one hand, many people in Grayndler would not want to see compensation and noise amelioration to be necessary; they would rather see the planes simply disappear and Kingsford Smith airport closed. But I understand, and I think a majority of my electorate understand, that Sydney airport has a very important role to play in Australia's economic development and prosperity and for jobs for the people of Sydney, New South Wales and Australia.

If that airport is to continue, the people around the airport deserve proper protection and proper compensation. The noise amelioration program was implemented in late 1994 essentially due to what I still hold to be the disastrous and incorrect decision to build the third runway at Kingsford Smith airport. It consisted of the voluntary acquisition of 151 houses and the Coptic church in Railway Road, Sydenham, which are within the 40 ANEF zone. When the noise was at that level, the houses simply shook and were ready to fall down due to the aircraft noise rather than requiring any voluntary decisions. The program also allows for the insulation of houses within the 30 ANEF zone and the insulation of public buildings within the 25 ANEF zone. That was paid for by the levy under the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Act 1995.

The original program included 17 schools, 21 child-care centres, seven nursing homes, 23 churches and two hospitals. The changes which occurred after this mean-spirited government was elected wound back the insulation program. The boundaries for residents were cut back to Stanmore Road in my electorate and some 2,500 people missed out at that time. The boundaries then had to be expanded in May 1999 in the budget when the government considered the Australian noise exposure indicator and the impact that was placing on residents at that time.

At that time, the expansion—the difference between the noise exposure indicator and the forecast—was the difference between practice and theory. That is one of the things I want to talk about tonight. The practical impact of aircraft noise on the people in the communities that I represent is much greater than suggested by the theoreticians, the forecasters who sit comfortably in offices in Canberra. The current situation is that, as a result of that expansion, 147 residences were acquired in Sydenham. The government provided some funding for Sydenham Green, an area of open space which was launched by me as the local member; the Mayor of Marrickville, Barry Cotter; and the then minister for transport, the member for Lyne. That was a very good project and I give credit to the member for Lyne for being prepared while he was the minister to come down and visit Sydenham, visit the people in my electorate, on more than one occasion. That is more than his predecessor, John Sharp did—he ranked zero—or the current minister, the Deputy Prime Minister, who is also on zero in terms of visiting the people who are most affected by aircraft noise.

The Coptic church in Railway Road has been successfully relocated to Bexley. I was pleased just some three weeks ago to attend the opening ceremony and luncheon held at the Coptic church and the Egyptian community. It is hoped that one level of the former Coptic church—the first in the Southern Hemisphere—will be converted into a museum of Egyptian history, in particular Coptic history, in Sydenham and that the remainder of the facilities will become available to the community to use as a centre for community activities.

The insulation of 25 schools has been completed; 28 child-care centres have been completed; and a residential area of some 4,300 residences is now eligible for insulation, of which 3,100 are in my electorate. Unfortunately for the people in my electorate, who have always suffered more than any others with regard to aircraft noise, they were the guinea pigs for this project. Much of the SANIP was new ground. Some 1,100 properties had wool ceiling insulation put in them, which was essentially a fire hazard and needed to be replaced, leading to a blow-out in the costs of the program. Much of the air conditioning, particularly that of companies such as Coral, simply does not work. All it does is lead to increased electricity costs for the residents, with little benefit.

Many other residents, due to the fact that bureaucrats have placed lines on maps as to who is affected and who is not, have simply missed out—because they are on the wrong side of the road; some even when they are next to people who do comply with the guidelines for insulation. A practical example is Patricia Campbell, who lives in Tempe in my electorate, less than one kilometre from the runway of Kingsford Smith airport—not from the terminals at Kingsford Smith but from the runway. That is less than 1,000 metres. Given that a runway is four kilometres long, people should understand exactly how small that distance is. Yet this government says that her residence falls outside the contour for noise insulation.

Patricia spends her days at home as a full-time carer for her aged mother who needs constant care. She is literally bombarded by aircraft noise from the time she is woken up by the planes to the time that she goes to bed—seven days a week, 12 months of the year. This has brought her to a situation where she has made representations to the minister that she is on the verge of a nervous breakdown. I urge the government to show a bit of compassion with regard to people such as Patricia.

Total expenditure on the insulation project is some $346.6 million as at 31 January, of which $196.8 million has been raised. It is my view that if the levy has to be raised under the user-pays principle or if it has to be extended out in its application—this legislation extends it to 30 June 2006—then so be it. If you are going to subject people to this terror of noise, then give them proper compensation.

I wish to raise the issue of Sydenham and the small businesses in the community there. There were 151 houses available for acquisition, of which 147 people agreed. There were 17 small businesses along Unwins Bridge Road in Sydenham prior to this decision. There are now four and those four are losing money. If you take away an entire suburb and demolish it, it is not surprising that the local paper shop closes, the corner shop closes, the milk bar closes and the liquor store closes, because there is no-one there to buy the products. These people—good hardworking Australians—many of whom are migrants, mainly of Greek background, who came out in the postwar period, do not get one cent of compensation under this legislation. Most of them live above the shop where they service their community but, because it is a retail outlet, they are not entitled to compensation. SACF and the minister opposite have met these people and I believe were sympathetic to their plight. SACF carried resolutions unanimously. SACF former chairman Joe Hockey supported them, and Brendan Nelson supported them, but there is not one cent of compensation to these small business people.

The next issue I wish to raise also applies to the battlers in that Sydenham-St Peters-Tempe area, and that is weatherboard houses. There was $15,000 extra given to insulate weatherboard houses in the 1999 budget on top of the $50,000 which is available to other residents. But you simply cannot properly insulate houses in the above 30 ANEF zone where noise is—if you will excuse the term, Mr Deputy Speaker—bloody loud all day. You cannot insulate weatherboard houses properly; you cannot treat the houses properly. Those people should be subject to a similar scheme which was put and supported by SACF to previous transport ministers whereby the houses would be acquired, people compensated, brick houses or houses that can be insulated built in their place and on-sold. It would be at very little cost to the government but would be a sign of real compassion and social justice. But these people just keep copping it.

My electorate of Grayndler is one in which 43.5 per cent of the population were born overseas—the fifth highest rate in the country. The vast majority of these people come from non-English speaking backgrounds, 11 per cent of the electorate do not speak English fluently and nearly half the people in the electorate speak a language other than English at home. Of these dwellings, 41 per cent are rented—the eighth highest rate in Australia, yet my electorate has to cop being told, `They're just inner-city people. They're affluent in the inner city.' I did not get 72 per cent of the vote at the last election because there are a whole lot of millionaires in my electorate. Housing prices in Sydenham, Tempe and Marrickville are still cheaper than most places in Sydney. You have communities and families, first generation from overseas, crammed into inadequate quarters. They are real battlers who deserve the support of the Australian Labor Party and deserve the support of the Australian community. At the same time, this week they cop from the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales comments that you cannot go into Marrickville without being at risk of being shot. So they cop it both ways. On the one hand, they are affluent and we do not have to worry about them; on the other hand, they are the underclass who can be dismissed from the other perspective. The reality is that they are just decent hardworking, working-class Australians.

I want to talk about schools. Since the spreading of the noise, there is a very clear case that schools such as Marrickville High School, Dulwich High and Fort Street High—to name just three—deserve insulation. I want to use Fort Street High School as an example because it is the oldest state high school in New South Wales, having been established in 1849. It is on a hill in Petersham, some 50 metres from the 25 ANEF zone. Tavaners Hill Public School, which you could hit with a tennis ball thrown from the grounds of Fort Street High, has been insulated, but Fort Street High gets nothing. Fort Street High is a heritage school. The building was constructed in 1914, and the hall was constructed in 1927. It is not surprising that the noise just filters straight through into that school. Noise measurements have recorded levels above 65 decibels every single day. That is an important figure because it is the figure that was used for schools in the Badgerys Creek EIS. The education of these children is suffering every day. They cannot go through a one-hour lesson without it being interrupted. They cannot study for their HSC without being interrupted—every day! It is not just some days; it is every single day. They deserve proper compensation.

If you compare it with Newington College up the road—one of the favoured schools of those opposite—you see that $18.8 million was spent on insulation and airconditioning there. I do not begrudge them that, because they are entitled to insulation. Every student is entitled to learn without their education being prejudiced. But let us be fair dinkum: just because those students are affluent does not mean that they deserve better than those students attending government schools like Marrickville High, Dulwich High, Fort Street High and other schools that are right under the flight path. We need to be consistent on this issue. The principal of Fort Street, Ms Ros Moxham, wrote to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services asking for assistance. She outlined their case—and what was the minister's response? Nothing. He got a staff member to send off a form letter basically saying, `Thanks for your correspondence—bad luck.' It is simply not good enough. Those students will campaign, and I will be with them, as their local member, in order to get justice.

I want to conclude my contribution to tonight's debate by speaking about the issue of privatisation. Section 18 of the Airports Bill 1996 clearly states that the sales of Sydney airport and Sydney West airport must be to the same owner, and the government's policy is that it can be done only once the aircraft noise problems of Sydney airport are solved. I would much rather that the problems of Sydney aircraft noise were solved than that we talked about how to compensate for the problems. It is always better to fix the problems than to provide compensation. This government's policy of having a second Sydney airport—make no mistake: there will be a second Sydney airport—is that it should be in Bankstown. So we will have one of these two airports in the inner west of Sydney and one in Bankstown, in the south-west of Sydney—the first and second most densely populated areas in Australia, not just in Sydney. It is an absolutely outrageous, obscene abuse of the government's own commitments and a betrayal of its responsibilities as a government to represent all Australians. The Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001 is necessary because of the government's incompetence in failing to fix the noise problem at Sydney airport, and it is consistent with its incompetent policy with regard to Sydney airport in general. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I join the member for Grayndler and, previously, the members for Watson and for Wills in condemning this government's administrative failure—not the administrative failure of the federal government bureaucracy but the administrative failure of this government yet again. Mr Deputy Speaker, you have seen the government's administrative failures time and again, as I have. But tonight we face, in the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Amendment Bill 2001, an attempt to retrospectively legislate for something that the government did not do correctly in 1996. So far, about $175 million has been garnered from passengers of jet aircraft at Sydney airport paying the aircraft noise levy. Up until now, Sydney airport was the only airport where that noise levy operated. However, the government has determined that there should be a noise levy collection in a second airport, Adelaide airport.

speech.para: As you well know, Mr Deputy Speaker, aircraft of the class of 737s are to be placed into Bankstown airport as a result of the Prime Minister, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and their cabinet determining in the middle of December that Bankstown airport should become the effective fourth runway, the replacement east-west runway for Kingsford Smith airport, and that there should be another leviable airport—that is, Bankstown. I, as the member for Blaxland, represent the people of Bankstown, and I represent the 6,000 to 10,000 local people who turned up on Sunday, 11 February at the trotting grounds at Bankstown to protest against the government's decision to belt the daylights out of the people of Bankstown by turning their airport into an airport for jets. Whether it be purely as a domestic jet airport or as an international jet airport, this is a crazy decision, a quite insane decision by this government.

They have already raised $175 million of a total of about $374 million that is projected to be needed in relation to Sydney airport. Instead of making a sensible decision about a second airport for Sydney, they are determined to make the people of Bankstown suffer for their great sins in voting Labor since 1949, since the electorate of Blaxland was incorporated, and prior to that. In this great year of the Centenary of Federation, it is fitting to remember that, since 1901, the people of Bankstown have voted Labor, L-a-b-o-r—that is, for one century. Because of that, this government has determined to belt the daylights out of them by turning Bankstown into Sydney's second airport. They therefore will have to bring another bill into this House to determine that Bankstown is a leviable airport. I will fight the expansion of Bankstown airport and its extension into areas beyond those of a general aviation airport. It is a deliberate act to change the current nature of the airport and to change it from what it has been since the 1940s into the effective east-west runway of Kingsford Smith airport. This is a crazy, stupid, dumb, ridiculous decision by a government that should know better.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

subdebateinfo.title: Lalor Electorate: The Women of Wyndham

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, as I am sure you are aware, this is the week in which we celebrate International Women's Day. I rise tonight to draw the attention of honourable members to a major event in my electorate on Friday night on the theme of celebrating the contribution of women in the community—that is, the opening of an art exhibition entitled The Women of Wyndham. It has been my very great honour to be invited to open that art exhibition at our Werribee South Art Gallery. The artist is a local woman called Kathy Vafiadis, a well-known local identity who has contributed to the community through her art and community activism. She works in a variety of mediums, including paint, pastel, watercolour and on a variety of three-dimensional surfaces, and is particularly interested in the image of the female as an icon. It is following that particular interest that she has put together this art exhibition which includes 15 portraits of women of Wyndham. As the artist is entitled to, Kathy has included her own self-portrait. Among that number—apart from Kathy, a very celebrated local artist—are women community leaders in the city of Wyndham. I am glad to be included as the local federal member on that list. It also includes Pat Goodwin, who was the first female mayor of our city; Karen Roberts, who is currently the only female councillor in the City of Wyndham; and Mary Guilette, the current state Labor representative, who is one of my very great friends and a very great colleague. She will shortly be celebrating her marriage on 17 March—St Patrick's Day, a very important date—and I wish her my best for that.

speech.para: Apart from local women leaders, this art exhibition celebrates the contribution of a number of community activists and local identities. One of them is Jan Goats. Jan had the vision and the passion to launch a brilliant idea in our city, and that was its quality community plan. Jan is celebrated for that community leadership. One of the portraits is of Dawn Hosking. Dawn typifies the spirit that drives our volunteers. She works hard for the Uniting Church and its charities as well as the Werribee scout movement. She is a wonderful mother and wife and contributor to our community. Another portrait is of Rosemary Brown. She gave us our local neighbourhood centre, the Cottage, which is a very important backbone to community life in the city of Wyndham. Her work is celebrated. Among the local identities celebrated is Terri Bracks. Terri's connection with the city of Wyndham is in part as an electorate officer in my electorate office and for a long period of time in the electorate office of the very Hon. Barry Jones before me. She is better known these days as the wife of our Premier and Terri's contribution to the Wyndham community is celebrated through her portrait.

There is a portrait of Heather Marcus, who has for a long time been one of our local traders. She has traded for a very long time on Watton Street, Werribee as a dress shop and each and every year puts a tremendous amount of effort into our local festival, Weerama, most particularly its fashion show. Another portrait is of our very prominent local activist Connie Menegazzo. Connie is a resident at Werribee South and was very prominent in the campaign against the toxic dump which the Jeff Kennett government sought to impose on our community. Joanne Ryan, who is a local teacher, a playwright and also a hero of the toxic dump campaign, is celebrated. Joanne is a very great personal friend of mine and I look forward to seeing her portrait.

These portraits include two others: Sue Anderson, another wonderful artist, and Clare Bannantyne, who is a designer, architect, glass artist, school teacher, horsewoman, circus performer, boat builder, gallery owner, dictionary lover, grandmother, living treasure and the adopted sister of the artist, Kathy Vafiadis. It will be my very great pleasure to attend and launch this very important art exhibition on Friday night. It is very important that we note it in this place tonight.

talk.start.para: —I have recently received information of what apparently is a secret or unpublished 1998 study on the quality management of methadone maintenance treatment programs in New South Wales. The report states that to ensure the desired health and economic benefits of methadone maintenance treatment can be achieved, the program must be capable of demonstrating best practice conditions necessary to obtain these benefits. It says that the priority aim must be to develop an implementation-ready, quality management system. This system must ensure that the direct cost of methadone treatment will be significantly offset by the social, crime and health costs to the community of not providing MMT services.

speech.para: I was appalled to read that the study went on to identify seven critical failure points. They were: (1) the organisation and administration of the program, (2) compliance with stated policies and guidelines, (3) approval of prescribers, (4) the roles and responsibilities of clinics and retail pharmacies, (5) the performance of service providers, (6) education and training of service providers and (7) liaison with communities. To remedy the situation, the report recommended, firstly, that a board with up to nine members and a full-time secretariat of four should be established to take responsibility for the management of the quality of methadone maintenance treatment. It said that the overall function of the board should be to act as an external body for the quality of services delivered by all MMT service providers.

Recommendation 9 called for the licensing of public and private MMT clinics by the board on a triennial basis. The issuing of a licence to a clinic should specify the client volume limits for each clinic. Licences should be issued for a three-year period, but non-accredited clinics should be licensed for a period of one year only. I understand that the New South Wales government's response has been to appoint one internal quality assurance officer. This is hardly an independent board supported by a secretariat.

I understand that methadone maintenance treatment has been around in Australia for about 15 years, and that this question of quality assurance was raised early. Australia ranks second highest in the world both in percentage of the population on methadone and the strength of dose per person. It appears that New South Wales has the highest rate of methadone syrup use in the world. In about 1988 methadone programs and needle and syringe programs were unleashed into Australia big time. They were accompanied by no balanced scientific randomised control study. In its place, success has been judged by how many addicts stay on the treatment, and how long, and the number of needles and syringes distributed. The criterion is the more, and longer, the better. To my knowledge, and that of many other people with detailed knowledge of the matter, there has been no scientific study of the use of this drug and the outcome in terms of rehabilitation. This raises questions about the stewardship of the New South Wales health department. I believe it has been studiously avoided because the outcomes do not justify the inputs, and because there have grown too many vested interests associated with the methadone maintenance treatment.

The New South Wales records are so bad that even deaths on the program are not reported. In 1992, when `takeaways' were first provided, the risk of death through diversion was recognised and, because of that, so was the need to monitor the policy. However, virtually no monitoring was done. It is sad, but I believe it is the case that there are many clear breaches of the rules by pharmacists, and the public interest will not be served until proper independent quality assurance and monitoring are put in place.

With the advent of naltrexone based rehabilitation programs and the high success rates achieved, and the pending use of buprenorphine, judging the methadone maintenance treatment programs by the numbers and the length of time an addict stays on them is obsolete. In fact, it is stupid. There needs to be accurate monitoring of death rates and abstinence rates, and the effects of these programs on the children of patients. I will be writing to the Minister for Health and Aged Care on this matter so that the government may raise these matters with the New South Wales government.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to congratulate the people and groups who received awards in my electorate of Canning on Australia Day. The Citizen of the Year for the shire of Murray was Mary Cleghorn. Mary is the community and child health nurse for the Peel region but is known to the vast majority of the community as `Mary the Clinic Sister'. She has worked in this region for the past 25 years and has worked tirelessly, with a dedication rarely seen these days. The Community Event of the Year Award this year went to the Dandalup and Districts Community Association for its holding of a very successful event to celebrate 150 years of settlement for the residents and ex-residents of the North Dandalup district. It was certainly a very enjoyable day.

speech.para: In Waroona, the Young Citizen of the Year was Megan Brown. Megan was recognised for her contributions to the community. She is a straight-A student who was dux of her school in 2000. Five people in Waroona were recognised for their contributions to the community. These were Glad Lane, Lynda Leroy, Charles Maffescioni, Joan Scott and Joan Walsh. The achievements of these people give great hope for the future of our community.

In the shire of Serpentine-Jarrahdale, the Citizen of the Year was Jill Van Der Sanden. Jill is an active member of the Serpentine Parents and Citizens. She joined the PCYC in 1989 and has worked diligently ever since with that group. The Community Event of the Year Award this year was won by the Walking Trails Committee of Jarrahdale Heritage Society. The work of Sheila Twine and her walking group under the Jarrahdale Heritage Society has put the shire on the map as a walk trail destination, and it is one I would recommend to all members if they are looking for an enjoyable time in Western Australia.

In the city of Armadale, Greg Kelly was made Citizen of the Year. Greg is head of the Department of Performing Arts at Armadale Senior High School. He is also president of the Kelmscott Tennis Club and secretary of the Armadale Golf Club. He has had a long association with the area and has worked tirelessly over this time. The Young Citizen of the Year Award was presented to Melissa Northcott. Melissa has cerebral palsy and has vision in only one eye, but this has not prevented her from being an active member of the community. She raises funds for the MS Society, Red Cross, Telethon and the Cerebral Palsy Association and has been actively involved in the Girl Guides, the Red Cross, Police and Citizens and St John Ambulance. I know that when Mr Beazley visited my electorate earlier this year Melissa was responsible for welcoming us to her school. She did a superb job and was a credit to that school.

The Community Event/Organisation of the Year Award went to the Heritage Country Tourism Association. The tourism centre was opened in 1993 and since then has made an outstanding contribution to tourism in our district. They won the Golden 1 award for a record fifth time last year. The City of Armadale High Achievers Award was won by Julie Ferns Pheasant in recognition of her achievement in winning two gold medals at the Abilympics in Prague. Certificates of appreciation for outstanding contribution to the community through volunteering were awarded to Margaret Bettenay, Joan Lewington and Mavis Gamble. A certificate of appreciation for his ongoing contribution to local radio was presented to Royceton Hardy. A certificate for outstanding personal achievement was won by Luke Ellis, who started flying at 10 years of age and was recently accepted for an Ansett scholarship in aviation studies at Melville Senior High School. The Armadale shopping centre was awarded a certificate of appreciation for its willingness to participate in and contribute to the life of the city of Armadale. The Environmental Contribution of the Year Award was won by the Friends of Bob Blackburn Flora Reserve.

In Gosnells, four young women received the Duke of Edinburgh Award. Laura Blackman, Kylie Watson, Katie Hope and Jenny Umfahrer are to be congratulated for their efforts. The Citizen of the Year Award was awarded to Clinton Phillips. Clinton coordinates the recreation network's leisure buddy program, which looks at recreation opportunities, counselling, information and support for people with disabilities. The Young Citizen of the Year was Amit Khaira. Amit is involved with the Thornlie Church of Christ's Youth Ministry. He coordinates the Brotherhood for Life Skate Ministry, which conducts regular sessions for skateboarders, rollerbladers and bike riders. The Thornlie Church of Christ was awarded the Community Service of the Year award for their work with young people in the community. Last but by no means least, the winner of the Year 2000 Constable Peter Ball Memorial Youth Award was won by the Brotherhood for Life Skate Ministry. They have made an outstanding contribution to crime prevention and overcoming antisocial behaviour. All of these people should be proud of the great contribution they have made to the quality of community life in our area.

talk.start.para: —The devastating news that parts of Europe, in particular the United Kingdom, have been infected with the highly contagious foot and mouth disease again highlights the importance of tough quarantine laws in Australia. Foot and mouth disease would have an equally devastating impact on Australia's livestock industry and could potentially cost up to 25,000 jobs. Foot and mouth affects cattle, pigs, sheep and goats and although in adult livestock it is not usually fatal it causes serious production losses and major constraints to trade in any exporting nation unfortunate enough to be exposed. As an island continent, we are indeed in a better position than many countries, and our quarantine system is the envy of the world. However, we cannot underestimate the ease with which this highly contagious disease could very quickly gain a foothold in this country.

speech.para: I understand the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service has temporarily suspended imports of all products from the UK that could constitute a risk of introducing the disease, including dairy products and uncanned meat. Travellers from the UK will be targeted for inspection at airports and more luggage will be X-rayed. I have every confidence that AQIS has employed stringent biosecurity measures and border controls in response to this latest outbreak. What I would like to raise is the fact that there are always unscrupulous people willing to run the risk of breaking our quarantine laws. Where there is a will, they will try. I believe penalties for breaking these laws should be increased significantly in order to act as a more effective deterrent. They are currently hopelessly inadequate. People willing to break quarantine laws often do so in order to gain financial benefit. Imposing a fine like $400 with no imprisonment is hardly likely to deter these people.
