A person was fined $400 for importing green apple snails through the Melbourne International Mail Exchange in a package labelled as video cassettes. These snails are considered a delicacy in Europe but are a serious pest to agriculture, particularly in my state of Western Australia. AQIS's own web site admits that if the snails had not been discovered, they could have caused serious problems for Australia. This person was fined a mere $400.

Another case saw an aquarium owner import 23 exotic fish into Australia that would have caused serious quarantine and environmental risks to the country. The fish, which came from the Amazon rainforest, can fetch around $450 on the black market. The aquarium owner was found guilty and fined $5,000. If he had not been caught, he would have made more than $10,000 through selling the fish, and they are just the ones that were intercepted. I believe we should treat people who intentionally break quarantine laws with the same level of seriousness that we treat drug smugglers.
Government members—Hear! Hear!

talk.start.para: —We recognise that harsh penalties for importers of illicit drugs are warranted because, first, they stand to gain large sums of money if successful and, second, because of the significant damage illicit drugs do to our community. Breaking quarantine laws also has these two considerations. Smugglers often stand to make a fortune if they are not intercepted, while damage to many of our exporting industries and the environment in general could be huge. An outbreak of foot and mouth disease here could cost us $6 billion, and that affects us all. I look forward to helping in the push to make our quarantine laws have more bite and better deter illegal imports and to seeing this issue treated with the level of gravity that it deserves.

—I would like to lodge a strong protest in this parliament tonight about the way the new dairy assistance scheme has worked out, particularly as it relates to farmers and shoppers. This new milk levy being paid by shoppers, which was meant to help farmers, is now going to finish up in the hands of the banks and the tax office. It is clear that the price now paid by people shopping in supermarkets for milk carries an 11c levy. That levy has been put in place by the Howard government, supposedly to assist dairy farmers whose businesses have been hit by the deregulation of the dairy industry. I am sure people in towns like Kyneton, Woodend, Gisborne, Sunbury, Deer Park, Melton and Bacchus Marsh in my electorate have no idea that this levy has been imposed on milk prices. It is a direct charge on consumers. It was supposed to go to farmers who are in trouble because they now receive much less for their milk at the farm gate.

speech.para: That is only the tip of the iceberg. We now find the Howard government has decided these compensation grants to farmers will be counted as income and farmers will have to pay tax on it. That means that 3c of that 11c levy is going from consumers to the tax office. What a rip-off! What should have been a $1.2 billion package is now a $1.6 billion package because $400 million is being transferred to the tax office. What is also making me angry is that many of these farmers who are in trouble are being forced by their banks to hand over their compensation grants to either reduce their overdraft or pay out their mortgage. Again, this is totally unfair to consumers. The milk prices have been loaded up to provide grants which in the end go straight back to the government and the banks—the very same banks that have lifted charges, reduced services and cut jobs in country towns.

I am calling on the Prime Minister to review this whole scheme. I think some of our people in my electorate would accept some of the price of milk going to help out farmers who have been squeezed out of business by changes in the industry. I am not complaining about that. In the past, in my territory, we have had tariffs and grants to help industries—textiles, motor vehicles and manufacturing—when they were opened up to more competition. But it is a totally different matter when consumers' money is going straight to the government coffers via the Taxation Office and to the banks. Shoppers should not be loaded with this. The GST is one thing; this is an entirely different matter. Farmers and consumers are on the wrong side of this equation. Farmers, who are now receiving much less at the farm gate—they were always going to be in that situation—and consumers, who are now paying an 11c levy, have both been suckered—and not just suckered in for a year or so but suckered for the next eight years. That is how long this plan is going to be in action.

I have heard some members of this House say that they are happy for their consumers because, in some cases, milk prices have gone down. They think that is fine. That may be so, but I say to them that those prices should be lower since this levy should never have been 11c but only 8c because the government has chosen to surreptitiously take its tax take out of it and, of course, the banks are in there taking their share. I repeat my call that the Prime Minister be called in—that the members of the National Party and the country members of the Liberal Party get to the Prime Minister right now—to make sure (a) that the tax is dropped and (b) that the farmers get the levy and the consumers get a decent deal. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to extend my remarks from earlier in the week about the lack of understanding on behalf of some of the civic leaders in the areas I represent about the efforts the federal government is taking to tackle the serious concern of drugs in our community. I might start by referring to an information circular being made available by the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia. It says:

quote.para: The Federal Government has over the last three years shown a strong commitment to reducing illicit drug related harm by putting more than $500 million into the National Illicit Drug Strategy.

speech.para: The report goes on to say:

quote.para: No previous government has made such a strong commitment to this issue.

speech.para: That is the context within which I will briefly remind people in my community, particularly the Mayor of the City of Frankston, about some of the measures that have benefited our community. I spoke earlier in the week about some very localised examples of how some of that $500 million is finding its way into our local community and supporting the work of some of the community organisations. Let me just outline where that $500 million is being invested. There are $57 million over four years going to more than 130 non-government treatment programs across Australia for the establishment of new, or the expansion of existing, treatment facilities and services for illicit drug users. Almost $6 million has been allocated to more than 80 projects across the nation to undertake community based prevention initiatives. $7.5 million has been allocated for a range of projects to gather new evidence on and insights into how best to prevent and treat illicit drug problems. They are evaluating some of the pharmacotherapy treatment options—naltrexone, methadone and the like—and also some of the therapeutic communities, an idea that I am particularly interested in where we seek not only to have the person withdrawn from the illicit drug use they have but to have some rehabilitation programs put in place to help develop the life skills and the support mechanisms that that individual needs to cope with modern life, and also to create some new pathways for those people for whom substance abuse is a solution to some problems they have. Unless we tackle the causal issues of those problems in their lives, we get into this revolving door of detoxification.

That leads me to another particular area of concern to me and the local community. In the south-eastern metropolitan area of Melbourne, where I represent the good folk of Dunkley, it is extraordinarily difficult to get into a rehabilitation and detoxification program. We have very few programs available and very few beds available in hospitals in the region—it is like winning Lotto if you can get access to them. We also have a number of home based services. As helpful as those things are, where the program response seems to be deficient is in connecting those detoxification services with rehabilitation programs to tackle those causal factors that I mentioned before and to develop some life skills and some coping mechanisms within the individual so that, once they have gone successfully through a detoxification program, we have the best possible prospect of not having them return to illicit drugs.

I am tired of hearing stories about families in my community where mums have to sit in park chairs in Springvale buying drugs for their loved ones because they are climbing the wall at home, unable to get into a detoxification and rehabilitation program. It is unacceptable that families in my community have to send their young kids—decent kids, good people who have perhaps just lost their way or made one mistake and been hooked on these horrible things that are afflicting our nation and nations around the world—to as far away as Mount Gambier and Canberra to get access to rehabilitation programs. It is just ridiculous. We need to look at the opportunity that exists to draw from that $500 million that is available to try to support the detoxification facilities in my area with proper rehabilitation services available as and when needed.

My final comment relates to the availability of free needles and syringes for people with diabetes. Why is it that the good folk of the ACT, New South Wales and Queensland can get access to free syringes when the good folk of Melbourne cannot? The reason is simple: the state government of Victoria has not met the co-payment cost—which is being met by the other states—which is the amount remaining after the Commonwealth program, the National Diabetic Services Scheme, which already subsidises the cost of insulin syringes, needles for pen injector devices and diagnostic agents for people with disabilities. There is a co-payment, and that co-payment is met by the ACT, New South Wales and Queensland governments to provide assistance to people with diabetes in those states. I am calling on the Victorian government to match the initiatives and the sensible thought that has been provided in these other jurisdictions and give people that suffer from diabetes in Victoria the support that is available to diabetes sufferers in other states.

to move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) expresses its concern over the degrading conditions forced on humanitarian asylum-seekers in Australia's refugee detention centres;

(2) recognises the criticisms made by the Commonwealth Ombudsman in his recent investigation into the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs' Immigration Detention Centres, including a statement that “those detained against their will are entitled to expect that there will be a reasonable standard of care provided for them in terms of accommodation, facilities, security, health, welfare and protection from harm; as well as reasonable timeliness of application and review processes”;

(3) calls on the Government to immediately implement the recommendations of the Ombudsman in his `Investigation into The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs' Immigration Detention Centres', namely recommendations 1 through 9.

(4) calls on the Government to establish more humane alternative measures to mandatory detention of asylum-seekers, including working with ethnic communities and other welfare organisations willing to care for refugees in a much more humanitarian manner.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 4.30 p.m.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Mr Fahey:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr Tanner moved by way of amendment:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns this Government for its:
(1) failure to address the significant investment needs in the areas of education and health and the provision of social and employment services since coming to Government;
(2) blowout in the cost of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and the threat this presents to the sustainability of Australia's subsidised medicines scheme;
(3) belated and inadequate attempts to remedy the chronic underfunding of research and innovation;
(4) mismanagement of the Defence Budget;

(5) refusal to remove the effects of the sale of the rest of Telstra from the Budget aggregates consistent with the resolution of the Senate of 16 March 2000, the findings of the Besley report and the wishes of the leader of the National Party;
(6) mishandling of the move to accrual accounting by providing complex, confusing and uninformative budget documents;
(7) wasteful and profligate spending on poor quality programs to buy Democrat support for its unfair GST;
(8) failure to identify in the Budget papers the full cost of GST collection and implementation;
(9) failure to put in place arrangements that deliver its guarantee that no Australian will be worse off as a result of the GST package; and
(10) bungling of the Business Activity Statement which has sent many small businesses to the wall”.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)—Before the debate is resumed on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2000-01, I remind the Main Committee that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this bill, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2000-01 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2000-01.

—I rise today to speak on a number of matters of government appropriation covered by Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2000-2001 and cognate bills on which I feel, as you might expect, that the opposition would perhaps do a better job. Let me begin with the business activity statement. Last Friday, in my electorate, I witnessed one of the fundamental reasons why the coalition deserves to lose the next federal election resoundingly. I saw the total disillusionment and disenfranchisement of a group which the coalition thought it had as its core constituency—small- and medium-size businesses.

speech.para: Last Friday, the member for Wills, the member for Gellibrand and I held an inquiry into the business activity statement in my electorate in the St Kilda town hall—now called the Port Phillip town hall; I am a bit old fashioned and cannot adjust to these things. A considerable number of business owners willingly offered their time to voice their frustration with what they considered to be a huge waste of resources for their businesses—the BAS statement. It was telling that the inquiry occurred after the Treasurer's superficial backflip last week when he declared that businesses with a turnover of less than $2 million a year need submit the BAS only once every 12 months.

These businesspeople were, without exception, extremely cynical. They feel strongly that those opposite have not represented their interests and they are unwilling to trust them further. They know that the coalition government's backflip does not address two fundamental problems of the BAS paperwork war. Businesses that made submissions were diverse. Many had previously trusted the government at its word. Those businesses ranged from a sole practitioner in what you might call a microenterprise to a medium-size company with an $80 million turnover.

Despite this diversity, there were clear common themes. The first one was a palpable frustration with the sheer amount of time wasted in preparing the BAS statement. The coalition hopes to contain this angst by the cynical backflip of the Treasurer. However, many businesses commented that they still need to keep the same detailed level of records throughout the year. This has not changed. This is not a net reduction in paperwork. The worst thing for the coalition is that businesses understand precisely this: they still have the same amount of paperwork to do. The coalition's ploy will backfire. Businesses no longer trust this government.

The time demands of the BAS compliance impact directly on the efficiency of small and medium businesses. One manager indicated that the time spent on keeping accounts had increased by 60 per cent as a result of the BAS. She commented that this will not change—her record keeping still needs to be as detailed for her once-a-year submission. That submission is now once a year only as a result of pressure from the opposition. As the Leader of the Opposition said, this so-called policy lazy opposition has to keep enunciating its policies as quickly as possible so the government can grab them.

One witness voiced great frustration at the level of detail which she must keep in order to comply with the BAS requirements. She said, `It is simply not good business practice to examine every transaction to this extent.' This was from an accountant at a medium-size business. Her family established the business from nothing. She knows good business practice. Another woman, who is traditionally a swinging voter from small business, declared that she would never vote Liberal again. She stated that the time taken to prepare the BAS statement `takes away from the efficiency of my business'. Since the introduction of the BAS she now has to spend hours every month filling out the statement. That is time that could be spent creating and evolving a profitable enterprise. How is that helping Australia?

She stated that her business had always been profitable. She knows her business and how to make money. She objects to being told condescendingly by the coalition that now she has good financial records. She stated, `Okay, so now I have good records, but that is not improving my business. In fact, it has decreased.' The BAS statement is taking away valuable management time from small- and medium-sized enterprises throughout Australia. How does this help our economic efficiency?

In my view, this is just a scheme dreamed up by Treasury bureaucrats who have no real understanding of how things work out there in the business world. It is also worth noting that these business owners and managers have no objection to paying their fair share of tax. They object to the extraordinary inefficiency of the system that this Howard government, and particularly the Treasurer, foisted on them. Clearly, this also costs businesses money internally, with professional salaries affecting the bottom line of all businesses. This is one of the matters that particularly came out of the inquiry.

The complexity of the BAS statement also requires businesses to spend vastly increased amounts on external professional fees. One medium-sized business declared that their professional accounting fees had increased sixfold since the introduction of the BAS statement. Despite the coalition government's belated changes, this company accountant still anticipates that she will need to employ a full-time internal accountant for the first time. This will add an appreciable salary burden to the firm—a burden they never had under Labor.

The ongoing financial expense of professional fees will also impact on every Australian business for as long as the BAS statement and compliance regime remain in place. The Prime Minister and his Treasurer have given no indication that they will examine this. What they have done, in my view, is reprehensible. They have simply delayed the next BAS statement for those businesses with a turnover of less than $2 million until after the federal election is due.

In my view, Australian businesses simply will not be satisfied by the backflip undertaken by the Treasurer in recent days. They understand that the amount of paperwork is exactly the same as before, that this huge amount of compliance is causing a dreadful problem as far as they are concerned and that it is absolutely not helping. They resent `smart alec' comments from the ATO or the Treasury that this will help them plan and have much better financial records. Many businesses at the micro level in particular do not need this level of detailed record keeping. Without their being slack about their accounts or not complying with tax, this business activity statement is an understandable nightmare for them.

I want to turn my attention away from the iniquities of the business activity statement. I believe the government will hear more about this matter following Mr Thomson's excellent inquiry. This is going to roll on throughout Australia. Believe me, small business has many ideas about how the statement and compliance can be changed in a way that will be more efficient and that will help Australian small business.

Let me turn to the government's drugs strategy—the so-called National Illicit Drugs Strategy. Mr Deputy Speaker, I can tell you that, two years after Mr Howard's mega-announcement of extra funds for this area, the drugs strategy is not working on the ground. In my electorate we have a very bad area of illicit drug use. St Kilda is well known for it. The price of a cap of heroin has increased from $10 or $20 to $80. The angst on the streets as a result of this is palpable. It is all very well for money to be spent on extra policing. But if this policing simply moves the problem from the inner city of Melbourne or Footscray to my electorate, this is really of no net benefit to the community or, indeed, to the people who are the victims of illicit drugs. It is basically a health problem which the Australian community should be focusing on in terms of what might get these people off these kinds of things rather than moving them around from place to place. One of the things that I regret in particular is that it seems that all of the money for treatment and community partnerships in the National Illicit Drugs Strategy has been fully expended.

Of course, it is good that various schemes for rehabilitation and for community partnerships are being taken up. It just shows the desperate need that exists in this area that this has already been taken up. Perhaps there should have been more emphasis in the drug strategy on the government spending money in that particular area. In my electorate we have organisations that are desperate to receive some government assistance.

I think, in particular, of one very devoted community worker, a former well-known professional boxer, Henry Nissen, who works for the Emerald Hill Mission. He is out every night feeding people whose drug habit is so bad that they have no money for food. He is out every night with young people trying to encourage them to participate in other activities such as sports that might get them away from their drug habit. His organisation, the Emerald Hill Mission, funds his activities entirely out of their own budget. They have not been able to secure funding from the community partnerships section of the National Illicit Drug Strategy. Indeed in my electorate, which is probably one of the most heavily drug-dependent electorates in Australia, where the problem of illicit drugs is very serious, as far as I am aware we have received only one community partnership grant—and, believe me, that is not due to the inactivity of the local member. As soon as I became aware of the community partnerships section of the National Illicit Drug Strategy, every social welfare organisation in my electorate received a copy of the application form and encouragement from me to participate. But we have received, at this stage, only one grant.

I believe that our state Labor government, along with one of the important local municipalities, the Port Phillip Council, has allocated some moneys for a special strategy in our area. The need for that is more than apparent when one looks at the television and sees the massive upsurge in street prostitution and drug sales. This is not a criticism of the people who are engaging in prostitution to feed their own drug habits or indeed of people generally who are hooked on illicit drugs; this is simply a reflection of the fact that there are not enough programs. There remains a national crisis, and we need to do more to help organisations like the Emerald Hill Mission to help people like Henry Nissen. We recently had another very worthy organisation, the Mirabel Foundation, move into the electorate.

talk.start.para: —That is an excellent foundation.

—The member opposite realises that they do a fantastic job in helping the children of people who are hooked on illicit drugs, caring for them if they are orphaned or if they are abandoned. Again, we need to raise more government funds, together with funds from private enterprise, to provide the circumstances for looking after the children abandoned in such tragic circumstances. I am full of praise for all of the people who work voluntarily to raise money for Mirabel and for the people who work in Mirabel. But I do not consider it only their responsibility; I think the federal government should be involved as well.

speech.para: I might say one other thing about the government's National Illicit Drug Strategy that I find particularly disappointing. Members here may not realise that some $39 million was allocated for an education program that was to go along with this National Illicit Drug Strategy. That remains largely unspent after two years. I believe one of the blockages was in the Prime Minister's office, where the advertising program that was to be presented was considered not in sound accord with the ideological views of the Prime Minister's office. The crisis on our streets all around Australia is so serious that it seems to me a great shame that two years have been wasted in preparing an advertising campaign on this and an even greater shame, as I am sure the member for Fowler will agree, that this vast amount of advertising funding is to be spent now in a pre-election atmosphere.

talk.start.para: —Definitely.

—I turn briefly to Aboriginal affairs. Last week we had the regrettable circumstance where a very important Aboriginal elder and respected leader, Lowitja O'Donohue, was characterised by a major newspaper in this country as having made a major revelation about her status: that she was removed rather than stolen. I found this revelation rather less than astounding. Firstly, whether Ms O'Donohue was removed or stolen is really just a semantic difference; and, secondly, her mother—as has been described in many articles since—waited many years to get her back and, through a chance meeting with relatives, they had their only, as I understand it, tragic reunion. This was as a result of her uncle and aunt spotting her outside a supermarket many years later, when she returned.

speech.para: The tragedy of so many of our indigenous Australians being taken away from their parents—sometimes, I understand, with good intent, but nonetheless forcibly—is something that I believe really needs to be addressed. However, it does not need to be addressed in terms of what this government did in Darwin during the Gunner-Cubillo case. In an answer to a question, the Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Ruddock, explained that the federal government had spent $8.5 million on barristers and solicitors fees in fighting two poor Aboriginal people in Darwin to prevent them from getting compensation for being members of the stolen generation. Our federal government, with taxpayers' money, spent a further $770,000 on private detective fees to try to show that these two Aboriginal people—who had been physically and sexually assaulted while they were in the care of the government in the Northern Territory—were liars. This is a shameful misuse of government money.

The government's `amen corner', as I call it—the Institute for Public Affairs and Quadrant magazine, and all of the other people who think, as the Prime Minister does, that the difference between the words `stolen' and `removed' is highly significant—may think that this is a good expenditure of public moneys. I do not, and I do not believe the Australian people do. It astounded me that, after this semantic difference in Ms O'Donohue's case was established, the Prime Minister regarded this as highly significant. In the wake of what has happened in Western Australia and Queensland I would have thought that he would have got the message. Part of the same message is presented by all of the people who walked across the Sydney Harbour Bridge, the 50,000 people who marched in Brisbane, the 30,000 people who marched in Hobart and the 300,000 people who marched through my electorate on this issue. I cannot understand the focus of the Prime Minister's views on these issues. I believe very sincerely that, with the election of the opposition to government, we would say sorry to the Aboriginal people officially, as a government. We would have an entirely different attitude to this important area of our national consciousness: the treatment of our own indigenous people. I believe that expenditure of public moneys to the extent that they were spent on fighting this case in Darwin would not take place again.

I conclude by turning to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, in relation to which I noticed a curious little occurrence the other day. I note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs has been described in glossy weekend newspapers as having had something of a resurrection, and I understand that he would like to project that view. I have noted also the very curious appearance of a former Minister for Trade, the member for Farrer, at a cocktail party in Beijing, where he pre-empted the right of the Australian Olympic Committee to announce its attitude to Beijing as the site for the Olympics in 2008.

I find the member for Farrer's pre-emptive announcements very curious, especially in the light of the three reports that have been published recently, which any serious government should have examined before it announced what Australia's attitude would be. First of all there is the report of Freedom House, a very well-known civil rights organisation, on the continuing abuse of human rights and civil rights in China. The second, just announced in the last few days, was Amnesty's report, which is causing many other governments in the world to at least take this into account before they make their decision. Finally, there is the official report of the State Department of our great and powerful ally, the United States, on human rights in China, which I notice the Chinese government has reacted to with great anger. I am not saying that the Australian government should have this attitude or that attitude to Australia participating in the Beijing Olympics in 2008, but we should take these reports into account, at least, and Australia's attitude should not be announced by a former trade minister. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak to the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2000-2001, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2000-2001 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2000-2001. A few years ago Paul Keating, the then Treasurer, made the suggestion that even the pet shop parrot was speaking the words `micro-economic reform'. It seems today that the pet shop parrot has learned some new words, and those words are `deregulation', `competition' and `globalisation'. I do not pretend to be an expert in the field of economics, but I think I know a bit more than a pet shop parrot does and a lot more than some of the people who are running around this country screeching those words do.

speech.para: As it happens, I learned about deregulation, competition and globalisation in a shop—not a pet shop but the local convenience shop. When my children were younger, in between playgroup and the household chores, my daily routine included a visit to the local corner shop to buy milk and bread and other odds and ends. There each day I would meet the friendly neighbourhood shopkeeper, a nice chappie but with one terrible flaw: he was a dyed-in-the-wool Lib, and he could not resist the temptation to try to convert the local mums to his way of thinking. So every time I walked into the shop I would cop an earful of his latest line of what was wrong with this country.

talk.start.para: —You should've listened.

—He was listening, but to the wrong people. He kept a radio behind the counter, and it was always tuned to—wait for it—John Laws and Alan Jones, and he would quote them as if they were prophets. Most of the other mums would nod politely when he spoke. Then, when they got outside the shop, they would shake their heads and call him a silly old—excuse me, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl—bugger. But, as a person who had worked with trade unions and Labor MPs, I could not help myself and I always took the bait. I usually gave as good as I got in defence of working people and the Labor cause. In the end I would storm out of the shop and threaten to take my business somewhere else. But there was nowhere else to go, so I would be back again the next day for another round. He would be there telling me and everyone how great the free enterprise system was, how good competition was for everyone and how the government should not interfere or try to regulate his business.

speech.para: Then one day something happened. The vacant shop next door was leased out to another grocer. Well, we did not hear the end of it. `This should not be allowed,' cried the shopkeeper, and on his counter was a petition to the government and the local council calling for them to regulate things so that you could not open up a shop near one that was already there. `I was here first,' he said. `I've got squatter's rights. They can't do this to me,' he shouted. Now, I had waited years for this to happen. This moment was so precious to me. `But what about all you said about free enterprise and competition and how the government should not regulate business?' I asked. I will not tell the Main Committee what his reply was, but things definitely got worse.

The young couple who opened the new shop were Greek Australians. That was the final straw for the shopkeeper. `Bloody migrants; the government brings them in here to take your jobs away,' he ranted. And it was the final straw for me, too. I did not have to go back to that store; I had somewhere else to go. The two shops competed with each other in a way. Their prices were the same. Some, like me, preferred the service in the Greek shop, as we called it. Soon, though, the young Greek couple installed a deep fryer and a hamburger grill. They had realised that in our neighbourhood the kids had grown a bit older. Instead of drinking Ribena, they were drinking Coke and, instead of teething rusks, they were munching on hot chips and hamburgers. So the Greek shop prospered while the other shop faded.

One day, there was a mysterious fire in the convenience store and we never saw the old shopkeeper again. Sadly, no-one seemed to miss him. The shop never reopened and still today has a tacky looking `For lease' sign in the window. What became of the winners in this battle for market supremacy? They sold out to a Lebanese couple, who sold out to a Chinese couple, who sold out to a Filipino couple, who sold out to someone else. I moved from that area about three years ago. Meanwhile, down the road, a set of golden arches appeared and the business went downhill. There was another mysterious fire and another tacky `For lease' sign.

The drama I have just outlined to the House is not uncommon. As all members are aware, it has been acted out in neighbourhoods all over the country. What I want to draw from it is an understanding of the forces which shape our economy. It can be all too easy to blame governments for too much regulation or not enough of it. It can be too easy to point to people from different backgrounds as the cause of our troubles, and it can be too easy to blame the world for moving on when we would like it to stand still. When I look back to my childhood, I can remember—and I am not going to give my age away too much—the ice man, the horsedrawn bread cart and even—

talk.start.para: —Oh, come on! I can't believe it.

—I don't look that old—a very rare sight these days, the milkman. We can be sentimental about the passing of these trades, but I am sure we would rather have a frost-free fridge than the old ice chest. So, for whatever reason, those trades have disappeared. Globalisation had little to do with it. Having said that, Mr Deputy Speaker, you might be thinking that this has little to do with the appropriation bills, so I will definitely get to my point.

speech.para: Appropriation Bill (No. 3) contains an item which provides an additional $36.4 million for assistance to the sugar industry. I will not pretend to be an expert on the sugar industry, nor would I oppose this increase in assistance, but I do note the fact that the sugar industry is receiving assistance. At this time, I will not even question why they are receiving that assistance. But I would ask why some other industries and, more to the point, workers who are displaced from those industries, do not get assistance.

Let us look at a recent example. Furniture Australia is a large furnishing manufacturer which took over the operations of the previously government owned school furniture complex in New South Wales. That was back in the days when the pet shop parrots spoke of micro-economic reform. After the sale, the school furniture contracts in New South Wales were put out to competitive tender. Supplying furniture to schools in New South Wales is a very huge contract and winning or losing a contract can make or break a manufacturer. Having held the contract for a number of years, Furniture Australia failed to win sizeable orders in recent tenders. The struggle to contain costs in order to keep winning the contracts has taken its toll on the company. An administrator was appointed and the company went into liquidation in December 1999. Competition had claimed another victim. But the bad management went beyond the marketing side of the business. Its finances were a mess. There was no provision for the entitlements of workers—workers who had been with Furniture Australia and with the government owned operation before that; workers with up to 20 years service in some cases; and workers who had devoted the whole of their working lives to the company. They found themselves left out in the cold.

The former owners of Furniture Australia, BTR Nylex, had already cut their losses, but the workers missed out. They were simply passed on each time the company was sold, going from having a guarantee of their entitlements under government ownership to seeing their money lost by the new owners. The workers of Furniture Australia were definitely sold down the river. They had no say as to who the owner of the business was. When I raised this matter with the then Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, his reply—too smart by half—pointed out that the Employee Entitlement Support Scheme was backdated to 1 January 2000. Furniture Australia went into liquidation in December 1999, one month too soon for workers to receive even the limited benefit of that scheme.

But why should workers' entitlements of tens of thousands of dollars, in individual cases, be put at risk? What other branch of commerce would trust large sums to a business manager? Workers' entitlements should not be a lottery. Those entitlements should be safeguarded. As we begin to see signs of a weakening economy, as we see a slump in the building industry, it is only a matter of time before we see more employees of $2 companies being owed thousands of dollars in entitlements when their employers go broke. Are they victims of deregulation, competition or globalisation? I doubt it. More likely, they are the victims of greed.

When we speak of deregulation, competition and globalisation, we cannot assume that all the players are equal, or that any one of the players will not try to gain an advantage at the cost of others. We may have to even up the playing field. We may have to regulate to ensure fairness, and we may have to provide assistance to industries which have shown that under normal conditions they can compete. The bias, if you call it that, on the Labor side of politics has been to regulate to protect the entitlements of workers.

Small businesses are often the victims of company collapses: the losses they face when larger contractors fall often lead to their collapse and start a chain reaction. More and more workers find that their entitlements are lost. When times are good, few people call for regulation. Like the corner shopkeeper, they resent having to comply with what they see as government red tape. But when they face competition, they cry out for government intervention and assistance. As the old saying goes, they want to capitalise their profits and socialise their losses. As for employees, it seems that they do not know that their long service leave and annual leave entitlements are at risk until it is too late. The call to regulate to protect these entitlements has not been heard loudly until recently, although the problem has been around for a long time. It is all very well for the former minister, Peter Reith, to say that Labor did not act on the problem when we were in office, but I do not recall his once raising the issue during that time.

After more than 20 years of deregulation, should we see further deregulation as inevitable? Some people would like to wind back the clock. They need to be reminded of the many benefits that have come in the form of lower prices and better service. I do not know how I would cope if shops were not open on Saturday afternoons or Sundays, as was the case not too many years ago. But there will always be a need for governments to regulate. There will always be a need to protect workers, consumers and small businesses. These issues of deregulation, competition and globalisation will require governments to be sensitive to the interests of not only those affected by changes but the broader community as well.

The fate of the three groups that I have spoken of—the corner grocer, the furniture workers and the sugar industry—have a common thread which reminds me of the story of the Siberian thrush. Some members may have heard this story and would know that it takes about half an hour to tell, but I will definitely give the House the short version. A kind Siberian woodcutter was walking through the frozen Siberian woods when he saw a tiny thrush which had been blown from its nest, perhaps by the chill winds of global competition. The woodcutter could see that the bird was near death, so he picked it up and warmed it in his hands, bringing it back to life. He could not hold the bird all day, so he looked around and saw a steaming pile of Siberian moose dung. He gently placed the bird in the dung and went on his way. Feeling warmer, the bird began to sing, but his song was heard by the fierce Siberian wolf, who came and snatched the bird from its warm surroundings.

There are three morals to the story. The first is that the person who gets you into the dung may not be your enemy. Regulation is not something you may enjoy but it has a purpose. The second moral of the story is that the one who gets you out of the dung may not turn out to be your friend. There are plenty of wolves around to take advantage of deregulated industries. But the third and most important moral of the story is: when you are up to your ears in steaming moose dung, you cannot always blame it on deregulation, competition or globalisation.
A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 5.06 p.m. to 5.18 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Do you remember where you got up to?

—Yes, I definitely remember. I think we have had a little bit of fun, so we will get right into it now. There is widespread talk of an economic downturn. There is evidence. Builders in Queensland are going broke at the rate of something like five a week. Small business is being hung out to dry because of the GST. My electorate of Fowler has a large small business sector. They are carrying the GST. They are struggling with the paperwork. They are struggling with the tax remittances. Many of them are about to dispense with the accountant they never had to have before. They are going to shut up their shops—not because of competition but because the GST has become too much of an added cost. The BAS relief is too late to save them, and we are bracing ourselves for a rash of small business failures, the like of which we have not seen since the credit squeeze of the sixties.

speech.para: The government has had to adopt Labor's policy—and they have adopted Labor's policy—because it did not have the antidote for the bite it inflicted on small and medium-sized businesses. It had no plan B, because it did not think it needed one. The GST was supposed to be simple. The GST was to mark a new era of prosperity. The GST was to be an uplifting experience. But small business has been badly let down. That is where the rage is coming from. Small business, the dynamo of employment, has been pushed against the wall by a government that declared its undying friendship to the little entrepreneur, the commercial Aussie battler. This government claimed it understood small business, as if the opposition did not. There is even $100 million in these bills to put a bit of commercial rigour into defence housing. But will they build in Queensland?

I am sure the seat of Ryan could do with a lot of defence housing—and soon. But, again, we cannot blame globalisation for Queensland's building slump. It has an awful lot to do with the GST and the pre-June building surge. Residential building has fallen more than 42 per cent over the half year. That is a big fall: over 42 per cent. Shocking, isn't it? It is 42 per cent over the half year. It also means a big increase in the number of people out of work, and it is not going to get any better. Company profits are down, petrol prices were up for too long and, again, the Howard government has had to do a complete backflip. I think we have been watching the ABC recently when we see those little captions of a couple of our ministers doing backflips and reaching into Labor's policy suggestion box, but it is too late for this government.

We are in the tunnel of the tunnel vision of this government and it is dark inside. All about us are echoes of words like `recession', `slump' and `downturn.' Confidence is what keeps economies going and growing. Lose it, and you slow down, and you go down into the darkness. But confidence is low, unemployment is rising and this government, this champion of business, does not have a clue what to do. Like Pooh Bear, full of honey, it has squeezed itself so far up the tunnel it cannot even turn around. It is a very clueless bear, and very soon it is going to have a very sore head.

talk.start.para: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2000-2001 appropriates extra funding for a range of purposes, but amongst them is $202 million to the Australian Taxation Office. Of that, $183 million is yet another allocation for increased costs associated with the implementation of the GST. Recall the exhortations and the proud boasts in the parliament of the Treasurer so many times saying that he was implementing a `streamlined new tax system for a new century'. I have had occasion to weigh that legislation and the explanatory material, and the latest weigh-in was certainly above seven kilos—and it is thicker than three telephone books. I have just had the opportunity of scanning some of the other acts which have been amended as a result of this so-called tax reform process and I do not dare, for the sake of the trees and public expense, print them out, because they run to literally thousands of pages. So much for a `streamlined new tax system for a new century'.

speech.para: This tax system was meant to replace the `outmoded 1930s Botswana style wholesale sales tax'. Incidentally, one of the boasts in getting rid of this Botswana style wholesale sales tax was that we would get a range of economic benefits, about which I will speak later, but one of those that was predicted by some of the modellers who did the work and by the Treasurer himself was that there would be an appreciation of the exchange rate. This was supposed to be a good thing but, in fact, since the implementation of the GST on 1 July, the Australian dollar has depreciated against in the order of 150 currencies out of a possible total of 161 currencies, including—surprise, surprise—the currency of Botswana and also Swaziland, spoken of in derogatory terms by the Treasurer as another one of those countries that had this outmoded complicated wholesale sales tax system that was being replaced with these kilos and kilos of the `streamlined new tax system for a new century.'

Every day the Prime Minister is spending the Treasurer's credibility. He is spending it to the point where this government and, in particular, the Treasurer have lost all economic credibility. They are spending like drunken sailors, desperately trying to hold on to government. The previous Labor government, over a period of 13 years, implemented a whole range of economic reform measures that had the effect, ultimately, of very substantially boosting productivity. Some of those benefits did not come through in the early years, and that is why people were wondering what to make of this economic reform agenda, because the floating of the dollar, the liberalisation of financial markets and the internationalisation of the Australian economy did not seem to be yielding the benefits that were hoped of it.

Those reforms in fact have yielded very substantial benefits for the Australian economy. But the benefits have become more manifest in the last few years. They have become more manifest in the form of an increase in the economically sustainable rate of growth—that is, the rate of growth that is sustainable without causing an acceleration in inflation. That sustainable rate of growth, having gone up, has meant that larger budget surpluses accrue because we are growing faster. That means lower unemployment benefits and higher tax receipts.

This government has been relying on that higher sustainable rate of growth to achieve budget outcomes. But its luck, I am afraid, is starting to run out, because the government has not done anything substantial to continue the improvements in productivity that are required in this economy. Instead, it has embarked on an ideological obsession in two areas. One is the implementation of a goods and services tax and the other is the workplace relations changes. They have been driven more by ideology than by any attempt to improve labour productivity. We were presiding over very great improvements in productivity in this economy and then the government changed. By and large, in the pursuit of its ideological obsession, productivity growth is falling away and now we are confronted with the situation of a very substantial economic slowdown.

The GST, and the blind ideological obsession that has driven it, is a GST that we did not have to have. This GST is causing an economic slowdown that we did not have to have. My fear is that there is a real risk that the GST will cause a recession that we did not have to have. I do not want this country to fall into recession. We will know a lot more about that when the national accounts are released tomorrow. It is very clear that if we are not in recession, we are in a period of very flat economic growth. That can only continue, because there are some very bad portents around. For example, just today, Westpac released data—the Westpac Composite Index. Its own verdict is that the GST has pre-empted the slowdown in the US economy. That is a nice set of words for saying that this is a self-inflicted wound; that the US economy is slowing down, anyway, but that has not in fact transmitted to the Australian economy yet. We have done our slowdown all on our own account through the implementation of the GST. The Westpac survey states:

quote.para: While high interest rates and energy prices have impacted both series, the GST effects in Australia have pre-empted the US weakness. The current level of the WCI—

speech.para: that is, the Westpac Composite Index—

quote.para: is around the lows of the mid-1990s with no guarantees that it has bottomed out.

speech.para: Today's ACCI Westpac survey of industrial trends for the March quarter 2001 has revealed a continued fall in business confidence. It has revealed a decline in output yet again. It has revealed a decline in new orders. It has revealed a sharp decline in exports to the lowest reading for the 1990s, except for the period of the Asian crisis. It has revealed a decline in capacity utilisation, and a decline in the profits outlook for the next 12 months to make up the worst profits outlook since 1990-91. It has revealed a squeeze on profit margins and a continued poor outlook for business investment, and it has revealed a continued soft employment outlook.

These figures and the surveys released today accompany other disturbing data that has also been released recently. I would like to take honourable members through some of that data. It includes the largest year-on-year decline in the ANZ job advertisements series in a decade. That was released yesterday. It includes the ABS composite leading indicator, which points to a decline in growth since the GST was introduced. It includes business surveys from Dun and Bradstreet pointing to worsening business conditions. It includes National Australia Bank surveys pointing to a slowdown in economic activity. It includes a decline in the Westpac Melbourne Institute leading indicator of economic growth. It includes a pitiful investment performance, with the average annual growth rate of real new private capital expenditure over the last three years a disappointing minus five per cent, compared with 15 per cent in Labor's last three years in office.

It includes the first consecutive quarters of year-on-year decline in real retail sales in nearly a decade. It includes the largest year-on-year decline in building approvals since at least 1984. It includes the largest decline in building work since John Howard was Treasurer back in the early 1980s. It includes record foreign debt of $301 billion, which is up by nearly 60 per cent in just five years under this government. It also includes more than 87,000 full-time jobs lost in the last four months. These are the portents, surely, of an economic slowdown.

I am always amazed, when the Treasurer gets survey data and comments on it in the House, that he says, `That's just one survey and it's a disreputable survey. Who would believe Dun and Bradstreet? Who would believe Westpac? Who would believe the ACCI?' But when you put them all together, you get a very disturbing picture of what the GST has done to the economy.

talk.start.para: —A disturbing pattern.

—Certainly, a disturbing pattern. The fact is that the GST is a wrecking ball swinging through the Australian economy. I recall that the Treasurer said that the GST package would create jobs, stronger growth and growth in exports. In fact, since the GST has been introduced there have been two contractions: a contraction in fiscal policy and a contraction in monetary policy.

speech.para: In relation to fiscal policy, there was meant to be in the order of a $6 billion stimulus associated with the income tax cuts. In fact, the GST has been reaping more revenue than the government expected it to do. It will not actually tell us exactly what those figures are, but it is quite obvious that the GST itself has been a source of fiscal contraction. In addition, the excises, particularly the ones that are fed by the GST, as they operate as a tax on a tax in tandem, have been a source of growth in revenue for the government. So you have got this fiscal contraction on the one side and on the other side there is a monetary tightening.

Why did the government tighten monetary policy? They did so for reasons that they articulated before and after the last election; that is, they did not want the workers to get any idea that they might be able to pursue wage rises in response to the increases in the cost of living associated with the GST. They said to the workers of Australia, `We're going to screw the economy down to make sure that there is no wages flow-on from the increases in prices.' They did so. They deflated wage expectations; in fact, wages growth has been very moderate. So to that extent, given that that was the government's objective, they succeeded. But in combining both a fiscal contraction and a monetary contraction, the government have inflicted on this economy our very own home-grown slowdown.

It is not as if the government was not warned about this. Evidence was given to the Senate GST inquiry by Professor Peter Dixon, who had done a lot of sophisticated modelling on the impact of the GST and the application of a new tax to tourism, education and a range of other services which are the big job growing areas in this country. Professor Dixon quantified that but he summarised it in these words, `The GST would be job destroying.' The government said, `No, the GST is going to create jobs.' With 87,000 full-time jobs lost over the last four months, it is pretty clear that Professor Dixon's warnings have been borne out and the Treasurer has been completely wrong in his predictions that the GST package would create jobs.

The government is still congratulating itself on the smooth implementation of the GST. Honourable members might remember the great celebrations in the first few days after the GST was implemented. It said, `Look, it's going really well.' We warned it then not to get complacent and not to believe that the GST had gone over very well. In particular, we warned about the business activity statement and the instalments of tax that would be payable at that time.

The government said, `Oh, well, the prices didn't really go up too much on 1 July in the supermarkets.' We never really asserted that the prices in the supermarkets would go up. We said—to use Kim Beazley's phrase—that there would be a `slow burn'. We said that the prices of services, and the lumpy services, would go up—obviously they would because there was no tax on services and now there is a 10 per cent tax on services. So when it came to insurance, when it came to electricity, when it came to phone bills and when it came to car repairs and a whole range of services, it would take time for people to start using those and to realise that the prices had gone up and that, `This is affecting my purchasing power.' As a result, consumer confidence has been collapsing in this country.

The other thing that we said—apart from it being a slow burn, which has in fact been completely borne out—was that it would not necessarily be the first business activity statement instalment but the second one that would do the damage. The reason that we said that is that in small business it is quite common for businesspeople to put away some cash reserves for a rainy day, because you do not know what is going to happen. You do not know whether you are going to get sick or whether some other key personnel will get sick. You do not know if there is going to be some sort of downturn or whether you are not going to get the contracts that you hope to get.

As a result, there is that cushion there, but that cushion of reserves was used up in the payment of the first GST instalments. After Christmas there are no cash reserves left, and it was the second GST instalment associated with the second BAS payment that we warned, right back at the beginning, would be the crunch time. Again, we were told that we did not know what we were talking about. I worked in small business. I was a small business proprietor for a couple of years. I feel I know what I am talking about. The Labor side are always told we are union people and we do not know about small business. I think we knew a lot more about small business than this government did, because we said it would be the second business activity statement that would create the difficulties, and so it has.

I understand that there are rumours abounding following the first simplification of the business activity statement that the government reluctantly did after saying it was perfect. I understand that there is a new super-simplified business activity form that is being trialed by Treasury. It has just got two boxes. Box 1 says, `How much money did you pay?' You tick that and provide the number. Box 2 says, `Send it to us.' So it is a much more simplified business activity statement! That is where we are headed with this so-called simplified, streamlined, new tax system for a new century.
I would like to draw your attention to what we might call the `Perth declaration' by the Treasurer. He said on ABC radio on 18 May last year:

quote.para: I don't think anybody will go to the wall as a consequence of GST. I think there are businesses that are getting into difficulty for all sorts of reasons. You know, it may be that sales are down, it may be that markets have changed, and businesses will rise and fall as they always have. But I don't think that there will be businesses that will founder because of GST.

speech.para: The Treasurer will live to regret those words. What do they say to the thousands of businesses that are under extreme pressure from the GST and to those many businesses which are already closing their doors because of the downturn in sales due to the collapse in consumer confidence associated with the GST? Is he going to say to them, `Look, that's got nothing to do with the GST. That's just because you weren't very good managers—the rise and fall of the small business sector'? If he does he will be doing so at his peril, because it is unarguably true that businesses are closing their doors because of the GST. They say, `We are on the side of business, but we are going to crunch business. We are on the side of business, but we are going to be the highest taxing government in a decade. But, worse than that, we will conceal it by classifying the GST as a state tax.' It is pretty clear that the whole tax reform—the Prime Minister's great tax adventure—is a complete and utter failure and a shambles.

The new tax system was supposed to replace 10 taxes. This was the big virtue of the new tax system. In the end, it replaced only four taxes: the wholesale sales taxes, financial institutions duty from the middle of this year; a small bed tax that applied only in New South Wales and the Northern Territory—so I do not think that would be of any benefit in our state of Queensland; and stamp duty on shares. There is a whole range of taxes that are staying in place. They include income tax, payroll tax, petrol excise, alcohol excise, tobacco excise, diesel excise, stamp duty on buying a house, stamp duty on hire purchase, stamp duty on insurance, stamp duty on cheques, stamp duty on mortgages and bank accounts, debits tax, customs duty, gambling taxes and other state and local council fees and charges. It has been anything but streamlined.

The entire tax system is a total shambles, symptomatic of the fact that the government has to appropriate more than $100 million to the tax office to implement this so-called `streamlined new tax system for a new century'. Of course we will not be opposing these appropriation bills—it goes without saying—but it does give us an opportunity to demonstrate one clear, unarguable point: the whole tax reform process has been a complete and utter shambles.

talk.start.para: —I congratulate the honourable member for Rankin for his very fine contribution to this debate. Although these are appropriation bills, my area of interest that I want to talk about is defence. I want to take the opportunity to talk a little bit about some military justice matters. In the previous parliament there were three terms of reference given to the defence subcommittee. The first was looking at defence expenditure and the projected block obsolescence; the second was the sinking of the HMAS Sydney; and the third, by way of a motion sponsored by our shadow minister at the time, Arch Bevis, was looking at military justice.

speech.para: I have probably been a bit unkind about the defence expenditure inquiry, basically because I believed a parliamentary committee, at the end of the day, would not be influencing an ERC process. But I am happy to concede that that is probably too trenchant a position to take. No doubt, that report—particularly the report of the library defence team led by Derek Woolner—has had an effect on the defence debate. The second inquiry was what I have termed a 50-year-old naval board of inquiry. Whilst it is true that it provided, in some measure, a listening post for a lot of people who are very keen to satisfy themselves as to the mystery of the sinking of the Sydney, as I have said, in my view it was a 50-year-old naval board of inquiry.

The most important of the inquiries was the military justice inquiry. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that the worst type of parliamentary committee inquiry is one that goes over two parliaments. We started the inquiry late in the previous parliament, and our chairman, Senator David MacGibbon, was retiring six months after the second election of the Howard government. There was some anxiety about finishing the two remaining reports: HMAS Sydney—which we did—and the military justice one. I want to put on the record that I had hoped that we might have taken a few more witnesses in the military justice inquiry, if for no other reason than to give the newer members of the subcommittee an opportunity to familiarise themselves with what we were doing. In the end, the pressure of time did not allow that before we finished the report.

I make the following points: firstly, in that inquiry I was very concerned about what were called attitude adjustment tours. When a private or private equivalent in the services was not performing particularly well and was in danger of being disciplined, they were sent over to the detention centre at Holsworthy and put through some exercises. In a preventative sense it was probably not a bad scheme; the problem was that it had no basis whatsoever in military law. It was, as I have said a couple of times, akin to kidnapping people and falsely imprisoning them. This came to light when a female private attempted suicide. She made this attempt not just because she had been part of the disciplinary tour but that was an element of it. I have read very carefully through the subsequent reports on the changes to the detention centre and I think they are very positive. I have seen nothing in them to quibble with; in fact, I endorse them. I have always been disappointed, though, that not one person has ever been charged over this. Here we have kidnapping and false imprisonment, yet not one officer was charged over it.

Mention of that matter in the military justice report excited my interest. I placed a catch-all question on notice about whether or not there had been any other inappropriate disciplinary action, and whether such actions were being investigated. On 12 May 1999 Minister Scott replied:

quote.para: The only other claims of inappropriate disciplinary action involve another Army unit at Holsworthy. The Military Police have been investigating these claims since September 1998.

speech.para: You may accuse me of being thick and I plead guilty: I thought it was another instance of attitude adjustment tours, but it was not. It turns out that this was in 3RAR. It is a matter of record that a Time magazine article blew the lid on what was going on in 3RAR. The journalist who wrote the Time article thought I was onto what was happening there, and so we had a long conversation about 3RAR before his watershed article—for which, frankly, I believe he deserves commendation—blew the lid on it. This is bastardisation in the Army.

I want to make it plain that there have been other occasions when bastardisation has occurred on a minister's watch—on the watch of ministers from both sides of parliament. I do not for one minute infer that the ministers approved of it or even knew about it. Yet they have always come forward and outlined what has happened and the action that they intend to take. The case of 3RAR is qualitatively different. It was not that the minister became vicariously informed about it. In fact, Minister Bronwyn Bishop or her office was contacted on two occasions by Mrs Nishimura, the first occasion being on 17 March 1998. I am not good at mental arithmetic, but I can tell you that in 11 days we will celebrate three years since Mrs Bishop was first advised that things were not going well in 3RAR. It is 1,085 days today since Mrs Bishop was first informed.

The thing that really irritates me about the whole 3RAR affair is that there has not been one ministerial statement, not one press release, in 1,085 days. As I said, Mrs Bishop is the first one for whom an alarm bell is rung. What happened to her inquiry? What did she or her office do about the first inquiry and, indeed, the second inquiry? I do not know; it remains a mystery. But under normal circumstances, there would have been action. There would have been a note sent over to Defence and there would have been a note sent back, a briefing or a whole variety of things which could have happened. But one of them certainly would have happened.

Minister Scott deceptively answered my question on 12 May 1999 by not saying that the unit was 3RAR; the answer was put back on the Notice Paper. Not only would the text of the answer have been there, but so would a briefing paper. If a minister is unhappy about an answer, or if he is unhappy about the note that briefs him or his staff about the answer, then he asks for further explanations. What did Minister Scott do when he said that the military police were winding up their investigations and that the report would be ready by the end of the month? This has been puzzling. I have placed some more questions on the Notice Paper that go to the heart of this matter, because there is no doubt that the military police investigation was wound up at the very point when they were concluding that there was a culture of violence in 3RAR.

In fact, when the defence subcommittee, following the first Time article, had a hearing in camera with General Cosgrove, one of the things that really annoyed me was their defence as to why they could not have told the committee at the time of the first report what was going on in 3RAR. I cannot table the transcript because it is an in camera transcript, but believe you me: there was an extraordinary defence mounted about the impossibility of doing it, which I do not accept.

Again, this did not prompt a ministerial statement, either by Minister Moore or by Minister Scott. At the end of the day, the 3RAR affair has caused a lot of action to be taken, but nothing has been put on the public record by Minister Bishop, by Minister Scott, by Minister Moore—and I think it is too early to say, by Minister Reith. At the end of the day, the buck stops with parliament; the buck stops with the ministers. If we are so concerned to identify and stamp out bastardisation, why don't we have a ministerial press release? Why don't we have a ministerial statement? We do not even have a ministerial press conference about the whole issue.

I think everyone in Parliament House is determined to stamp it out. Community standards change. There will be a difference between military and civilian standards, but in this day and age the gap has to be narrow; it cannot be wide. Yes, we expect leadership from Admiral Barrie, but we also need to have ministerial leadership on this issue.

I want to know how many times ministers have been briefed on this issue. What action have they taken? There has been action taken that I approve of: the appointment of an audit team, for instance. Whilst I am very happy that we have a judge who is an expert on copyright and patent law heading the team, I had hoped there would have been some outsiders in the team supporting him, but there are not. That would have added credibility and weight. But I approve of it. I think the Inspector-General is a good idea.

The important thing about 3RAR is not so much bringing people to justice—important as that is—but that it is making sure that not only the privates, the corporals, the CSMs and the sergeants are held to account for their actions but also, if appropriate, the officers—the command responsibility. But important as those things are, they pale into insignificance compared to restoring confidence in the military justice system, and I think we have started down that road.

I have said before that I think the investigative skills of the military police are an issue. And when you downsize an organisation from 500 to 400 people, you have got to lose some things. If it is at all possible, we need to use the military police reservists more. But the military police and the Army are now under unified command for the first time. That change occurred in January 2000. I have been critical of the Defence Legal Office; I think we have a serious problem there: there is an own motion inquiry going on, if you like. It is a pity that there are no proper terms of reference, and it is a pity that there is not a dedicated team doing that. But I will give the ADF some marks for that.

When we were doing this first military justice inquiry, the chair, Senator MacGibbon, and I argued long over the institution of a director of military prosecutions. To use his words about the failure of both the minister and the ADF to tell us about 3RAR, `They lied to us; they deceived us.' We would not have had that debate had we known. We recommended a sunset situation—that is, we would give the ADF another two years before we revisited it. Had we known about 3RAR, there is no doubt in my mind—and, if anyone wants to consult with Dr David MacGibbon, there is no doubt in his mind—that we would have recommended a director of military prosecution, an independent office within the Army. They have set up what they call a prosecuting cell in the ADF legal office. This is as close as you can get to a Clayton's director of military prosecutions. But it is not good enough.

There is a lot more I wish to say about this but, hopefully, the defence subcommittee will be bringing down its report shortly. Again, the most important thing is for us to make recommendations that strengthen confidence that military justice is fair and just and that it applies not only to privates, corporals, sergeants and CSMs but equally to officers. No more should we have Birrer reports that indicate that officers under the gun are dealt with administratively and get not only their retirement benefits but also a golden handshake by way of punishment. That is no longer acceptable; it is not good enough.

I do believe, and I want to put again on the publicrecord, that General Cosgrove and the Army are cooperating to the fullest extent with the defence subcommittee. I am very grateful for the detailed reports that General Peter Leahy has been providing to the subcommittee about the progress of charges, investigations and trials. Unfortunately, I think that that has still some way to run.

Last, but not least, I want to mention something that I have been accused of, and that is recommending that 3RAR be abolished. It is true, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I have said to a journalist that, at the end of the process, we need to consider this issue. You might say that I am splitting hairs—and I do not have a lot of hairs to split, to be truthful—but I do believe it is a consideration. I certainly am not in the camp of disbanding 3RAR, a unit with a very proud history. But I have to say that, on the issues that the committee has examined, I have been deeply disturbed. I know that we have witnesses that we have not examined that bring these instances back as far as the 1980s. These things, to me, are deeply disturbing but, at the end of the day, I want to assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and all honourable members that I think that they can be well satisfied with the work of the defence subcommittee on the issue of 3RAR in restoring confidence in the military justice system.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to raise a number of instances where people's rights have been trampled, people's concerns have not been listened to and people's despair has not been taken into account. I have always believed that our job as elected representatives is to reflect the views of people and to make sure that their voices are heard, both in government agencies and the government itself. I want to raise three instances this evening where that quite clearly has not happened. As I said, as elected representatives, I believe it is our responsibility to make sure that these sorts of things do happen.

speech.para: The first instance relates to an issue that I raised on 26 February about the ACCC and its inability or unwillingness to investigate substantial fraud that exists within the car insurance industry. The car insurance industry is a fairly substantial industry obviously but, most importantly, there are people that feed off the car insurance industry and they are in the crash repair industry. There are something like 8,500 crash repair centres in Australia and there is a scandal that they are being exposed to that they want fixed. They have been, as I understand it, pushing for this scandal to be resolved for some four or five years now. But this scandal, this rip-off of taxpayers and motorists, has not been addressed.

The agency that should be investigating this extortion, this fraud, is the ACCC but, despite numerous requests to the ACCC, and numerous legal opinions that it should be investigated by the ACCC, this substantial fraud has not been investigated. I would like to address some of the concerns that have been raised and to provide additional evidence as to why it should be investigated.

The car repair industry in Victoria has about 1,500 car repair centres. Seventy per cent of the money for the repair of these cars comes from insurance companies. The accident repair centres incidentally have received no increase in payments from the insurance companies for the last three years, as I indicated in my speech on 26 February, even though the cost of parts and other things have increased by some 23 per cent. There is an estimated $400 million to $500 million windfall that came to insurance companies as a consequence of this GST increase. What has happened is that, despite the fact that the insurance companies are levying greater amounts as a consequence of the GST increase, they are not passing that on to the car repairers. The crash repairers are being paid the same amount as before, or less, than they should be being paid. What I have raised is one particular instance.

One of the main perpetrators of the insurance fraud is the RACV, the Royal Automobile Club of Victoria. As I said, I cited in my speech of 26 February several instances of fraud—basically there is no other word for it—that had been perpetrated by that particular company.
