The RACV was asked for a response, and basically their response to the allegations and the instances that I raised was that, `That was past history.' I say that for the RACV and for the agencies that should be investigating it this is not past history. This is continuing to happen at this point in time. The fact that it is not being investigated is unacceptable.

As I did in my earlier speech, I refer to a document that is used by the RACV to investigate accident claims: a potential fraud indicator. I have that fine document in front of me. The fraud indicator lists the signs of a potential fraudster. Basically, the fraud indicator sheet must be looked at prior to processing every accident claim. Some indications of a potential fraudster are: the ethnicity of the insured, which seems to be fairly important; whether or not the vehicle was stolen from the western suburbs, and this in Victoria is fairly important; whether or not the nationalities of the parties are similar; whether or not the claimant is unemployed; and whether or not the claimant is between 21 and 25 years of age.

In my previous speech I gave an example of how a particular, innocent individual was affected by this potential fraud indicator, and I raise another example here as I revisit this wonderful indicator of the RACV. Mr Alan Nikolic's car was stolen and burnt four years ago. The car was under finance and was about 10 months old when it was taken. What has the RACV done with respect to this particular case? In four years it has done nothing. What is the problem? Mr Nikolic has a foreign name, his policy was less than one year old, his car was under finance, it was stolen and burnt in the western suburbs, and the policy was to be renewed in two months time. These factors amounted to a crime, according to the RACV. RACV investigators told Mr Nikolic that fraud had been proven and so the police would be called in. Mr Nikolic encouraged them to do this because he wanted the issue brought to a head. However, the police were never called and the company refused to pay him out. Mr Nikolic then pursued legal avenues until he ran out of money; he was also paying the car finance company at the same time. Mr Nikolic's insurance agent then went to the Insurance Inquiries and Complaints Commission, who found nothing wrong with the RACV's actions.

What is really dishonest here is that the RACV did not tell the finance company that the car had been stolen because they did not wish to pay anyone out. They actually did not want to deal with a company that had the power and money to take them on; they only wanted to take on a little person like Mr Nikolic. As I said, this case has not been settled after four years. The example illustrates the need for an independent assessor, funded by separate sources, to oversight the insurance industry—especially the RACV—and not the Insurance Inquiries and Complaints Commission which is paid for by the insurance companies.

I cite another example of an individual who has had some interesting experiences with respect to the RACV. Mrs Jenni Wati of Forest Hill was awarded almost $4,000 to cover repairs after taking the RACV to court. A chap rectified the problems after the RACV had tried twice. He was a crash repairer who had been operating as one of their agents for some four or five years, but the RACV seemed to have a difficulty with him after he started to bring to their attention the fact that he was unhappy with the way they were conducting their affairs. Despite him being extremely competent and repairing cars like Ferraris and Lamborghinis et cetera, the RACV had an issue with him. It is interesting to note what magistrate Hal Hallenstein said about the RACV's repair centres:

quote.para: The issue is, one or other is reasonable ... or one or other is unreasonable. This is not a simple cost of repairs. RACV say they can be done cheaper, but they have done an inadequate job because they were cheap.

speech.para: In 1999 Mr Herfords, who is one of the people connected with the RACV insurance, said on 3LO:

quote.para: If we went to the repairer with the lowest quote we would be putting a lot of vehicles back on the road that aren't being repaired in accordance with how they ought to be repaired.

speech.para: The words do not actually seem to match the actions or the court case. There is another instance, a Mr Lima of Lilydale. Mr Lima was unfortunate enough to run into an RACV-insured vehicle. This is bad enough, but in the subsequent weeks he finds out, through the person he has crashed into, that the RACV has got three quotes, including one from its own repair centre, which was the most expensive. The quotes were: $1,229; $1,002; and for the RACV, the finest repairers in the business, some $2,044. That is some $800 more than anyone else. Luckily, Mr Lima caught out the RACV and wrote to them. They have not followed up on that claim against Mr Lima because they were caught out. It is instructive to look at the RACV marketing brochure. In the quality standards section it says:

quote.para: Repair quality is difficult, if not impossible for the average person to judge. It is an unfortunate fact that a minority of crash repairers are dishonest.

speech.para: The question for us here looking at his matter is to judge for ourselves who is being dishonest about this. I would like to cite another case, the case of Mr Vonic. Mr Vonic had a crash and sought the services of Mr Gerry Raleigh. Well, did he get the runaround. The RACV even went so far as to say that Mr Raleigh was black-banned and that Mr Vonic would have to pay for the repairs himself and then wait for a cheque. Sadly for Mr Vonic, he had to pay for the car himself, because the RACV would not pay for it at that time, and then wait for the RACV's cheque. He actually had to borrow the money to exercise his choice. But that is not how the Insurance Council of Australia believes the industry should work. I would like to quote Mr Ron Frail:

quote.para: The Trade Practices Act prevents insurers forcing someone where to go.

speech.para: Here is Mr Herford's response on 3LOin April 1999:

quote.para: It's hardly in our interests or the best interests of our customers to be involved in any nonsense such as paybacks, and I think in the circumstances there are deeper reasons for our lack of relationship with Gerry and his panel shop.

speech.para: My question is: whom do you believe? Part of the scandal of this is that people believe that the car insurer should have the primary relationship with the crash repairer, and that basically car insurance companies should be the ones dictating how the repairs should be done. That is a falsehood that has been perpetuated by the insurance companies and is leading to a lot of the misunderstanding and—dare I say it—fraud that exists at the present time. I would like to bring to this chamber's attention the fact that I have in my possession a legal opinion which completely disputes that commonly held belief. It is, I believe, an opinion that has been tendered to Mr Alan Fels and the ACCC. I would like to cite selected quotes from it:

quote.para: The relationship between the insured and the insurer is the same in the context of motor vehicle insurance when compared with any other policy. Therefore, the relationships between the insured, the insurer and the repairer are the same in the context of household insurance, for example, as it is in motor vehicle insurance. Because of the volume of work handled by motor vehicle repairers there may be a closer liaison between the insurer and the repairer which has led to an apparent distortion of those relationships.

speech.para: It gives an example of when a vehicle gets repaired:

quote.para: Accordingly, if the car owner gains two or three quotations for the repair of the vehicle, it is up to the car owner to decide who will repair the vehicle—

speech.para: not the RACV—

quote.para: If the quotation from the owner's choice of repairers is higher than the insurance policy would allow, then the owner would be responsible for the difference between the insurance payment and the account rendered by the repairer.

This could arise in many circumstances. For example, the car owner may decide to have some other work attended to or he simply prefers the standard of work by a particular repairer even though the cost may be above market rates.
The point is, the contract of insurance is between the car owner and the insurance company.
There is not, and never has been, any contract between the insurance company and the repairer. There is, in fact, no legal relationship between the two at all.

speech.para: Contrary to what is implied by the insurance companies—

quote.para: The contract to repair the vehicle is made with the customer i.e. the owner of the motor vehicle.

Accordingly, the car owner has two contracts. Firstly, a policy of insurance with the insurance company to cover damage to his vehicle. Secondly, when a vehicle is damaged, the car owner will then make another contract with the repairer to affect the necessary repairs.
The role of the insurance company in the repair of the vehicle should be limited purely to the role of paying for those repairs to the extents covered under the policy of insurance.

We are all aware of course that because of the muscle flexed by insurance companies and the reliance that repairers have upon the work provided by insurance companies, they have learnt that they are able to exert a great deal of pressure on the repairers and in many ways may have gone beyond their contractual relationship with the car owner.
For example—

speech.para: this is absolutely scandalous—

quote.para: it is not uncommon for the insurance company to direct the repairer to use secondhand or imitation parts. This often occurs without consultation with the car owner. When looking at this process in the context of the contractual arrangements detailed earlier in this article, you will see that there is no contractual relationship between the insurer and the repairer. The insurer—

speech.para: such as the RACV, the NRMA or a number of other organisations that conduct their affairs in this manner—

quote.para: therefore has no right, or authority in a legal sense to make any such direction to the repairer whatsoever.

The insurer, if it wishes to follow this course, must approach the customer and if the customer agrees then the repairer can install the secondhand or imitation part. If then, as a repairer, the insurance company tells you the manner in which the works are to be affected and you, as the repairer, are aware that that may be contrary to the customers wishes, then you should advise the insurance company that they should consult with the car owner direct to gain their written authority or in turn you should contact the car owner to determine whether they are happy to follow the requests of the insurance company.

speech.para: The opinion states also:

quote.para: You will see from the considerations relating to contract, that the insurance company cannot direct either the repairer or the car owner as to how these repairs are going to be affected.

speech.para: But quite clearly that is not the case. Basically, this is happening all the time. I would like to quote more but time does not permit. The opinion concludes:

quote.para: In summary, it is important to realise at all times that the repairer has a contract to repair the vehicle with the car owner. There is and never has been any contract between the insurance company and the repairer. All instructions to repair a vehicle must come from the car owner. Any direction from the insurance company must be agreed to, preferably in writing by the car owner before the work is effected on the particular vehicle.

speech.para: This does not occur in the car insurance industry. I ask the ACCC and others who are supposed to be monitoring this industry: why do consumers not know this? It is costing consumers a large amount of money that they might not otherwise have to pay. It is also, basically, ensuring that cars are put back on the road after being repaired with second-hand and bodgie parts without the consumer's knowledge or consent. In my belief that is an absolute scandal, which should be addressed by the relevant government agency and/or body but to this point of time does not appear to have been addressed.

I had intended to talk about three cases, but I will have time for only two. The first concerns one of my constituents who served in the Navy and, in his view, has been betrayed by it. We have heard from Roger Price about some of the difficulties that exist within the bureaucracy of the military establishment.

Mr Graeme Griffiths has been involved in two tragic incidents when serving Australia in the Navy. On 3 June 1969, Graeme was serving on HMAS Melbourne when it was involved with USS Evans in a disaster. He, like many others serving at the time, has never fully recovered and has been left with mental scars which will never disappear. However, later in that year, in November 1969, a sublieutenant sexually harassed Graeme when he was still a junior officer. He reacted violently to this attack by the sublieutenant. Afterwards he was hospitalised due to severe distress, and he was later discharged. Immediate assessments of Mr Griffiths after these incidents rated his disability at 30 per cent. This took account of the sexual harassment but excluded the HMAS Melbourne disaster, which has ruined the lives of many people who survived it. A Navy doctor made this assessment but no counselling was provided for either incident in which Graeme suffered. Since then Mr Griffiths has led a tortured life. He has not been able to hold down jobs, he was divorced once and his ability to deal with day-to-day life has been getting worse, according to his psychiatrists. Current specialists rate his incapacity for loss of mental powers for work at 40 per cent, and the median level of impairment at 30 per cent. All reports indicate that this impairment relates back to his Navy service.

Immediately after Graeme decided to leave the Navy, the Commonwealth Medical Officer assessed him for defence forces retirement benefits and allocated him an incapacity for civil employment at 15 per cent. As a consequence of this assessment, Mr Griffiths received a payout to the grand total of $490—not much compensation for so much suffering. Today Mr Griffiths is still fighting the various institutions to seek proper compensation. At first he approached the Defence Personnel Executive, in May 2000, to see if he could be considered for an invalidity pension through the superannuation fund.

They told him that, since he was assessed at 15 per cent incapacity at the time and discharged medically unfit, a retrospective benefit could not be paid. Effectively, he needed an act of grace for reconsideration. Sadly for Mr Griffiths, he was not aware of his rights at the time of discharge and was totally unaware he was discharged as medically unfit with a 15 per cent incapacity. Currently, Mr Griffiths is dealing with Comsuper, trying to push his case along.

Unfortunately, all institutions continue to ask for medical reports from the 1970s, but they were never conducted properly by the Navy. One only assessment by the Navy assessed Graeme at 30 per cent incapacity but, to date, others, which vary, such as the Commonwealth Medical Officer's report, seem to hold sway. The fact that the Commonwealth Medical Officer was not a specialist in the area of post-traumatic stress disorder and did not include the incident of the HMAS Melbourne did not seem to matter—just a sort of a small accident obviously.

At 15 per cent Graeme is not entitled to much. At the moment Mr Griffiths is waiting for the slow wheels of bureaucracy to move. He may have a claim with the Department of Veterans' Affairs through the Military Compensation and Rehabilitation Service or possibly through the Veterans Entitlement Act 1986. It all seems very slow and wrong. Graeme Griffiths did try in 1980 to make a compensation claim, but his medical condition did not allow him to follow through. I call on the minister to see if we can provide some justice after such a long time for friends of Mr Griffiths who have allegedly committed suicide after sexual harassment. I have a statutory declaration that basically states that four people have committed suicide, allegedly due to sexual harassment. They will have some level of restitution, albeit too late. We hope that they will receive justice. We also hope that Mr Griffiths will receive justice. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The appropriation bills give members the opportunity to review the government's performance and look at where and how Australia's taxpayers' money has been spent. It is the time when, as a member of parliament, I can look at the government's legislation as a whole and ascertain whether or not the people I represent in this parliament are being governed fairly and whether or not this government is directing money into programs that benefit them or disadvantage them.

speech.para: I am sure that some of the programs in the legislation that the government passes do benefit some Australians. But the people in the Shortland electorate and in a number of areas throughout Australia are really hurting because they are finding it very hard to make ends meet. Unfortunately, when it comes to the Howard government the verdict is a very sad and sorry one. Not only is this government failing to deliver services and programs to the people of Shortland and Australia; it is actively discriminating against many ordinary Australians, and that really makes me sad. Many of those people end up in my office and, I am sure, in many of the other members' offices with their problems, telling us just how much they are hurting. Believe me, they really are hurting.

Since I have worked as a member of parliament I have never had to put so many ordinary Australians—people that have always managed to make ends meet—in touch with charitable organisations to help them pay their electricity bills, their water bills or their telephone accounts. These are families, pensioners and unemployed Australians, people that are finding it hard to find a job because of the structural changes within our economy and people who are sick. They include people with small businesses and motorists.

In Australia we have a Prime Minister that has said he is totally committed to winning the next election. What does this mean for the Australian people? Do they want a Prime Minister that is totally committed to winning the next election? Or do they want a Prime Minister that is going to lead a government that will put through legislation that will benefit them, set in place a future for their children, protect the environment they live in and make sure that as a country we have the knowledge, the technology, the education and the skills that we need to embrace the millennium?

If we have a Prime Minister who is committed to winning an election, he is going to react to all the populist issues within the community. We have seen that with the reduction in the petrol excise recently. Let me put on record that I welcome that reduction, but I believe that it was too little, too late. For a very long time, Australians were saying they could not manage, they were struggling and finding it hard to manage with petrol at the price it was; the GST had increased the price of petrol but the government did not listen. The Prime Minister said, `Sorry, we can't afford it.' But, given the fact that he is committed to winning the next election rather than governing Australia, when he was faced with electoral defeat he decided to act on petrol prices. This is sad, because it is sad for Australia. We need a Prime Minister that is there to lead Australia and do what is best for our country, and not just react.

We found a similar situation with the BAS statement. For a long time, I am sure government backbenchers were telling the Prime Minister and the Treasurer just how hard it was for small business. I know that they were ringing my office and telling me about the problems that they were having. A little later I will go into some of the details of just two small businesses that I have been dealing with over the BAS statements. There have been many people that have had problems, but it was only when the government felt, and only when the Prime Minister felt, that the commitment to winning the next election might not come to fruition unless he changed his position did he and his Treasurer and his government actually listen to the people of Australia. I do not believe that that is good enough. There has never been a government that has caused more hurt to the people of Australia than this, I have to say, mean-spirited Howard government.

I am sure the GST, on paper, looked very good to the government but, unfortunately, for the people of Australia, it has not been so kind. It is a tax that taxes every Australian every day in so many different ways. You cannot eat without having the GST impact in some way. Certain foods are supposed to be GST free, but the GST does impact on the price of food, all food, indirectly if not directly. I have already touched on petrol and the impact that the GST has had on the price of petrol. Education is GST free? Tell that to the mums and dads who have to buy the uniforms, the schoolbooks, the school cases and all the clothes that students need to go to school. They will tell you that education is not GST free. The GST impacts on health. It impacts on the price that is charged for so many different health services, yet the government does not acknowledge this. It has not acknowledged the hurt that it is causing the Australian people. With respect to services, I touched on telephones, electricity, gas, insurance, taxis, restaurants and all those things that previously were untaxed.

Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I know that in your own area you have felt the impact the GST has had on residents of caravan parks, who are now faced with having to pay a GST on their rental. It is a very harsh tax and it is the linchpin of the government's policy; it is the linchpin of the government's fundraising or taxing policy. It is a policy that has really hurt Australian people and has caused so much hardship. The pensioners in Australia are hurting and hurting in many ways. This week we have seen the government's policy on clawback.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —The policies of the Howard government are designed to drag Australia back to the 1950s when the rest of the world is embracing the new millennium. We have a Prime Minister with a vision of Australia that begins with the picket fence. His Australian dream is all about the wife staying at home looking after the children—that is his idea of social order: he sits in his Chesterfield lounge and looks back to the 1950s.

speech.para: There has never been a government that has caused more hurt or been more mean spirited than this government. Pensioners in Australia have been very disillusioned by the performance of the government. Prior to 1 July last year they were looking forward to receiving a $1,000 savings bonus. It has been argued by the government that it was always a bonus for saving, but pensioners thought this was being given to them to help them cope with the effects of the GST. That, coupled with the fact that they believed they had been given a four per cent pay rise to help them cope with the effects of the GST, has caused them quite a deal of angst, particularly when they have found out that now they will not be given an increase in their pension in March because a clawback principle was put in place in the GST legislation. I have had pensioners sitting in my office with tears rolling down their faces, saying that they feel dehumanised by this government and that they feel worthless. They feel that the government does not value them enough to pay them a decent savings bonus or give them a decent rise in their pension. It is a very sad state of affairs that, in a country like Australia, older Australians are feeling so devalued.

This government has a philosophy that if you work hard and save then you should be rewarded. I do not think anyone would argue with that principle, but the converse of that is that if you have not saved then you must not have worked hard and therefore you do not deserve anything or you are just undeserving. That does not take into account that things happen in a person's life. They can work really hard and try their best to save, but they may have an accident and find they have to finish work earlier than they intended, which can really affect their plans for retirement, or they may be retrenched—and we all know how industries have restructured in recent times. All these little accidents of life can change a person's plans for retirement. It is not that they are lazy, it is not that they are not prepared to work hard; rather, it is that they have not been as lucky as some other people. When we see that tax breaks are given by the government to benefit their mates in big business, looking after the big end of town, it really is hard to come to terms with this. We find banks with record profits, and their CEOs receiving salaries in one year that people would dream about receiving in a lifetime. The government has backed off on the family trust legislation. When you look at the favourable treatment that has been given to Kerry Packer as far as taxation is concerned, you cannot help but sympathise with pensioners and the way they feel.

There has never been a government so determined to disadvantage ordinary Australians and to deliver profits and rewards to their friends. The divide between people who are wealthy and those who are poor has never been greater. As recently as last Sunday I was reading an article in the Sun-Herald that talked about how 50 per cent of people who live in Sydney have never been better off on, how they have money to spend on entertainment and recreation. But there is another story that is hidden away: there are people who are struggling from day to day to survive. In our history there has never been a greater gap between those people who have and those who have not.

This government has boasted that it is a party for small business, but all this government has done for small business is to cause it hardship, to increase its workload and to turn it into a tax collector for the government. The BAS has been a fiasco. I will share with members the story of two businesses in the Shortland electorate. One is an appliance business. It worked on rebuilding whitegoods and then selling them. It also repaired washing machines, dryers and those types of goods. With the introduction of the GST, half of its business disappeared. The selling of the rebuilt machines went out the door—that was three jobs gone, three people out of work. Now the owner is facing another dilemma. He had been battling with the BAS, and he had been under the impression that he could claim back all his GST. He became very confused and annoyed because he could not get anything in writing. Recently he sold his old vehicles and bought new vehicles, and he thought that he could reclaim the GST back on the new vehicles. As we know, that is not the case, but he did not know that. He has since found out that there are things that he cannot claim back, and he has asked for a list of them from the tax office. The tax office has told him, `There is no such list. If you want to find out whether you have to pay GST on something or not, you are going to have to ring us each time to get an individual ruling.' I can tell you that this is one angry small businessman. He has lost half of his business, and now he is in total confusion about what he can claim the GST on and what he cannot.

I was talking to the owner of another business—a mixed business—on the Central Coast that is doing very well with a large turnover of just under $1 million, and she was telling me that she has to spend half a day a week away from the shop, which means employing extra staff. It takes her four hours to reconcile accounts and then another two hours to do paperwork. She is finding it really hard to cope with.

These are only two businesses that I am talking about but, believe me, the government ignores at its peril the hardship, the difficulties and the hours of extra work that small businesses are having to put in just to meet the GST BAS requirements. Every day there is a new problem. The Labor Party traditionally has not attracted a lot of small business people to join it, but you would be surprised at the number of small business people, just within the Shortland electorate, who have recently joined the Labor Party and who have offered to help me during the election. I think the government really stands condemned for what it has done to small businesses in Australia. It has taken away their hope, and it has transferred all the hard work—the tax burden—onto them.

Another area in which the government has failed the Australian people is health. There is a dramatic decline in bulk-billing, as I have mentioned many times in the House. The government has done nothing to address this issue; it has no commitment to Medicare. Another tragedy is its action of removing the Commonwealth mental health scheme, which has caused so much hardship for pensioners and families in our community. Its performance in the education area leaves a lot to be desired. Seventy per cent of Australian students attend public schools and 30 per cent attend private schools. It is an absolute disgrace that the government is funding category 1 schools at the level that it is. It is such a disgrace. Public schools are feeling so discriminated against that, on 15 March, they are holding a public education day, so that they can get out there and sell to the community what they are doing in their schools. The money has been taken out of the schools that really need it and has been put into those schools that are wealthy.

Trinity Grammar School is one of those schools that will benefit from it and will be in receipt of an extra $5 million a year from the federal Treasury. Whilst it is receiving this—a subsidy of over $1,700 per student—an average government school student will be receiving $5 extra per year. Please tell me where the equity is there—I cannot see it. Seventy per cent of the students are getting $5 while a student attending Trinity is receiving $1,700.

The Prime Minister has repeatedly told the Australian people that the government could not afford to reduce the excise on petrol. But guess what? That was before he rolled over on petrol. Instead of investing money in petrol and giving relief to Australian motorists he told us that he would put money into the Roads to Recovery program. Obviously I support putting money into the Roads to Recovery program, but the thing that was so dishonest about it was the accounting mechanism that was put in place and the way that the government misled the Australian people by double-dipping and double counting every bit of money they put into the roads. Senator Tierney in the Hunter put out information that said that $44 million was going to our area when in fact there was only $25 million. Appropriations provide a broad umbrella for the government's legislation. Unfortunately this legislation is an umbrella for legislation that disadvantages ordinary Australians, making it harder for them to put food on the table and forcing them to choose between the necessities of life. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2000-2001, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2000-2001 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2000-2001. I notice within these particular bills that there is no provision for funding of employment programs. I want to address my comments to the lack of attention being paid to unemployment and employment issues in this country at this time. It is particularly timely to be looking at employment issues in the context of the recent slowdown in the economy evidenced by the ongoing drop in building approvals, ANZ job ads down a further 10 per cent in February, and retail sales volumes down 0.1 per cent in the December quarter on a year earlier. This is the first time sales volumes have fallen year on year for two quarters in a row since 1991—a very worrying sign. This is on top of the other economic data of recent weeks showing full-time employment down 87,300 in just four months, inflation at a 10-year high, business confidence faltering and the dollar at a record low.

speech.para: I would like to make some observations about the human catastrophe of unemployment and some of the myriad of possible solutions. When researching this topic I was concerned to find that issues concerning unemployment appear to have fallen off the political radar screen. Newspapers rarely editorialise about unemployment; the government rarely raises it other than to promote its lopsided mutual obligation theory. It is even difficult to find discussions of it within the world of academia. This is why I was so pleased to have land on my desk a document called Pathways to work: preventing and reducing long-term unemployment, a collaborative effort between the Australian Council of Social Service, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Business Council of Australia and the Dusseldorp Skills Forum, amongst others. This call to arms is also backed up by quantitative polling that shows that jobs are still a key issue in the minds of all Australians. Reducing the unemployment rate must always be a goal of all good governments. The economic costs and threats to our financial security that sustained unemployment brings cannot be underestimated. Pathways to work notes one of the economic costs as a five to six per cent loss of GDP. The Boston Consulting Group estimates that the public costs for a year of unemployment will vary from $51,000 in the case of a 21-year-old earning $15,000 year prior to unemployment, to $146,900 in the case of a 50-year-old white-collar worker on a pre-unemployment income of $42,000 per annum. Most families with at least with one income earner out of work live below the Henderson poverty line. Unemployment leads to an increase in the need for affordable public housing stock and the attendant drain on the welfare support system.

However, we must never forget the social cost. Long-term unemployment is a truly soul-destroying experience for not only the unemployed person but their whole family. Not only are unemployed people more likely to be in poor health but they also suffer from more chronic disease. The poverty experienced by unemployed parents will often decrease the educational opportunities of their children, not to mention the increased risk of family breakdown. Intergenerational unemployment is a new phenomenon, as many parents unable to find work see their own children struggle with unemployment. In some households no-one has a job. Some of the other grinding effects of unemployment result in people suffering from a loss of self-confidence and self-worth, often leading to a spiralling cycle of depression, alcoholism and even suicide.

What we also know is that unemployment affects Australia in a disproportionate manner. Regional areas have been hit hard, whether they be on the outskirts of major cities, in the heart of the bush or in towns whose industries have suffered from the unrelenting winds of globalisation. The member for McMillan opposite can speak, probably at greater length, about this in his electorate. He has seen it all too often. ABS figures show that the profile of a long-term unemployed person tends to be a person who is without formal skills and education. Older workers and younger people are particularly at risk. The Boston report for the Business Council, which is published in Pathways to work, points out:

quote.para: ... major life transitions such as the school to work transition and the termination-back-to-work transition are the key stages when people are at risk of long-term unemployment. It is estimated these 2 groups make up to 50% of entries into long-term unemployment.

speech.para: Like most members of this House, I have heard heart-rending stories from constituents in my electorate of Chisholm about their battles to find a job. It is particularly this group of people who have been terminated and are trying to get back into the work force whom I have come across time and time again. It is tragic because there is nothing special for them. They are a distinct group of individuals. They have probably been with one company for 15, 20 or 30 years. They may only be 45 years of age and suddenly they are now without a job and without the skills to get a job. There do not seem to be any programs out there to assist these individuals, particularly men who have worked in middle management and have been made redundant, unable to find a job.

I had one individual who came to me and said, `Look, it seems like a silly thing, but 12 months ago I could pay my MCG membership. Nowadays I can't. I have paid it for all my life. I pride myself on being able to take my son and my grandson to the cricket, and I can't.' This man was a fairly senior individual on a high executive salary who thought that he would have no problems in getting another job. He has been out of work now for five years and has only been able to pick up casual bits of work. It has totally demoralised him and it has, tragically, led to the breakdown of his family. Many women who have taken years out of the work force to raise children find their skills are out of date and no-one will rehire them. I had a youngish woman in my office the other day who had taken several years out of the work force to go and look after her small children and was finding it increasingly difficult to be recognised with her teaching skills to get back into the sector in Victoria. I am pleased to say that things have improved now that we have a state Labor government. I was seeing a lot more women in this situation when the Liberals were in power in Victoria, because they had dramatically reduced the number of teaching places and this was a great impost on women trying to return to the work force. I have also seen young people who have finished school or university only to find they can only get a couple of hours work a week or contract labour, three months here or three months there, with no hope of ever getting a loan from a bank to buy a car, go on a trip or—God help us—actually purchase their first home. I have also come across 50-year-olds who are told they are simply too old to get a job and they should forget about the paid work force and take up a hobby or do volunteer work. The thing that most people do not realise is that a lot of people at 50 still have young families to support. They still have kids going through school. They still have mortgages to pay and they cannot afford to be on the work scrap heap, nor do they choose to be on the work scrap heap.

The rapid changes to the world economy have left many people behind. As jobs in the manufacturing and primary industries have either been moved offshore or been made redundant by technology, the new economy has not provided the transitional jobs to accommodate these dislocated workers. The demographic trends in Australia mean this issue will exacerbate rather than ease the problems of mature age unemployment. The percentage of the population aged between 45 and 65 will rise until 2011 and then taper off. As the baby boomer generation moves into this age group, there will be an even greater need to look at strategies to assist mature age people to find work.

So what can governments do? This is obviously an enormous question but I would like to look at a few suggestions primarily addressing the issues of young people and mature age workers. The school to work transition is a crucial time for young people. This is where we need to provide as many opportunities as possible to help young people avoid long-term unemployment. Young people must have ready access to meaningful further education, ongoing vocational training or employment. Young people need quality careers counsellors to ensure they are made aware of which industries are growing and job rich and which industries are not offering good job prospects. Young people must leave school with basic skills that are valued by employers. We must have adequate amounts of TAFE and university places available for those who want to study, and we must also provide sufficient traineeships and apprenticeships.

This brings me to an issue that I think we should be discussing more and that I have often discussed in my electorate, particularly with training providers. Not very far from my office is a wonderful organisation known as Inner Eastern Group Training. They replicate many group training schemes, I am sure, around the country. There is a fantastic woman there called Sharon Strugnell. She is a forward thinking person in a forward thinking and wonderful organisation. She has often told me that one of the biggest problems they are facing at the moment is encouraging young people to take up trade based apprenticeships, such as electrical, plumbing or cabinet-making apprenticeships.

It appears the problems are varied. Young people are often not attracted by the idea of four years of study and work when they can do a 12-month so-called New Apprenticeship. From the employer side, they are often reluctant to take on a 16-year-old and give them the attention they need. They simply do not have the time to deal with some of the teething problems that come with teenagers fresh to the job market. Probably the most concerning element is the apparent lack of parental and general community support for apprenticeships. Whilst no-one would deny that vocational education and training is one of the keys to reducing long-term unemployment, it has led to a decline in trades work. Society has deemed it lowly to be a tradesperson. As I will tell anybody in this place, the only decent relative I have is my brother-in-law, who is a plumber. It is as if being only a cabinet-maker is somehow undignified. This is an elitist view and is both unhelpful and wrong. Not all young people want to be doctors or lawyers. Some of them will never fit into an office environment and prefer to work outdoors or with their hands. We will always need electricians, plumbers, cabinet-makers, et cetera.

Many people prefer the flexibility of a 12-month traineeship. These jobs are generally available in the areas of hospitality and office administration. The irony is that, once a young person has completed their apprenticeship, they can usually set up a small business and their earnings will exceed those of most of their peers who have completed a traineeship or struggled through a generalist university course. It is a real shame that jobs such as these that provide a steady job path for many young people—in particular many working-class kids—are now shunned as substandard and perceived as worthless.

Sharon Strugnell has told me that it is often the parents of children who are not willing to provide the transport and the family support needed to enable a young person to complete an apprenticeship. One of her ideas—undoubtedly shared by many people in her field—identifies a need to make apprenticeships more attractive to both young people and employers alike. One proposal is to provide a qualification at the completion of each year of the four-year apprenticeship, describing at the completion of each year what the apprentice has learnt and how it can be applied in a job setting. This would help raise the status of apprentices and apprenticeships alike and may even lead to young people being able to take up other jobs without needing to complete the four years study. As with all matters related to the scourge of unemployment, we need to be lateral in our thinking and I think this idea is worthy of consideration. Making apprenticeships more attractive to young people is part of the answer, but in order to really build our labour force we need to direct our young people into vocational training and education and, in some cases, into labour market programs.

At the end of last year I was pleased to present the certificates to the individuals from Inner Eastern Group Training who were completing apprenticeships and traineeships. But I was very saddened to see that I was giving out only eight certificates for people who had completed their apprenticeships. It was a sad indictment—although not on Inner Eastern Group Training, because they are out there struggling to get the jobs. Last year they actually had more apprenticeships than they could find kids to take them up, because everybody has been turned off it. I think it is something that we really need to drastically turn our minds to.

Labour market programs are where Labor's plans for a knowledge nation are so important. We need to approach skill shortages in an aggressive and targeted manner. We need to look at the mismatch between the skills many workers have and the ones we need and this can be done through vocational education and training, starting at primary school. At the other end of the scale, we also need to utilise the benefits of vocational education and training and labour market programs for the mature age unemployed. One of the recommendations in the Pathways to work document reads:

quote.para: Employers, unions and employment assistance and training providers, should work together at the local and regional level to develop employment assistance packages for workers facing retrenchment who are at high risk of long-term unemployment.

speech.para: Labor's spokesperson, Cheryl Kernot, has already announced that we plan to target training opportunities through our work force skill profiles, to assist at-risk workers before they become unemployed. We will work with employers, unions and training providers to appropriately train and retrain for emerging job opportunities. This will be part of Labor's overall continuum of training. As part of this approach we will ensure that a Labor government honours its responsibilities in reciprocal obligation contracts, by providing basic accredited training under programs based on a work for the dole scheme. This would be particularly useful in regional areas, where it is relatively easy to predict, for example, that the local timber or manufacturing industry is about to downsize or shut. Employers must begin to acknowledge that they have a responsibility to provide transitional assistance to their staff who in many cases have served them loyally for a number of years.

The other area we need to look at is labour market programs. The federal government had cut these programs from $2.7 million to $1.5 million by 1998-99. Labor's Working Nation program introduced the concept of reciprocal obligation by promising the long-term unemployed either employment or training though a system of job subsidies. It was an expensive program that enabled many long-term unemployed people to retrain and re-enter the work force. Upon taking office, the coalition replaced these programs with the delivering of employment assistance via the government purchasing employment services on a fee for service basis, as described in the research paper `Changes to employment assistance' by Steve O'Neill of the Parliamentary Library. Through the Job Network, the coalition has sought to promote job matching. This has been done with a background of severe cuts to the old CES, now Centrelink, and a flawed tendering process.

I do not need to go through the countless stories of the disaster that we have seen with Centrelink and Job Network providers. Not long after I took up office in Box Hill, I had a young lady come to see me. She had applied for 62 jobs in the last three weeks through a Job Network provider. Not one of those 62 jobs ever amounted even to a letter to say she had not got the job. They were just generating all this angst for this young individual that never resulted in any employment. She came to see me after three weeks, she came to see me after six weeks, she came to see me about a year later and she was still unemployed. She must have done thousands of job applications on the advice of the Job Network provider and out of them she had two interviews. This was just totally inappropriate. They were just fobbing her off, saying, `You match this job; you match this job.'

In my previous employment before parliament I worked with the Finance Sector Union and had seen the major banks decide that the best way to make people redundant was to offer them outsourcing and job matching with `wonderful people like Drake Employment' and other such wonderful organisations! They would lock a whole lot of people in a room and say, `Here's a typewriter. Do a CV and that will magically get you a job.' Funnily enough, it never did. It is just a short-sighted way of fobbing people off and it is tragic, because these people are at their most vulnerable at that point in time and that is when they need the greatest assistance, and they are not getting it from this government. It is my view that we need to relook at the labour market programs and how they can be utilised to help compensate the many `casualties' that have been created from economic restructuring such as tariff reductions and public sector cuts. We owe it to this group of people, mainly the mature aged and those living in the bush, to help them overcome their displacement and retrain them.

Just briefly, I would also like to make mention of the recent announcement by Labor's shadow minister for employment, my colleague Cheryl Kernot. Last week she announced that a future Labor government will ensure that the Australian Bureau of Statistics asks those who have been defined as `not in the labour force' plus those who are underemployed as well as those who have a job: `How many hours did you work and how many did you want to work?' With this information, governments can deal more honestly with the complexity and diversity of the unemployment problem. We do not know how many hours people want to work. We do not know precisely how many people are underemployed. We have very little idea how `efficient' the labour market really is. The reason we do not know these things is because we do not ask the right questions. The proposal will put policy makers in a better position to judge the true needs of not only those unemployed but those who are underemployed.

I think this is most telling at a time when we know that there are lots of people in the work force who are chronically overemployed, who are working an excessive number of hours, often for no pay. This is a complete mishmash. The people out there often say, `What are we going to do about it?' I am sure there is no easy answer, but I think we need to look at the problem realistically. We need to ask the questions that will lead us some way to resolving this problem.

In conclusion, I am sure all members acknowledge that there is no one solution to the unemployment crisis that has beset the Western world since the 1970s. As with all complex political issues, we must consult closely with the Australian people and look at a broad range of solutions. The traditional churn between Keynesian pump priming and economic rationalism has failed to produce a climate of full employment. As legislators, we must prepare to open our minds and our hearts to find the array of solutions to this blight on our society. I think it is about time some of us started to reconsider this issue, which is genuinely of interest to our local communities.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to contribute to this debate. Tonight I am going to deal with an issue critical to a lot of people in my electorate. I will be speaking mostly about the importation of apples from New Zealand, which poses a very serious risk to apple and pear growers in terms of fire blight, which contaminates many New Zealand apples. Tonight I want to communicate to the parliament, the Prime Minister and ministers exactly how strongly people in my constituency feel about this issue.

speech.para: This is a critical issue for many apple and pear growers in my constituency. We are, in Australia, still a sovereign nation, and we should be able to choose what comes in and out over our borders. However, I think a lot of people in the Australian government today think that their chief role is to aid and abet the World Trade Organisation to get their way to be able to get New Zealand apples into Australia, despite the fact that this poses a very serious risk to the livelihoods of many apple and pear growers throughout Australia. In particular, tonight I want to communicate very frankly and directly the views of my constituents, the apple and pear growers in my electorate, to the parliament, to the Prime Minister and to those people present.

I got in touch with the apple and pear growers in my constituency and asked them what they want this parliament to be aware of in terms of their views on the importation of New Zealand apples. I intend to read their comments directly into the Hansard tonight. I have a lot of comments to read out here, and I will do my best to get them all into the parliament, but I make this point before I begin: I have not heard a Liberal Party MP or a National Party MP speak out in this parliament about the very real risk that fire blight poses. I have yet to hear one of those people in this parliament stand up and say very plainly that they are against the importation of apples from New Zealand and that they will stand with their communities and the apple and pear growers in their electorates against the threat of disease, which stands to substantially damage the livelihoods of apple and pear growers throughout Australia.
This is what David McKenzie from Two Macs Fruits in my constituency had to say. This is his message:

quote.para: Is the Government prepared to compensate all Australian growers if the disease destroys our industry? Some of us are third generation fruit growers and believe that it is hard enough now to make a living. If this is allowed into the country, growers will simply walk away from their properties. We have a clean & green image, so why ruin it? Why even risk it? Our export markets are at risk with thousands of jobs at risk and devastation of the fruit growing economy will flow on if the federal government lets them in. Say NO to NZ apples.

speech.para: This is what Hayden Witchell from the business Golden Lodge had to say:

quote.para: Fireblight could, and most likely will, if NZ apples come into Australia, destroy the livelihood built up over four generations. Once fireblight is here it can never be eradicated. Using measures such as streptomycin to try to control this virulent disease will destroy Australia's fruit growing industry's green, clean image. We should be proud to have this image, and it should not be risked. By the way, who will compensate us for the loss of our livelihood?

speech.para: That is a very good question, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is what Julie and Brian Witchell from Witchell's Golden Apple Orchards had to say:

quote.para: We have a wonderful fruit growing industry in Australia, producing top quality fruit, as well as employing many, many people. Our `small' business has employed 84 people in the last 12 months. If we go broke as a result of fireblight destroying our orchards, the unemployment rate goes up again. The `Powers that Be' need to recognise our industry and protect it, not sacrifice it for the sake of not upsetting the WTO.

speech.para: This is what John Wiadrowski from Wiadrowski Orchards had to say:

quote.para: There is no time like the present for Australia to capitalise on its disease-free status. More and more, the world is facing disease epidemics, and it is time that we, as a country, used this to our advantage ... The present problem with Mad Cow Disease in the UK only exemplifies these comments. Australia must not jeopardise its trade advantages on this issue and for that reason, we must not allow the importation of New Zealand Apples.

speech.para: This is what C. and M. Harding from Harding's Orchard had to say:

quote.para: As a small to medium family orchard employing 22 people each year, we are totally opposed to New Zealand importing apples into Australia. We grow apples and pears and feel that the risk is far too great, especially for pears. Australia's clean green image around the world is in jeopardy. The introduction of New Zealand apples could end in the same outcome as the foot and mouth disease in Britain at present.

speech.para: This is what Glynn Fankhauser from G.E. and E. Fankhauser had to say:

quote.para: Mr Howard, we implore you to carefully consider the plight of Aussie growers should we ever get the disease we are a hands on 4th generation family of apple growers who have seen fireblight in New Zealand orchards and would never like to see it here. We have a good clean green industry that is improving in quality and professionalism. We compete well overseas in markets with no subsidies on what will never be a level playing ground. Please do not destroy all that we have worked for by permitting this or any other disease into our country.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker, there is still more to come. This is what Gavin and Samantha Bullen from N. and H. Bullen and Son in Drouin in my electorate had to say:

quote.para: As the fifth generation of Apple and Pear growers, with a great deal of our future riding on the industry, I am totally against the import of pome fruit from overseas under what has proven to be an inadequate protocol flawed in many areas.

There is not one country that has imported pome fruit from a country that already has Fire Blight and not ended up with it themselves. If we import apples from New Zealand, we will be putting our $320 million a year apple and pear industry in danger. Our industry could be wiped out if fire blight spreads across the Tasman. In 1988 New Zealand protocol was rejected by the Australian government—

speech.para: I point out that it was a Labor government in 1988—

quote.para: because it was believed that there was insufficient research evidence available to show that Fire Blight could not be imported on mature apples. In 1995—

speech.para: once again, still a Labor government—

quote.para: they applied again, and in December 1998, AQIS rejected application on the grounds that the proposal was not consistent with “Australia's appropriate level of protection for the disease.” Now New Zealand have applied again, asking for “the least trade restrictive access while delivering the level of protection deemed appropriate by AQIS.”

speech.para: He makes the following point:

quote.para: But isn't it a fact that if a Fire Blight country can import their apples into a country, then they can also import Fire Blight.

speech.para: That is a very commonsense contribution. Heather Bullen, from Drouin, also had this to say:

quote.para: Why should Australian growers be faced with a watering down of protocol in the Draft Import Risk Assessment when previous protocols have not allowed the importation of apples and pears due to the fireblight risk?

Australian Apple and Pear Growers should be able to continue to supply world markets with high quality fruit of a clean green status and should never be put at risk of the disease fire blight, which is world wide known to be such a devastating and extremely infectious disease to pome fruits.
A classic case is currently before the world market places with foot and mouth disease in the meat industry in England and Europe because of relaxation of regulations.

speech.para: Heather Bullen also makes the point:

quote.para: Ask any world apple or pear grower who has had to contend with fireblight in their orchards and you will find that once fireblight enters the country you will NEVER get rid of it.

speech.para: That is a very good point. This is what Neil Bullen, who runs an orchard at Drouin in my electorate, had to say:

quote.para: As producers of apples and pears over four generations, with a large investment in the pome fruit industry, we are totally against the import of apples from overseas under what has proven to be an inadequate protocol which is flawed in many areas ... The implications for the Australian apple & pear growers would be devastation of many of Australia's growing areas. The Australian Government should be mindful of what is happening currently in the UK and Europe with regards to foot and mouth disease when we do not have strict quarantine controls.

speech.para: This is what Wayne MacDougall from Orchard Apples and Peaches up at Labertouche in my electorate had to say:

quote.para: I, Wayne MacDougall, do not want New Zealand apples in Australia. The risk of fireblight here would be devastating. We don't need the apples here, why risk the chance of having the disaster happen.

speech.para: And at the bottom of his message he says, in relation to this issue:

quote.para: Thank you Christian Zahra for making the effort to try and help us.

speech.para: To sum up how the apple and pear growers in my electorate feel about this issue, I would like to communicate to the chamber the view of the Gippsland Fruitgrowers Association Inc. I have received a letter from Helene Armour, who heads this association and is also the Southern Victorian Fire Blight Task Force leader. She says:

quote.para: Australia is one of only a handful of countries in the world that is fire blight free. Fire blight, the foot and mouth disease of horticulture is now endemic in 43 of the world's pome fruit growing areas.
Gippsland's growers have had enough. We have proven our point that the DIRA—

speech.para: the draft import risk assessment—

quote.para: is scientifically flawed and therefore valueless. Our harvest is now in full swing. Our attention must be directed at picking, packing and selling quality fruit.

speech.para: That is the view of Helene Armour from the Gippsland Fruitgrowers Association. And those views I have quoted of the apple and pear growers in my electorate would be very typical of the views of the apple and pear growers right across Australia. I have tried tonight to give voice to the very legitimate concerns they have in relation to the very serious threat that fire blight poses to their businesses. A lot of these businesses have been built up over three, four and five generations. These are people who have shown a lot of guts, resilience, application and determination. They started without much and have been able to build great successful businesses, which they have passed from one generation to another and the next generation has been able to build on the success. That is the sort of effort which we should applaud, celebrate and hold up as an example of what we want other people in the Australian community to aspire to. Instead, what these people are getting for all the labour and hard work they have put into their businesses and the risks they have taken is a federal government which is an apologist for the World Trade Organisation, a federal government which is aiding and abetting the New Zealanders to get their apples—ridden as they are with fire blight—into Australian markets.

As we have heard, the people who have written to me know very well that if you get fire blight into Australia you will never get rid of it. There will be a huge cost to Australia's image as a clean, green producer of apples and pears and also a huge cost to those farming families who have contributed so much throughout the years by taking the risks and putting in their labour and effort to build up these successful businesses which, in many cases, are very large employers in electorates such as mine.

It is my contention that we should not have a situation where the federal government is aiding and abetting the World Trade Organisation against the interests of Australian apple and pear growers; rather, we should have a federal government which is proud of the effort that these people have put in over many years and is prepared to back them and defend all of the effort, the labour and the application that they have put into their farms. That is what this government should be doing right now. They should be saying that, if there is a risk of fire blight, we are not having those apples and pears from New Zealand coming into Australia. We are still a sovereign nation, and we have the right to protect our boundaries and to protect the people who live in our country from the substantial risk which exists in terms of the threat of disease from fire blight.

As I mentioned before, we have people from quite a few different political parties in this place—there are people from the Liberal Party, the National Party and even an Independent in here—and who is speaking up on behalf of apple and pear growers? I have not heard the National Party talking about it much. I certainly have not heard the Liberal Party talking about it much. It has fallen to us in the Australian Labor Party to defend the interests of apple and pear growers and to make sure that we do not have New Zealand apples coming into this country which are going to pose a substantial risk to those people who have been prepared to take substantial risks in their own right as individuals and build up successful businesses over a large number of years and who have been able to employ people as a result of that risk and their application and hard work. We are the people who are prepared to stand with the apple and pear growers of Australia against this risk. We are the ones who are now putting the pressure on the federal government to make sure that apples from New Zealand which carry the risk of fire blight—as they do—are not allowed into Australia.

I say to those people who are apple and pear growers living right across Australia—I think there are something like 43 federal electorates where the apple and pear industry is a very large employer—that the time has come to get active. They should be calling up their local member of parliament—whether they be Labor, Liberal, National or Independent—and saying to them: `What have you done for us? How are you representing our interests? What effort have you put in to make sure that the Australian apple and pear industry is protected from the risk that is associated with the importation of New Zealand apples?' If the answer is nothing, then those people should ask them again and pressure those members of parliament to come into the House and represent their interests. It has not taken a great effort on my part to get in touch with all the apple and pear growers in my electorate and let them know that I am giving this speech and to ask them if they wanted me to represent their interests in the remarks that I had to make tonight.

The view is very plain from apple and pear growers in relation to this issue. In fact, I would say that there would be almost 100 per cent agreement—complete consensus—in relation to how everyone feels in the apple and pear industry about the very real risk which is posed by the importation of apples from New Zealand, carrying, as they do, the very genuine threat of the importation of fire blight into Australia. So we have absolute consensus from the apple and pear growers and we have some representatives who are prepared to come into this place and stand up on behalf of these people, to advocate on behalf of them and to put their case, and we have not seen anything yet from the Howard government. That is not good enough. The Howard government, which has just gone through the doldrums in terms of the electoral support they have, should not really be surprised at all if that continues as long as they continue to ignore the very legitimate and genuine concerns of groups like the apple and pear growers of Australia.

These people have made an enormous contribution to Australia. They started with very little, they built successful businesses and they were able to build on those businesses throughout successive generations. These are the people about whom poetry has been written in Australia: the great risk takers. They are the people who have been prepared to go into parts of rural and regional Australia and get out there, break the land, bend their backs, take risks, endure hardship and build a great, thriving and growing industry in the apple and pear sector in Australia.

Instead of doing nothing for these people when they face this very genuine risk from New Zealand apples, the federal government should be saying to them, `We will stand with you, we will support you and we understand that the risk which you are talking about is not one which you are imagining, is not one which you have made up and is not an issue about you guys getting a subsidy. We understand that there is a very real risk that many of your orchards and properties will be substantially devalued if we allow this disease into our country.'

I reiterate clearly and passionately: Australia is still a sovereign nation. We should not kowtow to the likes of the World Trade Organisation. The role of the federal government is to stand with the apple and pear growers of Australia, not to aid and abet the World Trade Organisation and the New Zealand government to the detriment of apple and pear growers in Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Those of us who have been in public life for some time, like my friend and colleague here the member for Hinkler and yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, and even those who are somewhat younger in public life, like the member for McMillan, are very conscious of irony in politics and how certain myths build up. One of the stranger myths in the context of Australian politics at the moment is this view that in some way this present government are good economic managers and that one of the assets they have—many would say in public debate that it is their only asset—is that they are in some way good public managers. Frankly, this supposed credential of this government really does not stand up to close scrutiny.

speech.para: This country, blessed in all sorts of ways as it is, really ought to be much more economically successful than the indications now appear to suggest. In the energy sector, for example, we are producing in our trade of all fuels a surplus of $1 billion a month. We are a net oil exporter. The lower Australian dollar has produced all sorts of opportunities for this economy. I noticed in question time today that some debate was beginning to emerge about just how successful we have been in exports. However, the indications seem to be that for the December quarter there has been a significant increase in export revenue. Just seven months ago the economy seemed so strong that the Reserve Bank seemed to be intent on reining it in by their monetary policy.

The situation now, however, really seems to be causing considerable concern. This economy, blessed in all the ways that it is, is beginning to show some disturbing signs. If we compare Australia's economic performance to most of our trading partners—with the notable exception of Japan—they are all growing somewhat more rapidly than us. Last year's figures for Singapore, for example, in our own region of the world, were showing that economic growth was being achieved at some 11 per cent. A country that is seen as being very comparable to Australia in its economic structures, Canada, was growing at four per cent. We are simply not presently achieving those sorts of figures in Australia under these great economic managers.

In fact, the indication seems to be that we are about to achieve a home-grown slump. I say `home-grown' because our trading partners are not showing, by and large, the same sorts of concerning trends in their economic performances. In looking at who is responsible for these deteriorating circumstances, one really needs to sheet home the blame to these great economic managers we presently have!

Of all the factors that one can look at in the Australian economy and its performance, one would have to say that the new tax system is, frankly, a bit of a disaster in terms of our comparative performance. The joke of this new tax system, in terms of the productive sectors of the economy was, I suppose, most appropriately highlighted by the paltry sum of $200 that the government very kindly was handing out last year to businesses in my electorate and in those of the members for Hinkler and Batman, to try to make a contribution, a gesture, towards the costs that the businesses, the productive sector of the economy, were incurring in meeting the burdens that this new tax system has imposed on them. We are all aware from our own experience that, in most instances, even relatively small businesses have been incurring costs of anything up to 100 times that $200 that the government handed out as its contribution towards them meeting the obligations of the new tax system. We are also aware of the immense loss of productive effort that goes into the compliance aspects of this new taxation system.

Tragically, we are looking at the moment as if, in the six months to September at least, the estimated domestic final demand dropped by 0.5 per cent, and we are awaiting—possibly as early as tomorrow—new figures which are, frankly, going to be of considerable concern, I believe. The indicators are not good. Building approvals are down a further 3.7 per cent in January and down 40 per cent for the year—the biggest annual fall since at least 1984. I stress again that this is in a country that is blessed with massive economic strengths and massive advantages. The ANZ job ads figure was down a further 10 per cent in February and 24.1 per cent for the year—terrible figures.

None of us on this side of politics are trying to talk down the Australian economy; we are just desperately concerned that this team of great economic managers are running the place down. Retail sales volume is down one per cent in the December quarter on a year earlier—the first time sales volumes have fallen, year on year, two quarters in a row since 1991. Full-time employment is down by over 87,000 people in just four months, the period during which Mr Costello, the Treasurer, upgraded his employment growth forecast to three per cent. Business investment was down 5.2 per cent in the December quarter. Building works were down 23.6 per cent for the year to December. Inflation is at a 10-year high. Business confidence is in deep trouble, and the dollar is at record lows. As I say, this is a strange business because of the mythology, the view that I suppose a few of the scribes of the press continue to push, that in some way this mob in power are good economic managers. The reality is that they have produced, by their poor economic management, a huge set of lost opportunities for this country.

The broad ranging nature of the appropriations debate allows me an opportunity to get onto a subject that I had commenced to develop a little in adjournment speeches and the like, and that is the question of a serious injustice that a constitutent of mine faces in terms of his dealings with the military justice system. This constitutent, Mr Kevin Lee, is a gentleman who is highly regarded in my local community. He is a man who served Australia with distinction some 45 years ago, yet he finds himself in a very difficult situation in terms of getting the recognition he deserves from this country because of the operations of the military justice system.

This is a matter I have taken up in the past—back in 1998, in fact, with the then minister responsible, Mrs Bishop—and, frankly, I got nowhere. What has occurred in more recent times is that there has been a very significant intervention on behalf of my constitutent by a very prominent member of Australian military circles, Rear Admiral Kennedy. Rear Admiral Kennedy is a man whom the government—and I think also former governments—have used regularly for a whole range of tasks. He was, for example, involved up until fairly recently in a review of a number of anomalies in the veterans' affairs system, and he has intervened very strongly in support of my constitutent.

Let me read a letter that Rear Admiral Kennedy, a very distinguished sailor, wrote to the Chief of Navy on 9 February. I will not read the whole lot but I think it is important, given that there is a little more time on this occasion to address some of these issues, to read more of it. His letter to Admiral Shackleton reads:

quote.para: Dear David,

Knowing how busy you must be what with East Timor on top of the normal heavy burden, I am loath to tax you further with another. It is however important in that it relates to an alleged miscarriage of naval justice, with respect to a former shipmate, forty five years ago. Perhaps the Director of Naval Legal Services could spare the time to look into it.

The alleged miscarriage was brought to my attention some months ago as a result of the publicity ... given to the very recently completed South East Asia Review of medals, anomalies, etc. The former PO MTP Kevin Lee spotting the publicity approached me with the attached details of miscarriage which occurred as our ship was about to leave Kure, Japan after a nine-months tour of duty of Korea in 1955. It had to do with assault on a Japanese taxi driver.

My own recollection of events are attached as a separate deposition together with other relevant documents provided by Lee. He claims he is innocent of a charge which led to his serving 45 days in a Japanese prison and which in turn led to his not receiving the Naval Long Service and Good Conduct Medal.
I left SHOALHAVEN—

speech.para: that is the ship—

quote.para: almost immediately on return to Australia and in less than one month was navigating ARUNTA to the South China Sea as the first ship of the FESR.

speech.para: That is, the Far East Strategic Reserve. The letter continues:

quote.para: Thus, I had not known of Lee's incarceration in Japan.

Personally I believe him to be innocent. However even if he was as `guilty as sin' the legal process (without defending counsel or first-hand witnesses) clearly constitutes a mis-trial. On that basis he remains innocent.

speech.para: He concludes:

quote.para: I am not happy with this `one'.
Could it be `looked at' please.

speech.para: As I said, Rear Admiral Kennedy, a very distinguished former senior naval officer, goes to some lengths to set out the circumstances that he believes led to a serious miscarriage of justice towards my constitutent. He goes into some considerable detail, having provided it to the Chief of Navy, on the mistrial that occurred, including: the accused did not have a defending counsel, he did not understand the charge or the proceedings—they were conducted in Japanese—and no first-hand witness was available to provide identification.

All this material was provided to the Chief of Navy—some of it had been provided earlier to the minister—and on 23 March last year Rear Admiral Kennedy got a letter from the Research Officer to the Chief of Navy, which read as follows:

quote.para: Your letter outlining an alleged miscarriage of naval justice ... is indeed an issue that requires closer scrutiny than perhaps was given in 1955. The circumstances surrounding the incident and actual trial appear to be unmerited—
