speech.para: note those words, `appear to be unmerited'—

quote.para: in light of your information.

speech.para: This response was eventually followed up, however, in due course by a letter to my constitutent Mr Lee on 27 October last year. Amongst other things, the letter said:

quote.para: Unfortunately as the matter is now some 45 years old, and despite the evidence that you have provided—

speech.para: and the evidence that Rear Admiral Kennedy provided and that of some of his ship colleagues—

quote.para: it has been impossible to garner the type of information required to rebut the charges. As a result, and following advice from DLO—

speech.para: I presume that is the Defence Legal Office—

quote.para: I have been unable to conclude that your trial was improperly conducted and therefore cannot justify the overturning of your conviction.
Likewise, I have reviewed the King's Admiralty Regulations as they pertain to the award of a LS&GCM.

speech.para: That is, the Long Service and Good Conduct Medal. The letter continues:

quote.para: As you have been previously informed, one of the criteria to qualify for a LS&GCM is that a member must have served for 15 years with continuous `Very Good' conduct and with previous character not inferior to `Good' in service qualifying for pension. As a result of your 1955 conviction, your Service Record was annotated to reflect `unsatisfactory conduct' ...

speech.para: The Chief of Navy finishes:

quote.para: I am truly sorry that I cannot give you the decision you seek. I have no power to alter the regulations that were in force at that time. Should any additional information on your conviction come to light, I would be very happy to receive it for further review.

speech.para: I would suggest that that is a particularly unsatisfactory response for a gentleman whom I know well and who is highly respected in my community, particularly in the returned services community in my electorate. As a man who is now ageing, he takes great pride in his service to this country. I emphasise again that he has a sailor of the distinction of Rear Admiral Kennedy actively supporting his case, suggesting that not only was the substance of the case incorrect but also that there were serious miscarriages of what we would expect as part of a fair judicial system in the conviction. As this gentleman enters an age in life where he is reflecting on these matters, and in his retirement is giving it greater consideration, he wants his name cleared and his honour restored. Yet we get this run-around and gobbledegook. Frankly, it is just not good enough and I take this opportunity to again call on the appropriate ministers to review the situation. If there is a need for some legislative change to restore justice, good stuff; let that be done.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—I believe that this is a most important consideration, and I am pleased that the parliamentary secretary opposite, the member for Leichhardt, supports this. This is a matter that ought not be subject to partisan politics. It is a matter on which I think people on all sides of this chamber can agree. I am delighted that the parliamentary secretary is providing support in this.
—Absolutely.

—In the short time I have left I wish to move on to another matter of local significance in my electorate—that is, some 17-odd hectares of Department of Defence land on the Maribyrnong River. Over recent decades, the Maribyrnong River has become a significantly enhanced recreational and environmental asset for the people of the north-western suburbs of Melbourne. With this one exception, this one parcel of land, it is an area that has almost uninterrupted community access along its banks to its recreational and environmental resources. But, in Essendon, this one particular parcel of defence department land is closed off to the local community, and the local community is anxious to get access to it.

speech.para: The defence department are prepared to dispose of this land, but there has been some nonsense spoken by them in recent times about wanting to extract the absolute maximum for this land by allowing residential development on it. It is simply unsuitable land for residential development. Apart from its proximity to some very beautiful stretches of river, in many parts it is also land that is badly contaminated because it is part of the land that during wartime, and probably right up to the early 1960s—certainly to the 1950s—was used for defence production associated with the Maribyrnong complex—the Department of Supply as it then was. So this land simply is not suitable for residential use but, with some modest cleaning up, it is suitable for recreational and conservation use. The local council is prepared to negotiate, and is in the process of negotiating, with the defence department to acquire this land at recreational land value, not at residential value.

talk.start.para: —It should be a gift to the nation.

—Yes, it should be a gift to the nation. I thank the member for Batman for reminding me of that. At the last election, the Prime Minister did make some announcements about land fronting Sydney Harbour being returned to the Australian community for recreational use.
—He is Sydneycentric.

—Maybe he is Sydneycentric, but here is an area in Melbourne where the local community would certainly benefit. The local council is prepared to maintain it and look after it and, frankly, they are prepared to pay a little for it to the Commonwealth. But we have not yet finalised the matter with the defence department. I think this is very unfortunate. It does reduce the opportunity for the local community to enjoy this land. As I indicated, the land in many areas is contaminated and is simply unsuitable for other sorts of uses. If one were to try to have it for residential usage, one would have to put the dozers in to create a road into the site.
—The member for Leichardt would like that.

—He may, but even the member for Leichhardt, who was so helpful on the naval matter, would recognise that it is not very smart to put a dozer into contaminated soil and expose that soil to the elements so that it blows into the local residential community and into the river and ultimately contaminates Port Phillip Bay.

—I take a more charitable view of the parliamentary secretary than does the member for Lyons because he was so supportive on the naval matter. Let me just conclude by taking this opportunity also to urge the Defence Organisation to accept that the community in the north-western suburbs of Melbourne for many generations now has provided the work force for probably the most substantial Australian defence production in this country. Certainly the Maribyrnong complex was, until very recently, the centre of a whole range of defence production. Really, it is not asking too much for that local community to now have the full cooperation of Defence in returning this land to the community for recreational use rather than trying to extract a few dollars by using it for a purpose which would cause an environmental catastrophe. Defence should ensure that this area of land—some 17 hectares—is returned to the community so that there is continuous public open space right along the Maribyrnong River, which is in fact the main river of Melbourne; the Yarra is purely a tributary of the Maribyrnong. If Defence were to do that, the local community would certainly benefit. (Time expired)

—I would also like to reinforce the request by the member for Maribyrnong for the government to actually make a gift to the people of Melbourne. It would be appropriate if it announced that gift when the ceremonial meeting of parliament is held in Melbourne in May this year. I think the member for Maribyrnong has acknowledged that there have been gifts to the nation in the form of lands in recent times, but they seem to be a little bit Sydneycentric. In the not too distant future the parliament will actually travel to Melbourne to celebrate 100 years of parliament's existence.

speech.para: I think it is also fair to say that the area represented by the member for Maribyrnong is not what you would describe as one of the better-off areas of suburban Australia, especially suburban Melbourne. It is an area that has done it tough; it is an area that has pulled its weight in the best interests of the nation at large. It would therefore be appropriate for the new Minister for Defence to give serious consideration to this request, especially as he is a resident of Victoria. It would be a clear statement that he is prepared not only to face up to his national responsibilities but also, importantly, where appropriate, to assist Victorians in getting the same access to assistance that people in Sydney seem to get from the Prime Minister when it comes to gifts to the nation.

I would also like to talk about why the Howard government is on the nose in regional Australia—something that the member for Leichhardt is well aware of. In doing so, I would like to draw to the attention of the Main Committee an interesting document that I came across the other day, and I want to go into that document in some detail. It is an historic document, and it has been previously tabled in the House and the Senate. It is not my document; the document belonged to the former shadow minister for regional development and infrastructure of the Howard opposition prior to the 1996 election. It details a Howard shadow cabinet decision that was made before they were lucky enough to win government in March 1996.

It is interesting to note that before the Howard government came to office—and I know the member for Lyons would be interested in this—it actually had some interesting ideas for regional development and infrastructure. Up front, the shadow cabinet document stresses that the coalition should support the regional development effort. It is a very interesting document; I am sure the member for Lyons would like to cast his eye over the document later in the evening.

After the Howard government was elected, one of its first acts, despite the submission to its shadow cabinet of the time, was to abolish the Office of Regional Development. It declared in a press release that there would be no role for a Howard government in regional development. I think it is fair to say that such a position is being exposed today for what it was then: short-sighted. It was suggested in the shadow cabinet document that existing state regional development groups be supported rather than Labor's regional development organisations. So the coalition abolished all support for regional development organisations. The problem was—as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, coming from Tasmania, a region that has a requirement for special regional assistance—that the Howard government did not put anything in the place of the Office of Regional Development when it abolished it and walked away from its responsibility to support regional development organisations. There was nothing left. There has been no support at all from the Howard government for regional development since March 1996.

The shadow cabinet document also suggested that the coalition move some Commonwealth agencies out of Canberra. That would have been good, because it would have been a continuation of decisions of the Hawke and Keating governments to, for example, locate taxation offices in regional Australia and provide access to the Family Court and other court proceedings in regional Australia. You know this, Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, because Tasmania was one of the beneficiaries of that deliberate government policy of taking services out to regional areas so that people in regional Australia would have access to them in the same way that people in the cities have. It would also, importantly, create regional employment opportunities. But what did the Howard government do, despite that statement in the shadow ministerial document? I think it is fair to say that they moved one Commonwealth agency out of Canberra, and that was the Office of Regional Development. That decision did not create any benefit, and nothing was put in its place to support regional Australia. All we had was a decision to abolish the Office of Regional Development.

That is when the Howard government told the truth and declared that it saw no role for our national government in regional development. It is almost as if they thought, `All we need to do is abolish the Office of Regional Development and the Prime Minister can wear an Akubra and travel around regional Australia trying to suggest that he has a little bit of interest in the needs, aspirations and concerns of regional Australia.' Other than the Prime Minister wearing an Akubra on an irregular basis, the Howard government took the view that there was no requirement to give any support to regional activities.

The shadow cabinet document did not stop there. It then identified a number of regional issues for the government to consider carefully. It makes very interesting reading, and I am sure the member for Leichhardt will find this interesting. It identified petrol prices—yes, petrol prices in regional Australia—as a major issue of concern. This was not identified today; this was identified more than five years ago in a document prepared for the Howard coalition shadow cabinet in the lead-up to the 1996 election. But what have we had for the past five years, despite the so-called identification of a problem? The government has deliberately lied to the Australian public and increased the price of petrol due to the GST. After denying it and denying it again, the Prime Minister has finally had to cave in to popular opinion and act—but only out of desperation—in light of the campaign run by the Labor opposition.

The shadow document of the Howard coalition opposition has more to say. It says, for example, that we need more flexible labour market arrangements for regional areas. I must say that, since 1996, I have heard on occasion reference to that, such as at Christmas in 1999 when we had, following a major statement by the Prime Minister trying to regain a bit of momentum, yet another endeavour by the Treasurer to undermine the credibility and standing of the Prime Minister when he sought to put the spotlight on himself yet again by making those famous little statements like, `Yes, we have a special proposal for workers in regional Australia.' That was about cutting wages for workers in regional Australia. Despite, for example, the higher petrol prices and other costs of living that are experienced by people in regional Australia, we had the Treasurer, in accord with the thinking of this document, suggesting that we should have some very special labour market arrangements for regional Australia—in essence, cutting their standard of living by cutting their wages. We all know what that means. Regional Australia, in a reaction to the Treasurer's suggestion, made it very clear to the Treasurer what it means, and we soon had a back-pedalling.

In the face of all the uncertainty around the coalition leadership at the moment, if the Treasurer actually gets enough guts to do what he is saying privately—that is, that he would like to challenge the Prime Minister—and he was lucky enough to win the next election, I wonder whether he would actually put in place what he mused about not so long ago with respect to cutting the wages and conditions of people doing it tough in regional Australia. That is very important. We have a Treasurer—part of the Howard government and, if anything, the pretender to the throne—who wants people in regional Australia to work for less than minimum wages. That is what our Treasurer's view is on how we should develop our regions: simply cut their wages. But there is even more. I go to the new Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business—a very good friend to the Treasurer—Mr Abbott, who also thinks that we should have more flexible labour market arrangements in regional areas.

talk.start.para: — The Abbott and Costello show.

—The Abbot and Costello show; you are right. Maybe leader and deputy—who would know? What is Australia in for—the Laurel and Hardy of the coalition government! What we find with the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is that he wants to cut the benefits of unemployed people in regional Australia if they refuse to move to the cities. Strange how that did not apply to the royal family—the Howard family—when they did not want to move to Canberra to live in the Lodge and accept their full responsibilities with respect to the office of the Prime Minister of Australia. There was no cut in wages for the Prime Minister and the royal family, just more and more renovations to ensure that they lived in the lap of luxury in Kirribilli House in Sydney.

speech.para: So I suppose it is fair to say that we should worry about supporting job creation in regional Australia under the Howard government, which just says to those people in areas that are unfortunately experiencing population loss, such as areas of Tasmania and a lot of other regional centres in Australia, `Look, we've got a special message for you. Don't worry about population loss in regional Australia and jobs; just move to the cities. That is the answer to all your prayers—just move to the cities.' I suppose in essence that is the stuff you get promoted within the Howard government. But, having walked away from the task of regional development and slashed support for the unemployed in regional Australia, we then have Minister Abbott, as I have just suggested, wanting to move people to the cities. But why would he want to move people to the city? For one very simple reason: there are no opportunities in regional Australia under the Howard government. That is because, at the moment, we have a government that has walked away and withdrawn from its responsibility to regional development. At the same time, having made that decision soon after its election in 1996, it has simply suggested to those who want to remain in regional Australia—because they do not fit the government's model for the development of Australia—`You must accept lower wages or, alternatively, move to the cities, because it is not for us as a government to actually provide new opportunities in regional Australia.' What a hide—to abandon regional development and to then suggest that they move to the city or take a pay cut! This is what people in regional Australia have got from the Howard government.

No wonder the National Party leader—or the Liberal Party member in drag, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anderson—is in so much trouble. He has been a silent partner in this process of walking away from his responsibilities to represent, as he likes to make out, the needs and aspirations of people in regional Australia. We know the Liberal Party does not do that, but historically the National Party—and in its previous form, the Country Party—has sought to get through a message that they are the party of regional Australia. Well, the proof is in the pudding. There was a shadow ministerial document prior to the 1996 election which supposedly said that the government, on election, would do something for regional Australia. But all the decisions, utterings and actions of the Howard government since that election in March 1996 show that that was yet again a false promise and a false statement of what the coalition government would do when it actually came to support for regional Australia.
I also want to refer to another issue—infrastructure coordination and planning. The document says:

quote.para: We need to approach infrastructure from both the grand vision and the more localised angle.

speech.para: The grand vision, as the document goes on to say, is for a:

quote.para: ... long-term visionary Infrastructure Planning and Priorities Council ... for planning and coordinating long term infrastructure and the funding of it.

speech.para: A few months back the Labor opposition announced that we will establish a national infrastructure advisory council in government to improve planning prioritisation and financing of our infrastructure needs. It was widely acclaimed by the infrastructure community, which has been let down by the Howard government for five years. But I did not notice any government response. I did not hear, for example, from Senator Macdonald, a close friend of the member for Leichhardt, or the Deputy Prime Minister congratulating us. Perhaps they were, I suggest, a bit embarrassed that we have proposed from opposition something that the Liberal and National parties have not managed to deliver in five years. Labor's approach to infrastructure development does differ in some respects. The Howard shadow government cabinet document tells us that the government was not actually interested in delivering better infrastructure. The document says:

quote.para: ... prior to the election we would announce a list of long-term visionary projects we would specifically like the Council to investigate and prioritise, for example: Darwin to Alice Springs Railway, turning coastal waters inland, rejuvenating the Murray-Darling Basin, Adelaide Airport.

speech.para: It goes on:

quote.para: This gives us the flexibility of announcing a lot of major long term visionary matters but without committing ourselves to actually proceeding with them.

speech.para: Interesting reading! It is clear that the government's ideas were based on nothing but promises which would not be delivered, and as we look back on five years of the Howard government we can see that promising what you cannot deliver has been a hallmark of this government. It promises something but then says that it is impossible.

The Howard shadow cabinet document also revealed a proposal for a local government infrastructure program as part of a policy submission which claims to duplicate—what?—the Labor Party's local capital works program. This document has one element of honesty in it and that is when it points out that the Labor approach was enthusiastically supported by local government. What did the Howard government do when it came into office? The local government infrastructure program never saw the light of day.

I have spoken a lot this evening about what the Howard government did not do for regional development. I would now like to remind the House of what the Howard government did do. When they got into government the Prime Minister asked the National Commission of Audit, the famous razor gang, to advise on regional development. The advice coming from the economic rationalists was predictable. They said, `Abolish the Office of Regional Development and sack the 220 public servants working in Regional Development.' So the Howard government acted on that recommendation. They said, `Walk away from the national role in regional development,' so the Howard government did. To demonstrate how much this policy was driven by the economic rationalists the minister's press release copies word for word the National Commission of Audit recommendation. The economic rationalists, the friends of the member for Leichhardt, also said that regional development programs, support for regional infrastructure and support for best practice should be abandoned. So that is what the Howard government did.

I suggest, in conclusion, that the Howard government walked away from regional economies and regional communities and sided with economic rationalism over ordinary Australians. When the next election arrives people in regional and rural Australia will have a real choice—between a government that has abandoned them for five years and a Beazley Labor government committed to working with and for our regions.

The Howard government regional development history is catching up with it very quickly, as the member for Leichhardt knows. When it catches up with the Howard government at the next election, I would not want to be in the shoes of the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Treasurer or, for that matter, the member for Leichhardt. I will tell you why, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I move around regional Australia, I get one question from voters: `Will you ensure that, upon election, you will deliver the promises that you make in the lead-up to the election?' They then go through a litany of broken promises by the Howard government. Those promises in many ways are detailed in the document that I have referred to this evening—the Howard government's so-called blueprint for what it would do for regional development infrastructure. This blueprint was laid out and approved by the shadow cabinet of the Howard opposition prior to the 1996 election. The document promised tangible support for regional Australia. The Prime Minister promised prior to the last election that petrol prices would not increase because of the GST. The Prime Minister promised before the last election that small business would not suffer because of the GST. The Deputy Prime Minister promised that dairy farmers in regional Australia would not suffer because of dairy deregulation. The Prime Minister promised that he would govern for all Australians.

In this appropriation speech, I simply say that the majority of Australians have had a gutful of the Howard government, its broken promises and its deliberate lies, as well as the misrepresentation of its policies before the 1996 and 1998 elections. The time has come for the Prime Minister to stop doing backflips and to bring integrity, honesty and a commitment to the proper machineries of government in the remaining days of the Howard government. We do not need any more McGaurans and Sharps; we need honesty and integrity in government.

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure to speak on these appropriation bills. Once again we are discussing the ways in which our tax dollar is being spent—how it is to be allocated, the costs involved with introducing a regressive tax such as the GST, the costs of putting this tax onto the Olympic tickets and the costs of implementing all this government's policy without appearing to do anything. Our economy is staggering, our wealth system is being obliterated and social security is being watered down to such an extent that we are almost putting people onto the streets to beg. Education funding now promotes the elite and forgets those in the state system. Where is this supposedly family-friendly government?

speech.para: Education is the means by which we secure a certain type of future for the nation. Now we are educating the elite and forgetting about the other 70 per cent of the population, who have just as much right to a decent education. The state education building program has been blasted. The existing buildings across the country need more than $1.5 billion spent on them to bring schools up to a standard that is adequate but still far behind those private schools. The money for those supposed goals that the minister keeps talking about—literacy and numeracy—is being wasted on managers and bean counters rather than being spent on additional teachers to ensure that children get proper access to education or to innovative programs to help those that are struggling. It is a sad time. It has been said time and time again that the environment in which we live and work throughout our life cycle sets the health risks, learning and behaviour for the individual and the family.

One of the reasons we are having problems with our young people today is that the living environment has been well and truly twisted. Just take the recent spate of television programs. Shows like Survivor, Greed, The Weakest Link and The Mole all exploit the weaknesses of humans—their greed, their vulnerability and their need to be liked. These sorts of programs are just the pits. It is the worst of our American cousins' desire to humiliate people. I suppose the Australian culture adopts them because of our apparent need to knock down the tall poppies, but what does it tell our youngsters? It tells them that, in order to survive, you have to be mean, selfish, greedy and streetwise. I do not think that really personifies the Australian personality.

Historically, we are very much team players. We enjoy our families, we want to look after our mates, money does not mean everything and it is the quality of life that matters. I do not believe these American programs do anything towards improving our lifestyle here or in assisting our children to get a better grasp of what life is all about. Television is a part of our culture and it is important that it develops the good things about our culture. Indeed, there must be comment on the issues but it should ensure that there is some fairness about the reporting on the development of themes. That is why I believe the Australian Broadcasting Commission is so important. Aunty plays a big role in education, and its quality and independence are crucial for a decent and thinking society. Cutting the funds and taking away the independence of such bodies as the ABC has an overall impact on the quality of the environment in which our children grow.

It was the ABC who re-alerted me to a very good and interesting set of ideas being expressed by Dr Fraser Mustard. I met Dr Mustard in Canberra a couple of years ago. Dr Mustard is a Canadian who is the head of the early years task force in Ontario. I do not think that he is a hot mustard—I think he is just an ordinary Dr Mustard. He explained recently on the HealthReport on 6 November 2000 that health went along with human development and that it is the early development of the brain that is crucial to the ongoing wellbeing of humans. He said that a very sensitive period of brain development is the first three to six years of life, which means that the early years usually become important in terms of overall equity and health in the population, not just for the physical and mental health problems later on but also in terms of functional literacy and mathematical skills. He went on to describe one of his studies in Ontario. From that, he came up with some measures of how well or badly children were achieving. The measures considered were verbal skills at the age of four and five, which are predictors of subsequent literacy and which he also said were pointers towards juvenile delinquency.

I must put in here my own theory about those who at a very young age watch television. When they get exposed to such things as SouthPark and other adult cartoons, it must have some serious effect on young children's mental ability to distinguish between right and wrong. Mustard goes on to say that it was not so much income that was significant in his studies but parenting. He said, however, that good parenting can be influenced by the environment in which the parents live. If they are struggling economically and have come from a generation of parents who have also struggled, the pressures become enormous. Those pressures may be because of a lack of finance or work, violence in the family or a lack of help at a crucial time—that crucial time being between when a child is born and when it starts school.

Dr Mustard talked about establishing a kind of birthing centre where both parents would receive training as they began the process of being a parent. This is something that Australia was looking at before the funds fell out of health care. That part of education is now virtually ignored by the present government. It is an area that I believe is sadly lacking in attention. It is no good pouring funds into schools or even into private institutions if you have not first dealt with the early development of a child. In fact, perhaps we should start before the parent becomes a parent. Maybe there should be courses in parenting and what it means to bring up a child—both the joys and the pitfalls.

We need to look at improving the opportunities for families to ensure that children have the best start in life, that there are resources made available to develop programs that will ensure children have an equal chance at full and varied education to cope with the changes going on so rapidly in their world. Another pet theory of mine is that children are not exposed to scientific theories early enough. Work in the curriculum of early learning could allow for more science to be part of our environment. Children are growing up with 30-second grabs of science on the news and no understanding of the way nature works. I do not believe that this government has bothered to consider these sorts of options. It talks about being pro-family, but what exactly does that mean? It is cutting all the government programs that have helped families in the past.

There does not appear to be any direction or any vision anymore. The government is not leading; it is merely reacting. We are not starting to look at what the future should hold for Australia. It is a bit like those opposite trying to plug in a computer in this room. Here we are in a new century, celebrating 100 years of Federation, and instead of looking forward we have our sights firmly on the past. The major commentators of the day have not been concentrating on the future either. Everybody is so tied up in the present, the fortunes of the economy, the government and a few individuals, there seems to the very little discussion of what we should be looking forward to in the future.

There are so many issues that we should be taking a lead on—whether it is improving health care, real health care or just the treatment of illness. We should be getting into preventative health: looking to see if we can bring down the costs of health care by keeping people more healthy. Likewise, education: we should not just be dealing with some ancient theory of compulsory years between five and 16 but the whole of life learning process between birth and when we leave this world. We need a government that has a vision. We need ministers who are prepared to run the gauntlet, to fight for the rights of Australians to have the quality of life that we all aspire to. We need some of our leaders to dream a bit. Okay, we might not be able to achieve it all, but even if we move a bit down towards community aspirations, surely that is better than doing nothing.

No wonder the electorate are jaded; no wonder they are cynical. They are saying that this government is not listening. `It is not caring how government policy affects us,' they say. We have seen this with petrol prices and the backflip, we have seen it with the BAS statements and today we are seeing it with this ridiculous situation of the two per cent clawback on pensioners' incomes. Running a responsible budget is important. But running a government surplus just in case is a nonsense and makes people uneasy about their taxes—where their taxes are going and what they are going to be used for. They have no control of them whatsoever.

All this is evident from the sale of government assets—such as part of Telstra and a whole pile of other government agencies—and a lot of the work that is now being outsourced, which the consumer has very little control over. In our own state of Tasmania we have suffered from such action. Our population is shrinking because of services to our state that have moved out. Headquarters of banks and insurance companies have gone, and so have many branches, particularly in country areas. Services including pensions and other benefits, health, family courts, and communications—and the list continues to increase—have all disappeared. Services have been ripped out of Launceston and, with community pressure, partly put back in.

It is left to the local communities, of course, to pick up the pieces. These communities, as in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, have been picking up, and they are keeping the ideas flowing. These people are holding their communities together, and the government should be listening to them. Some of these people have a vision for the future. In Tasmania, they have worked hard to survive, and they are now asking the big questions in their communities: how to deliver services with less in the way of funds, how to make life work, whether to keep our small hospitals, how to provide vocational training for young people and how to help others to develop employment out of new ideas.

Quality of life is certainly what people expect, and that is not measured in financial terms. A better measure would be happiness—if we could in some way measure that. There has been work done on the degree of happiness, particularly in young people, and it is this measure that is used to see how satisfied or otherwise a young person is with his or her life. Work on suicide in young people has developed this measure. It is about a young person's lack of happiness with their relationships, with their families, with their possessions or with their ability to achieve, to get a job and to keep up with their peers. That plays a role in this terrible situation.

There are other issues. As I mentioned earlier, there are cuts to the ABC. The ABC is a part of Australia. It helps develop a culture for Australia. It has played this role. It has been cut and is continuing to stagger along without being given the resources that it needs to become efficient in new technologies, like the digital technologies. Regarding the situation in regional Australia and the argument put forward by the member for Batman, we know that the Howard government went to the people in 1996 with a platform on regional development. As soon as they were elected, they abolished the Office of Regional Development. It went down from something like 260 people to five—enough people to write the correspondence for the minister and that was all. Of course, that is now what is being reaped by the National Party in regional Australia. There has been no development of regional policy by the government, and they have tacked stuff on as they have run into difficulties.

We had the Treasurer arguing that one way to lift regional Australia was for people in regional Australia to take a lower wage. He said that regional Australia could survive, that South Australia could cut wages by 20, 30 or maybe 50 per cent and that they could attract development and economic activity. That is a pretty poor way to treat regional Australia, but that was a proposition put forward by the Treasurer. Of course, many other services in regional Australia have been cut back and withdrawn.

In Canberra this week we had the Rural Health Conference, with people from the health service delivery area in regional Australia coming to look at better ways of delivering those services, to look at their problems and to work through some of their problems. I had the opportunity of meeting some of them today. They certainly give you some enthusiasm for the way they go about their business. We now have an organised lobby group within this area to help develop and increase opportunities in Australia.

Also today we talked about the cutbacks made by this government to pensioners and its clawback of two per cent of the four per cent CPI increase for pensioners. While this government increases its funding to private schools, while it refuses to tax people who can set up family trusts to get the advantage of paying less tax than other people do even though they have a bigger income, it can claw back from the pensioners of Australia and from other benefit recipients two per cent of a four per cent cost of living increase. That means very bad leadership.

I understand that leadership is a bigger issue in the coalition parties as well. I understand that the Abbott and Costello team could be talking about a Melbourne-Sydney set-up and that the Prime Minister is starting to get worried about his numbers in the party room. I do not know how the honourable member on the other side of the committee will seek to protect her evolution into junior minister status by cutting a deal with one or the other when the numbers start to fall. It will be interesting to see how she reacts.

talk.start.para: —I find that absolutely offensive and I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. There is a standard of behaviour in this chamber of making the sorts of comments in Mr Adams's statement, but I do not find it acceptable in the parliament for someone to say they believe the member opposite is going to `cut a deal' to protect her status. I cannot see why we have to have those sorts of slurs in this committee, I really don't. If we want to have a slanging match across the floor, go ahead, but I suspect the Deputy Speaker would rather sit over a committee that did not have a slanging match going ahead all the time.
—And you are a big buffoon who has not got a clue about what is going on.
(Mr Quick)—Order!
—You are a nasty silly little woman.
—You are a nasty big fat man—
—Order! The parliamentary secretary has made her point—
—And you don't know a thing except to start a slanging match!
—Order! I warn the parliamentary secretary. She has made her point. The honourable member for Lyons' time has expired.

—I am very pleased to be able to talk tonight on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2000-2001, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2000-2001 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2000-2001. Before I commence bringing the voice of the people of Stirling into the parliament and sharing with the government their concerns about the lack of an adequate coastguard in Australia, I would like to touch for a moment on the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2000-2001. In the second reading speech on that bill, the minister says that it provides additional revenues for agencies to meet expenses in relation to grants to the states under section 96 of the Constitution and for payments to the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. I am very pleased at the recent win by Dr Geoff Gallop and the coming of a Labour government to Western Australia, and I look to that appropriation bill to provide the kind of funding and resources that Western Australia needs to rebuild the services—the health, education and community services system—which have been so depleted over the last couple of years. This, again, has been a source of great anxiety and angst for the people of Stirling. Dr Geoff Gallop's win makes my job a lot easier because I am now working with state colleagues to implement a Labour vision of how Australia can be better for all.

speech.para: The issue I mainly want to talk about in relation to these appropriation bills is the need for a properly developed coastguard. In an excellent Parliamentary Library research paper entitled The developing policy pressures in Australian coastal surveillance, under the heading `major issues', the point is made that:

quote.para: There is no overriding jurisdiction covering enforcement of law in maritime areas under Australian control. Rather, legislative authority lies with of a number of Commonwealth and State agencies that hold the responsibility in general, whether enforcement is required on land or water. The jurisdictions reflect Australia's history of federalism and do not necessarily coincide in any logical way.

speech.para: It then goes on to say:

quote.para: The most important characteristic of the Australian coastal surveillance system is that there is no agency with the core role of and, thereby, legislative authority for overall law enforcement in the nation's maritime jurisdictions.

speech.para: It further states:

quote.para: Coastwatch, the organisation which coordinates most coastal surveillance activity reflects this situation.

speech.para: That brings me to the vision of the people of Stirling, which is also the vision of the Australian Labor Party—that is, the need to develop a cohesive, modern, integrated system. I am pleased to say that a Beazley Labor government will establish an Australian coastguard that will have overall responsibility for our coastal surveillance and protection. Labor is committed to improving Australia's coastal security. The current arrangements are clearly not working. People regularly ring my office stressed and upset whenever they see people-smuggling boats arrive, because the majority of them have arrived off the north-west coast of Western Australia. They are concerned that we seem to be so open to incursion not just by people smugglers but also by the fishing fleets of many nations that come down into the Indian Ocean into Western Australian waters to fish inside our economic zones, in breach of not only Australian law but international law.

People are also concerned about the open access to the coast for drug smuggling. There have been many instances of yachts bringing in drugs. When the various authorities have conducted surveillance or have targeted people suspected of bringing in drugs, they have been able to successfully find some of these drug hauls and deal with the people through the legal system. Again, it raises anxieties in the hearts not only of Western Australian people but of other Australians. But it is on the west coast that a lot of these activities have been discovered and chased up. Despite the efforts of Coastwatch, people are concerned that it is happening more and more regularly. There are also the poaching of pearls and quarantine related issues.

People feel that Australia needs a coordinated approach to address the difficulties I have just mentioned, and I support their thoughts on this matter. Labor wants to establish an Australian coastguard and has asked the government to seriously consider as a model a coastguard that is responsible for conducting coastal surveillance and meeting Australia's maritime protection needs, as well drawing together the resources, programs and activities currently undertaken by the Australian Defence Force and other agencies. I point out that there are a number of agencies involved and, as the library research paper points out, the client agencies are: the Australian Fisheries Management Authority; Environment Australia; the Australian Customs Service; the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; the Australian Federal Police; the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service; the Great Barrier Marine Reef Marine Park Authority; the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; the Department of Defence; and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. This is a large number of client agencies and there is sometimes difficulty with their coordination. Coastwatch, which coordinates most coastal surveillance activities, has no legislative base of its own to cover its functions. This has led to difficulties and coordination failure, one of these being the surprise arrival of two refugee boats on the east coast in 1999, despite the existence of prior information. How did this surprise happen? It happened because of a breakdown in the transfer of information between these many agencies with responsibility but with no coordination.

In a recent audit, the Australian National Audit Office found the intelligence framework had not worked as well as expected and that some agencies had not continued to develop their intelligence capacities as required in earlier ministerial directives. With such a large number of client agencies, it is easy to see that coordination and passing of information becomes very difficult. What the Labor Party wants, and people tell me they want, is a coastguard that will have primary responsibility for the maintenance and enforcement of Commonwealth maritime law, that will have a full range of law enforcement powers so that it can act as a maritime police force in peacetime, and whose role will extend beyond monitoring the coastline. It will be charged with the detection, surveillance and law enforcement response to people smuggling, drug smuggling, illegal fishing, search and rescue operations, and maritime safety. In peacetime, an Australian coastguard would be a maritime police force within the Justice and Customs portfolio. The operation commander would be seconded from the Australian Defence Force, and in times of declared emergency or times of war the Australian coastguard would form a fourth arm of the Australian Defence Force and have sufficient appropriate training and a command and control structure to enable it to be readily transferred to the control of the ADF.

This framework has been developed by looking at what is currently in place—seeing the gaps and the ad hoc, uncoordinated initiatives that have failed to address the situation—and also by a very close examination of the role a coastguard should play. To put an act through parliament to establish the role, you would have to give such a coastguard the primary responsibility for the maintenance and enforcement of Commonwealth maritime law. It would also need to liaise and cooperate with all relevant state government agencies. The Australian coastguard's role could also extend beyond monitoring the coastline, into the surveillance, detection, and law enforcement of all those other issues such as people smuggling, drug smuggling, illegal fishing, search and rescue operations and maritime safety. There is also the issue of having responsibility for oil spills and environmental protection and pollution control. It could respond to the increasing need for surveillance in our southern waters to prevent illegal fishing and environmental degradation. An Australian coastguard would be a well-trained, well-equipped organisation with the command and control structure that would allow it and its officers to easily integrate with and come under the control of the Australian defence forces in times of a declared emergency or war.

This is an appropriation bill and there seems to be in the government coffers a very good surplus, so it is not that the people of Stirling or I am asking for anything that would cause an impost on the budget or the budget to go into blow-out. There seems to be quite a good financial surplus, so funding and resourcing of an Australian coastguard is a possibility. But in looking at that we would need to look at the current patrol boat fleet. The current fleet of Fremantle class patrol boats is used almost exclusively for coastal surveillance and patrols. These vehicles will not be suitable for or capable of this task into the next century. They are too small and too slow. They are coming to the end of their economic life and require expensive refitting if they are to be retained in service. The government is aware of this and has come up with a scenario. Now is the critical time for decisions regarding the future of the patrol boat fleet. The government should not miss this excellent opportunity to reconsider its plans, its scenario for a `life of type' extension program for the fleet. Instead of pursuing this option, the government should be taking the opportunity now to replace the Fremantle class patrol boats with purpose-built vessels capable of performing a variety of coastguard tasks.

Opportunities for Australian business in outfitting and equipping the Australian coastguard will emerge with the reconfiguration of the existing surveillance fleet, and of course in Fremantle we have an excellent boat building industry as well as a boat repair and maintenance industry. Boats come from all around Australia into Fremantle and the coast of Cockburn there to have fit-outs and maintenance done. There are other places in Australia, too, that have boatbuilding industries, but I can talk with familiarity about the wonderful industry we have in Western Australia.

A new fleet of purpose designed vehicles could be constructed to civil standards at a cost comparable to the costs of a total refit of the Fremantle patrol boat fleet. Technological advances over the last decade allow the use of civil navigation communication and surveillance systems for the vessels that minimise costs but maximise capability. Such vessels would be larger and faster than the Fremantles, and would be capable of being armed as appropriate. Australia also needs the capacity to undertake deep water surveillance of the Southern Ocean to protect our economic interests in these fisheries. The government has allocated funds to lease ship time for this purpose—a commitment that will be maintained by a Labor government but integrated into the responsibilities of the coastguard. In addition to an appropriate patrol boat capability, the Australian coastguard's maritime assets will include the following vessels currently used by Customs: four fast outboard vessels currently used by Coastwatch in the Torres Strait and six small capability launches that are currently being replaced by eight new 38-metre ocean-going patrol boats.

There is also the issue of aerial capability. The coastguard's aerial capability will initially continue to be supplied under current civil contracts and the arrangements whereby the RAAF supplies Orion surveillance hours to Coastwatch. This of course would require agency cooperation—something lacking at times in the current model. But a strong relationship between surveillance intelligence and response is critical to an effective coastguard system. Defence has a vital role to play in enhancing the intelligence and operations capability of the Australian coastguard. The Australian Defence Force currently makes an annual contribution to Coastwatch of 1,800 Fremantle patrol boat days and Orion surveillance flights and provides the Director-General of Coastwatch and liaison staff.

Existing and emerging sophisticated defence surveillance assets will continue to be an invaluable resource for the Australian coastguard. To achieve best coordination of resources and maximum efficiency, the coastguard's intelligence and surveillance headquarters will be jointly located with one of the Australian Defence Force's current national surveillance centres, such as Headquarters Northern Command. The coastguard will complement the Royal Australian Navy in times of conflict, carrying out coastal surveillance and protecting our shores against incursions. An act establishing the Australian coastguard will authorise coastguard vessels to undertake combat duty when placed under ADF command.

The Australian coastguard will have responsibility for the coordination of search and rescue operations currently undertaken by AUSSAR, which resides within the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, and various volunteer groups. The coastguard will also have a volunteer and entirely civil reserve component, which could be called the Australian Auxiliary Coastguard. Membership would include those of the 3,000 members of existing volunteer search and rescue groups who agree to appropriate accreditation and service obligation arrangements with the Commonwealth. This group could provide a localised search and rescue service and could be linked through command and control relations and standardised training to the coastguard. This group could represent a vital reservoir of expertise and commitment. This component will not transfer to the Australian Defence Force in times of war or declared emergencies.

Under Australia's current coastguard surveillance arrangements—to be replaced by the establishment of a new Australian coastguard—Coastwatch, a branch of the Australian Customs Service, is responsible for Australia's civil coastal surveillance. Coastwatch conducts surveillance and response operations according to the competing needs of client agencies and departments—and they are the ones I mentioned before. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority, AFMA, AQIS, ACS, Australian Search and Rescue, the Australian Defence Force and various state departments conduct coastal surveillance and response operations independently of Coastwatch.

The transition to an Australian coastguard would mean that the coastguard would take over Commonwealth maritime policing responsibility. It would be the agency's core activity and it would entail the transfer of the following types of responsibility to the Australian coastguard: the enforcement of all Commonwealth maritime law, including for people-smuggling, quarantine, illegal fishing, customs, drugs smuggling, coastal watch functions and resources.

In 1999 the Minister for Trade went to Singapore and awarded a company from my home state of Western Australia, Geraldton Boat Builders, the contract to supply 20 vessels to the Singapore police coastguard, drawing attention to Australia's expertise in high value manufacture. Surely the minister would recognise that Australia has both the need and the ability to produce coastguard vessels for our own country and not just for other countries. We have the expertise, we have the vision, we have people's angst to deal with, we have practical problems and political problems. But, if we work together in a very focused, bipartisan way on this issue, we would have a solution that would be a politically palatable one to all parties. It would be a solution for the community and would assuage the angst and anxiety that get expressed regularly in talkback radio programs, newspapers and other media, and through my office—and, I am sure, other people's offices. I commend this vision, this model, to the government and will be looking in the appropriation bills for money to be allocated for the implementation of this vision.

talk.start.para: —In the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2000-2001 and associated legislation, I want to address two quite diverse subjects. The first is to look at the institution of the parliament itself, and the second is to talk about future directions in Australia's overseas aid program. As one looks around our institutions, it is possible to identify something of a paradox: politics and government have become the most conservative parts of our society, lagging well behind the rate of innovation that one would find in information technology sectors and in the work of business and social entrepreneurs. Some people say that governments fall these days when they implement too much change. In fact, I think the converse is true: governments that fail to keep pace with the rate of change in society and its economy are overwhelmed. They fall, much as the Howard government will fall, because they have been paralysed by the rate of change and have not acted to help their citizens respond to change.

speech.para: The Howard government is suffering from a complete collapse of trust by the electorate, and this relates to the Prime Minister's promise to restore trust in the institution of the parliament. We are debating parliamentary appropriation bills, and so it is appropriate to look at what sort of public trust now rests in the Australian parliament. The Prime Minister promised to implement and introduce an independent Speaker, yet the three office holders under this government have all been highly politicised people, people who have held highly political jobs before they took the Speaker's chair. Bob Halverson was the Liberal Party Whip before he became Speaker; Ian Sinclair was a former National Party leader before he became Speaker; and Mr Andrew was also a Liberal Party Whip. These were highly political jobs, highly political people moving into the Speaker's chair, totally contrary to the Prime Minister's promise to introduce an independent Speaker. I say that the parliament desperately needs an independent Speaker.

The parliament also needs to modernise the standing orders to improve question time, to move beyond its horse and buggy type of structure and actually move into the information age. There is so much that can be done to improve the interaction and standard of second reading debates.

talk.start.para: —The member for Hindmarsh is a perfect example of what needs to be done to improve standards, given her behaviour here this evening. We also need to deepen the quality of information and the standard of debate in parliamentary democracy. We need to look seriously at Internet forums and the introduction of direct democracy, so that people will feel more empowered by the process of parliamentary democracy. This is not a party political observation so much as one that is relevant for all MPs. There would not be anyone in this place who is not disheartened by the level of public distrust in the institution of the parliament generally. The Prime Minister is in the hot seat at the moment; he is in the gun because he promised to do something about it—and, in truth, trust has collapsed in this government and the institution of the parliament.

speech.para: There are remedies available—I have tried to outline some this evening—and any MP who thinks they are not important is just blind to the truth, blind to the public reality and blind to the feeling in the electorate that the institution of the parliament has grown distant from the concerns and values of the Australian people. We need to get much closer to those concerns and values, and modernising every part of the parliamentary structure is all important.

It is also important to lift standards of public administration in this country. I can give an example very close to the Howard cabinet. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Cabinet, Senator Heffernan, has abused his parliamentary entitlements through his bizarre obsession with homosexuality. It is a standing joke around this building that the senator is personally obsessed with all things homosexual and that he uses his office resources to keep files and run vendettas against homosexual citizens. He has turned his office into a star chamber to satisfy his own homophobic and bigoted views. Unfortunately, this is more than a joke: it is a damning commentary on the Howard government and its attitude to human rights. It is a damning commentary on a government that is willing to tolerate such a person as its cabinet secretary. Senator Heffernan is unfit to serve in such a position. The senator regards homosexuality as a sickness; in fact, he is the one who is quite sick and who needs help. The Prime Minister should not ignore this problem any longer.

There is much to be done to lift parliamentary standards and improve the quality of parliamentary democracy. In the micro, we should address the appalling behaviour and abuse of entitlements by people like Senator Heffernan. In the macro, we should fundamentally reform the standing orders and the structure of the parliament itself.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member for Werriwa should be careful to structure the points that he is making about the senator in ways that would not require a substantive motion.

—I am now moving on to the second matter that I wanted to address this evening, that is, to examine the future direction of Australia's overseas aid budget. Let me relay to the House a true story from my recent visit to India. New Delhi is one of the poorest cities in the world, with almost four million people living in abject poverty. Fortunately, AusAID is supporting some wonderful poverty alleviation projects. One of them is ASHA—Action for Securing Health For All. Under the leadership of a true social entrepreneur, Dr Kiran Martin, this project is achieving results through the creation of social capital. It is rebuilding the bonds of community and cooperation through the empowerment of women's groups and the provision of community health services.

speech.para: In January I visited a reformed slum in Delhi and witnessed first hand the power of ASHA's work. In this country, of course, we from time to time talk seriously about the issue of poverty. In India, it adds a whole new dimension. One just struggles to contemplate the seriousness of their problem. A city like Delhi, with four million people living in abject poverty, has conditions beyond any decent human standards, is certainly beyond anything that is experienced in our nation. But ASHA, with the support of AusAID, is getting results, and it is an important lesson for poverty alleviation and the direction of our aid project. The local women's group on my visit explained to me the foundation of its success. It is training local residents in the provision of basic health care, it is mobilising community effort to create a decent drainage and sanitation system, and it is securing property rights and access to reticulated services; and, most of all, the work of ASHA is giving people the skills and self-esteem to find work in the real economy.

I also learned about the obstacles to poverty alleviation. One woman told me how she did not want to upgrade her home too quickly as this would encourage the local policemen and politicians to seek a bigger backhander. Other residents told me of how they were forced to pay bribes to government officials just to keep their access to the power system. Case by case I heard of the entrenched and sickening level of corruption across all levels of government in India. Stories such as these convey a huge message to those of us committed to social justice. The true enemy of the poor in Third World nations is the corruption of the state. No-one I spoke to in the slums of Delhi said that they were being exploited by McDonalds or Coca-Cola, but they each had an example of government corruption and expressed their hatred of government officials.

The biggest debate in Delhi at the moment concerns the privatisation of the power grid. Unlike similar debates in Australia, it is not an ideological question or an argument between the left and the right. The key policy goal is to end the corruption of the electricity system, whereby 40 per cent of Delhi's power is currently lost to illegal connections. The public sector has created a black market for electricity even though this causes blackouts for its bona fide customers. No private sector company, of course, could tolerate the loss of 40 per cent of its product; hence the commonsense argument for privatisation.

India is a good example of the need for economic reform in the Third World. After centuries of invasions and colonialism, India foolishly adopted the Soviet economic model in its post independence decades. The impossibility of central economic planning added to the level of poverty and nurtured the growth of government corruption. There was very good summary of this in the HindustanTimes on 8 January in an article by Amulya Ganguli, who wrote:

quote.para: ... `socialism' ... has served the Indian political classes well. The word carries a pro-poor ring which is helpful to the parties at election time. All that they have to do is to allocate certain amounts (in crores, of course) for `poverty alleviation' and not bother if only 15 paise out of every rupee meant for such purposes reach the poor, as Rajiv Gandhi once pointed out. The remaining 85 paise apparently keep the wheels of the election machinery of each party—and the personal budgets of politicians—well-oiled. As does the gratefulness of the industrialists who are protected from any threat of competition by high tariff walls—in the name of the poor. Like the criminal-politician-bureaucrat link in the political field, the industrialist-politician-bureaucrat link, along with the subsidy raj favouring affluent farmers, has long kept the Indian economy in a crippled state with its snail-paced Hindu rate of growth.

speech.para: Only since 1991 has a program of economic liberalisation been in place in India. Already, this is achieving impressive results, including the growth of a substantial information technology sector. India desperately needs to develop a large middle-class with the spending power to create service sector jobs with poor. This cannot be achieved without economic openness, market liberalisation and large national investments in education and training.

Further afield, over the past three decades the development of trading economies in East Asia has lifted 150 million men, women and children out of abject poverty. The countries which have been unable to break the poverty cycle—most notably in Africa, Latin America and the old Soviet Union—are those which have been most resistant to free trade and clean economic institutions. This explains the income gap between the world's richest and poorest nations: those which first embraced economic reform have reaped the greatest benefits. Nations which adopted the Soviet model or tolerated systemic economic corruption now have the highest levels of poverty. Internationally, the evidence is clear; the verdict is in. Poverty can be beaten providing governments open their economies to free trade and market based growth, invest heavily in education and training, respect the rule of law and eliminate corruption, build stronger civil societies, value social capital and, finally, mobilise the skills of social entrepreneurs—the sort of people I saw working for ASHA in the slums of Delhi.

These findings from my visit are reinforced by an excellent new book on poverty alleviation in the Third World by the Peruvian development expert, Hernando de Soto. It is called The Mystery of Capital. De Soto's main point is that while there are some assets in Third World nations, they are unable to be converted into decent property rights. Without property rights, poor people find it very hard to trade effectively, to build networks of information and commerce and to enter the real economy—that is, to get themselves out of poverty and into small businesses and jobs. Property rights allow people to trade and to share opportunities in the market economy. Without property rights, they are trapped in a cycle of poverty. Let me give an example to the House from de Soto's conclusions. In talking about Egypt he writes:

quote.para: ... the person who wants to acquire and legally register a lot on a state-owned desert land must win his way through at least 77 bureaucratic procedures at 31 public and private agencies ... This explains why 4.7 million Egyptians have chosen to build their dwellings illegally ... If, after building his home, a settler decides he would now like to be a law-abiding citizen and purchase the rights to his dwelling, he risks having it demolished, paying a steep fine and serving up to 10 years in prison.

speech.para: Egypt is by no means an exception. In Peru, building a home on state owned land requires 207 procedural steps at 52 government offices. In Haiti, obtaining a lease on government land—a preliminary requirement to buying—takes 67 steps. The bottom line, sadly enough, is that all this regulation—all these obstacles to the acquisition of property rights—is very closely associated with bribes and corruption. There is a positive correlation between the level of regulation and the extent of bribes and corruption in these nations—not only in India, Egypt, Peru and Haiti but in virtually every Third World nation across the globe. Again, the bottom line is very clear: the true enemy of the poor in these countries is the state and the systemic corruption of government.

For many on the extreme left of politics, these conclusions are not welcome. They are contrary to an ideological hatred of market economics. They contradict the current militant campaign against globalisation. In effect, they demonstrate the disconnection between the rhetoric of these left-wing groups and the reality of poverty alleviation. If the true enemy of the poor is the corruption of the state, economic reform is actually part of the solution.

The lessons for Australia's aid program are compelling. We need to identify and support the work of social entrepreneurs like Kiran Martin and ASHA. We need to back success. What matters in poverty alleviation is what works in practice. Backing successful projects is all-important. It is very hard to build public support in Australia for a bigger aid budget. The only way we can build support for these projects is to demonstrate success to the Australian people. The sad truth is that there is a lot of corruption in these nations, and aid funding is susceptible to those unhappy processes. But identifying successful projects and seeing people working together, building cooperation, building social capital at a local level and backing their success is the very best way to run our aid budget. We need to build a record of progress so that this parliament can demonstrate to the Australian people that every single dollar of aid funding gets results.

I am very confident that, if we went down this path of identifying and supporting social entrepreneurs, we could build a bigger aid budget. We could demonstrate to the Australian people that our projects are getting results and that they deserve extra funding. We talk in this country about a fair go. The fairest go that we can give in the use of our national resources is to do things for people not only in our own country but also in other countries who are living in conditions of abject poverty.

The first step in addressing poverty is social: building cooperation and networks of trust in local communities. This is the best role for our aid budget: small, targeted grants that get results. I do not support a return to big infrastructure projects. We should leave the building of roads, bridges and other infrastructure to national governments. Our aid budget should be specifically targeted at the work of social entrepreneurial groups at local levels—not big grants and not running through big non-government organisations but small, significant grants that achieve results on the ground.

I am cautious about the work of the big NGOs. My experience in India was that they, too, can be so hierarchical and bureaucratic that they are an obstacle to progress. They become another type of government. There is a different way in which we can structure our aid budget: have our overseas postings and aid workers identifying and supporting people like Kiran Martin and ASHA. This is a new model for poverty alleviation. It is supported by the evidence in so many countries, and it should be built into our foreign aid policies. There is another lesson closer to home: if people really cared about the poor, they would not underestimate their capacity to get results. The lesson from ASHA is that poor people can help themselves if they have the right support and the right sense of self-esteem, success and cooperation within their communities.

It is important not to get caught up with outdated ideologies. This is the problem we have with much of the welfare reform debate in Australia. Affluent people very often disparage these poverty alleviation strategies—the role of the market, the importance of property rights, the significance of civil society, the work and the social entrepreneurs. They have become market sceptics. They no longer have to rely on economic growth for their quality of life, so they think that poor people no longer need to rely on growth. That is how they come up with their antimarket rhetoric.

It is often said that the market and globalisation are immoral. What I find really immoral in this debate is the disconnection of these rich but disillusioned critics from the circumstances of poor people themselves. Poor people know that there can be no answer to unemployment and long-term poverty without economic growth, and history shows that the market economy is the best way of generating growth.

This is the source of the antimarket rhetoric. It is from a group of disaffected rich people who themselves have become disconnected from the circumstances of the poor. We see it in this parliament in the rhetoric of people like the member for Kennedy and his Queensland National Party colleagues. He talks about economic disadvantage, but he never talks about the most disadvantaged group in his electorate, Aboriginal people. He talks about welfare all right—welfare for farmers and other business interests. He does not talk about the need for welfare reform and new poverty alleviation strategies in the Aboriginal communities in his electorate.

Of course, closely related to the member for Kennedy is the phenomenon of Hansonism. Where did Hansonism come from? It came out of Ms Hanson's own interests and perceptions as the owner of a business. It is further evidence that these antimarket politicians are very much disconnected from the circumstances of the poor, and that is indeed a great challenge as we move forward with public policy in this country. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mrs Gallus) adjourned.
